output: Mr President, I very much welcome the approach we describe in the White Paper, which seeks to get to the root causes of malnutrition and obesity and the resulting diseases.
Unfortunately, in European food policy, whether we're talking about nutrient profiles, food labeling, or even in some parts of the White Paper, we fall back on a very one-sided approach.
We are trying to solve the problems we have in Europe through product policy.
And I believe it is fundamentally the wrong approach to assume that there are good and bad foods.
Many proposed amendments demonstrate that this does not exist.
There are only good and bad, or balanced and unbalanced, ways of eating.
This should be our approach.
The causes of poor nutrition are multifaceted.
Trying to solve this by guiding consumers through product labeling, or even by imposing advertising bans or regulations, or by using different VAT rates, will not achieve our goal.

I believe that everything we do here is not meant to preempt the debate on the labeling regulation, but everything we do here should be somewhat under the heading: What can we do to motivate consumers to think about their eating habits?
In my opinion, a traffic light labeling that suggests to him that I am now facing a good or bad product is more an instrument of disempowerment than an instrument of education and enlightenment.
That is why I would like to see a balanced approach here and the realization that the path through product policy alone will not take us forward.
Mr President, Madam Vice-President, dear colleagues, budgetary control is not about new issues.
We are satisfied with the old ones and would also be satisfied with progress on the old topics.
Five points in the forefront: Our urgent plea for support for Romania and Bulgaria in building the rule of law, the judiciary, and financial control.
We don't want to be where we are today in two years, and that's why this point is very, very important to us.
The second point: The declaration of assurance for the overall budget following the tiered control procedure, incorporating the national audit offices.
It would be great if we could make decisive progress in the last six months, which are left to the Commission, or at least agree on a common path.
One becomes modest as a household controller.
The third point would be simplification.
We need to provide more help to the lower administrative levels of the Member States in implementing EU law.
It turns out that they are completely overwhelmed by large parts of EU law, which is why the high error rates occur.
The fourth point is external aid. Here, I would like to address, above all, Kosovo and the question of cooperation with the United Nations.
The Committee on Budgetary Control has been to Kosovo, and I would like to announce that Kosovo will play a certain role in the budget discharge.
I believe that we have fallen far short of the European Union's capabilities so far and that we urgently need to catch up in this area.
The fifth point would be to improve cooperation between member states in combating fraud.
We have homework, primarily for the members of the Council.
The Parliament will vote on the legal basis, the anti-fraud regulation, in November, and then we will have to consider together how to proceed if we want to achieve better results in this area.
That has been our wish up until now.
Mr President, India and Europe need more and better contacts with each other at all levels, especially at the level of so-called ordinary people.
Business travelers, tourists, students, etc. A brief note on this: it also has significance for the Commission's legislative program, which we discussed earlier.
In global air travel, we need good safety regulations, ones that are effective, not just mere alibi measures.
It would therefore be a sensible, truly necessary measure to finally abolish the senseless liquidity regulations and come up with something better.
Mr President, I voted in favour of the resolution because it is a clear call on the Belarusian government to finally respect human rights.

It is disappointing that the hopes for a democratic development for the people of this last European dictatorship were not fulfilled with the questionable, if not fraudulent, parliamentary elections in September.
The same applies to the strategic suppression of the opposition and civil society.

At the same time, we have today called on the Council and the Commission to facilitate and intensify contacts between the peoples and to democratize the country by seriously considering the possibility of a
Consider reducing visa fees for Belarusian citizens when entering the Schengen area, thereby preventing the increasing isolation of Belarus and its citizens.
First of all, I would like to refute the notion, which I heard just a few minutes ago, that foreigners are flooding the job market.
Secondly, I would have liked a clearer, more unambiguous report from the Employment Committee.
Trust in the social cohesion of the European Union can only be achieved if fundamental social rights are defined as European primary law.

We should send a stronger signal to the Council, the Commission, the Member States and the ECJ and not be satisfied with merely calling for a balance between fundamental rights and the freedoms of the internal market and free movement.
This does not change anything. Social fundamental rights, like freedom rights, are human rights that must not be restricted by the free movement within the internal market.
It is about defending and improving the European social model, and it is high time to introduce a social progress clause as a binding protocol to the existing EU treaties.
And it is time to amend the Posting of Workers Directive so that wage and minimum standards requirements cannot be limited to minimum requirements.
Mr President, I would like to join in thanking the rapporteur, Doris Pack, a sentiment that has already been expressed by many of my colleagues, and quite rightly too.
We have someone with her who, hopefully, doesn't actually shed her heart and soul, but invests a great deal of heart and soul into this space.
I am pleased with you and the colleagues who have also said that there have been some advances, including in the area of police cooperation.
This is important so that actual life on the ground can also function in reasonable ways.

I still believe, however, that we must repeatedly remind our interlocutors in Bosnia and Herzegovina that a great deal still needs to be contributed by them, from their side, probably more than is currently being contributed in some areas.
The internal cooperation, the willingness to engage in this internal cooperation within the ethnic groups is something that we must constantly demand.
It's not a case of everyone trying to go their own way.
And also the integration into the regional cooperation in the Western Balkans is important.
Madam President, the distance between the European Union and its citizens must not become as great as it has become.
We need to make sure it is reduced in size.
In this context, the Ombudsman has an important task, especially when and where he does it well.
Above all, it is also about the fact that we must expect the Ombudsman to act with commitment and a sense of proportion.
The point is that we should not raise expectations that are too high for anyone to meet.

However, on the other hand, it is also about addressing the shortcomings that have occurred in the administration of European institutions wherever they may be found, and, if possible, seeking reasonable solutions that can ensure and satisfy the citizens.
Experience to date has shown that the Ombudsman takes this task seriously and does a good job of it.
We can hope that this will continue to be the case, and we thank him and the rapporteur for this report.
I'm a little nervous.
Dear colleagues, ten years after the realization of monetary union, Europe is in a severe crisis.
Banks are collapsing or are being supported with billions of dollars from the state budget, sales are plummeting, and millions of people are worried about their jobs and their future.
But it is not only the market that has failed; the ruling politics also seem incapable of learning from their mistakes.

We believe that even with such interim comments, you do not wish to particularly distinguish yourself. We believe that serious mistakes were made during the construction of the Economic and Monetary Union.
One such mistake is the structural separation of monetary and fiscal policy. You cannot create a common currency without simultaneously harmonizing tax and spending policies, at least in outline.
I think the economic imbalances in the Eurozone have become enormously worse.
What we need now is indeed better coordination of economic and, above all, tax policies.
We need effective measures against tax dumping, tax havens must be closed, and capital flows must finally be controlled again.
We see the second serious mistake in the construction of the Stability and Growth Pact.

Anyone who considers household consolidation to be inevitable in times like these is obviously living in a different world. There would be nothing more disastrous than responding to this economic crisis with public austerity programs.
The Stability Pact has clearly demonstrated its failure.
It should be replaced by an integrated European strategy for solidarity and sustainable development.
In our opinion, what is needed is an investment offensive to renew public infrastructure and improve the situation of the socially disadvantaged in Europe.
We see a third mistake in the construction of the European Central Bank itself, which is not subject to democratic control and is solely committed to the goal of price stability.

We advocate for democratic control of the European Central Bank and also demand a correction of the ECB's monetary policy mandate, which in the future must promote growth and employment at least equally with price stability.
The current crisis also offers an opportunity for profound reforms of the European monetary and financial architecture.
This opportunity should not be squandered lightly.
Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, honourable Members, the automotive industry is indeed in crisis, and there are many reasons for this.
The financial crisis, in particular, has accelerated the crisis in this sector, and member states are currently working on solutions.
The European automotive industry is a key industry.
And that is why we need European solutions for this key European industry in order to overcome the crisis.
Almost all car companies have European structures.

And in order to make the necessary investments in environmentally friendly cars - as has been mentioned several times here today - in order to be able to implement environmentally friendly and fuel-efficient technologies, car manufacturers need public guarantees or low-interest loans from the European Investment Bank.
But the supplier industry, which is very important to me, must not be forgotten in this context.
It is precisely in the supply industry, in small and medium-sized enterprises, where jobs are created and where innovations take place.
But what can the European Union do to protect this key industry?
In the last plenary session, the Council President made a proposal to protect key industries.
A good proposal. In my opinion, if one consistently follows through on this proposal, it would mean a Volkswagen law for the entire European automotive industry.
And this would certainly be a good instrument.
But this protective instrument is currently being fought against by the European Commission.
And my question to the Commission is: Will the European Commission persist with a lawsuit despite the crisis in the automotive industry, or will it change course in light of the crisis?
Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, dear colleagues! Indeed, it has become a tradition to note that,
We must be aware that, in the relationship between spending at the European level and administration at the national level, a statement of assurance cannot be issued repeatedly.

I can recall conversations with the former President of the Court of Auditors, Professor Friedmann, who once told me, "Due to the structures in place, it is not at all possible to provide a declaration of reliability."
That is why we should start thinking about how this instrument can be brought to life in such a way that the goal of a declaration of assurance can be achieved when it is justified.
We need to distinguish a few things from each other here.
Firstly, a budget that includes around 95 subsidies is much more susceptible to fraud than a national budget, a regional budget, or a municipal budget.

A subsidy budget, which is essentially managed by the member states, who have demanded much more independence from us in the new financial period, because the criticism in the last funding period was that too much was centrally controlled.
Of course, this also means that responsibility for the money must be taken on at regional and national levels.
And I just want to briefly touch on a third area of focus.
We also need to learn to distinguish between fraud and waste.
These are also things that are always thrown together.
I also get annoyed when EU money is used to fund things that aren't absolutely necessary.
But that was not fraud, that was waste.

Therefore, those who are responsible for the projects, especially in the field of structural policy, the Member States, also have the responsibility to ensure that money is not wasted and that only projects which really generate added value for the region are promoted.
That's why I think we should consider converting parts of the structural policy into interest-free loans.
If Member States have to repay funds, they will only promote what they really need. Thank you very much!
It is not just me who finds it difficult to agree with the emerging self-praise of European decision-makers when it comes to dealing with the financial market crisis.
This is not going to happen, because if this EU were a functioning democracy, one would first have to ask the question of responsibility for how all of this was allowed to happen.
It is simply not true that all the problems we are facing now are a tsunami, something natural, but rather they are man-made.
With all the regulatory fervor that this Union has unleashed, one wonders: Why wasn't action taken when banks began to cross national borders on a significant scale?
Why, despite appropriate warnings, did no action take place when derivatives crept in like this?
I remember well that Nobel laureate Josef Stiglitz was here and addressed all these points.
There was a silence, there was a taboo.
That is where one must start, because recognizing one's own mistakes is the only key to finding solutions in the future.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, my question is about what you think of Iceland and Hungary introducing the euro as a second currency.
Do you think that could solve the problem of these two countries?
The second question is: Do you believe it would be possible to introduce a risk premium for derivatives, which could then be used to strengthen the banks' equity capital?
My third question is, do you not believe that a reduction in value added tax would accordingly support imports, especially from China and India?
Wouldn't it be more reasonable to consider tax reductions for our businesses and our employees, to pay investment premiums, and to adjust the progressive depreciation accordingly?
The focus is on increasing low-value economic goods by a factor of 10, so that apparent profits are not taxed, the money remains in the businesses, and wages can be paid better as a result.
Madam President, the comprehensive report highlights the numerous human rights violations that occur daily around the world.
This is particularly alarming 60 years after the declaration of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and calls on us to intensify our efforts.
This is also why I would like to advocate for establishing the current Subcommittee on Human Rights as a main committee.
Today we awarded the Sakharov Prize to Hu Jia, who advocates for human rights and the environment in China.
However, because he is incarcerated, he was unable to take possession of it in person.
A disgrace for China, and tomorrow there will be a debate here on human rights violations in Russia.
In our relations with these two countries, not only economic interests, but above all human rights, must be given a higher priority.
We demand freedom for Hudzhia in China and freedom for Mikhail Khodorkovsky in Russia.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council, Commissioner, dear colleagues, as rapporteur for the Anti-Fraud Office, one gains interesting experiences, such as the fact that everyone talks about combating fraud and then no one does anything.
Or the experience that the member states calculate their payments to the European Union with a fine-tipped pen, but when it comes to spending this money, they pull on their tight pants?
and even make it easy for fraudsters, for example, by the fact that it still takes an average of 36 months for irregularities to be reported to the European Union at all.
The European Parliament disagrees with this.
We want efficient fraud prevention that also includes prevention.
We want the member states to make the fight against fraud a priority and for us to discuss the necessities and challenges together.
We want to see greater interest from national judicial authorities in following up on OLAF's mediation results.
In the case of curved routes, there can no longer be areas free of right-of-way as has been the case up to now.
We need to equate European money with national money.
We want an independent agency that has the necessary resources and legal basis to fulfill its tasks.
And we want an office that can work smoothly and efficiently with the member states.
Our opinion on the legal basis 1073 covers all these points.
We advocate for the further development of this regulation as the core of the anti-fraud office, in collaboration with the Council.
We urge the Council to incorporate our opinion, we urge the Council to begin discussions on the further development of this regulation.
We want to bring OLAF's problems to a solution.
I thank all the factions of the High House for supporting this in a resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.
I appeal to the French and Czech Council Presidencies to take up Parliament's ball and pass it back.
In our proposals, we have also incorporated solutions developed and submitted by the Council working group.
On our part, I can tell you that we are interested in a swift conclusion of this regulation and assure you of our constructive willingness to engage in discussions based on our proposals.
Consolidating all the OLAF legal bases, as the Council has indeed planned, would mean a further considerable loss of time with an uncertain outcome.
OLAF is soon to celebrate his 10th birthday.
Consolidation means another ten years without an improved legal basis.
We take the fight against fraud too seriously for that.
That is why we want to implement what is feasible now in cooperation with the Council.
Thank you very much!
Mr President, I would like to take up a point that my Austrian colleague Paul Rbig raised earlier.
We spend less than 1% of the European GDP on Europe, and at the same time we demand that the European Union should handle more and more tasks for more and more member states.
This accounting cannot be wrong, it is therefore also truly unbelievable that we have been on a cost-cutting course for many years, but this cost-cutting course is not only about being frugal.
They are not really using our money to achieve our goals, but rather to ensure that the finance ministers can collect the money at the end of the year and add it to their domestic budgets.
We would have enough new tasks for which we should spend our money.
We also have tasks that we have not really adequately funded in terms of the budget for years.
I believe that the European Union's information funding needs to be significantly increased if we really want to connect European citizens to Europe.
And there are many tasks in the area of student and apprentice exchange that Europe could deploy here.
The Commission is also advancing in the justice sector, a traditionally state-reserved area.
This corresponds to the changed living conditions of people in our Union.
But - and this point has already been made several times - integration must not interfere too much with traditionally established structures, especially those that are already functioning well.
Not everything can be lumped together.
Public documents and public notaries are interpreted quite differently in many member states.
In Austria, but not only in our country, the notary profession as a public authority for authenticating documents has a long tradition and enjoys a high level of security and trust.
This should not be jeopardized unnecessarily, just because such professional groups do not exist elsewhere.
Therefore, integration and mutual openness are a good thing, but in moderation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, plant protection products have been and remain essential inputs for agriculture.
Farmers need a minimum selection of plant protection products because it is about protecting the native cultural landscape, providing high-quality nutrition, and conserving resources.
We discuss chemicals all too often on a very irrational level.
But in order to get sensible results, we must think and act rationally.

The consequences of the original parliamentary stance would have been disastrous: a broad ban on plant protection products would have led to lower agricultural yields and, ultimately, rising food prices.
Therefore, I am glad that a barely acceptable compromise was found in the trilogue negotiations.
It is commendable that we have maintained the three-zone system, albeit with significant exceptions for the member states.

A courageous step towards a consistent internal market solution would look different. In addition to acceptable compromises, we should not pre-empt a final definition of endocrine-active substances, but actually give the EU Commission the four years of time to present a scientifically sound definition.
Otherwise, we would be stretching the precautionary principle at this point.
And finally, I find it regrettable that we have not been persuaded to initiate a follow-up assessment of the agreement that has now been reached.
Mr President, the last time a head of government or head of state visited and expressed similar opinions, the President of this House intervened very strongly.
At that time, it was about an issue that was important to him personally, namely the Lisbon Treaty.
When today the president, the sovereignly elected president of a country, speaks and is massively interrupted, disturbed by the socialist side, the president does not shout back.
Do you know what that is?
This is not democracy, this is arbitrary rule, and I demand that appropriate measures be taken.
Madam President! Children and politics, rarely do the interests of citizens and politicians diverge so widely.
The issue of children is at the top of the agenda for citizens across Europe.
For politicians, children's interests are arranged under distant lives, as we can see here once again.
I know of no country that has its own Ministry for Children. Nor does the Commission have its own representative for the interests of our youngest citizens.
The issue of children is spread across all parliamentary committees.
That is why I would like to particularly emphasize to the Commission at this point that it is dealing with childcare facilities and the Barcelona objectives today.
Mr President, in our parliamentary working group on Quality of Childhood, we have established the following: Our children live in a very complex world.
The future of a person who is a child here, now, and today is completely uncertain.
A child today can climb all the way to the top of the social ladder or fall all the way to the bottom.
It can remain in its own cultural circle or seek a new one.
They may follow a similar life path to their parents or do exactly the opposite.
One can marry someone of the opposite or the same gender.
All of this was completely different more than 50 years ago, when we christened the united Europe.
The diversity that distinguishes us Europeans has become a determining factor in the lives of children.
The concept of diversity must therefore be incorporated into the pedagogy of child-care workers and teachers.
This is still far too little taken into account at present.
Europe's childcare facilities and schools are indeed struggling with the challenge of integration.
In matters of integration, we need to press the reset button and go back to the beginning.
That is why we are approaching this topic once again completely free of prejudice, in accordance with the motto 'Unity through Diversity'.

And furthermore, I ask all the Members of the European Parliament who follow me: Do not only advocate for gender mainstreaming, but also fight for children's mainstreaming, especially now during the global financial crisis, because otherwise we will impose immeasurable debts on our children.
Thank you, Mr. President. I will keep this very brief.
I am very grateful for the constructive contributions to the debate that I have heard here.

I would just like to send out two final messages. Firstly, I would like to expressly thank the Commissioner for not having fundamentally spoken out against the concept of minimum requirements for the safety net.
This proposal is not the work of the devil, and it is not a bureaucratic monster either.
It is a problem-solving tool that we should give a chance.
That's why I would like to advocate for it here.
And the second thing I want to say, and this is now directed at my British friends, is to cross all the parties.
My dear British friends, I do understand Caroline, I do understand your problem.
I can well understand that a country might prioritize energy security over compliance with an air pollutant limit value for a certain period.
I have great understanding for that.
I am also the last person who would not give Her Majesty additional time when it comes to building new coal-fired power plants.
We can talk about it.
The problem is, we haven't done exactly that.
This conversation has never taken place over the last four months.
I would like to ask you, this is now the outlook in the second reading, to be open-minded again at this point and to say Let's talk about a compromise here.

I am in favor of abandoning the resistance, which I see as completely irrational and unjustified from a competition and environmental policy perspective, the fundamental opposition to the minimum standards.
This is the point where a compromise can be reached, which I hope will also be achieved in the second reading.
Incidentally, I do not believe that we should not seek a compromise in a first reading.
This legislation is too complex for that.

I do not want to end this legislative term as rapporteur and leave the next Parliament with legislation in which a legislative text is being discussed that is inconsistent, illogical, and contradictory.
That is why I am asking for support for the compromises when we vote here in an hour.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think the crucial question regarding all the economic stimulus programmes currently being put together across Europe is, of course, who ultimately receives the money?
more blank checks are being issued to the banks, even though rapid nationalization would ultimately be much cheaper for the taxpayer.
Should corporations and high-income earners be further relieved of their burdens, even though they have been fattened up for years throughout Europe with tax gifts?

The more money is squandered on such purposes, the more foreseeable it becomes that such programs will fail, and the more likely it is that the European economy will continue to sink into a very dangerous downward spiral.

The years-long policy of privatization, deregulation, and liberalizationexactly this policyhas increasingly concentrated income among the top ten thousand, and it was this policy that is responsible for the current crisis in which we find ourselves today.
Anyone who believes that they can overcome this crisis by continuing to pursue exactly this policy with minor modifications simply hasn't understood anything.
The exact opposite of this is needed.
Instead of buying up bad debts from banks, tax money should be used to renovate schools, hospitals, and to restructure the European economy in an environmentally friendly way.

If private companies receive public funds, the following must apply: No tax money without employment guarantees and, above all, no tax money without the acquisition of public property rights, so that the state and, above all, the general public can also share in the future profits.
The best economic stimulus program currently available would be a radical redistribution of income and wealth from top to bottom.
The low-wage sector in Europe must be reduced, rather than being continually promoted.
We need higher minimum wages, we need better social benefits in Europe.

And we need taxes that ensure that the millionaires and the beneficiaries of the past financial market party now also bear the immense losses that have been incurred, and not the vast majority of citizens who never benefited from the financial boom in the first place.
I believe that the socially just is currently also the only economically sensible approach.
It is the only way to break the devastating crisis dynamics.

Mr President, at the beginning of March, the political prisoners Mikhail Khodorkovsky and Platon Lebedev were transferred from Chita in Siberia to Moscow in order to be charged again on the basis of untenable accusations.
The first public hearing day was scheduled for March 31.
On the same day, the EU-Russia human rights consultations were supposed to take place.
These important talks have now been postponed by the Russian side indefinitely.
Russia is thus demonstrating very clearly the low priority it places on human rights.
The judiciary continues to be used not only to ensure justice, but also to eliminate regime opponents, and the EU is being duped as a result.
Mr President, Commissioner, thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen. I am particularly grateful to Commissioner Verheugen for once again pointing out the ban on animal testing.

I drew the attention of the honourable Member to this because it reminds me that this is now the third amendment to the cosmetics legislation that I have had the privilege of accompanying. The sixth amendment, the seventh amendment and now the amendment to a regulation.
And we have indeed managed to ban animal testing.
We have managed to ensure that consumers, for example, know how long a product will last by seeing a small can with a number inside that indicates how long it will remain valid.

I also say this to some of my colleagues, especially to my colleague Reutow, who unfortunately couldn't be here at the beginning. Labels are never warnings. At no point would a product not be safe, in which case it should not be on the market, and it should not be marketed.
Every product on this European market must be safe and harmless.
But the labeling gives consumers the opportunity to choose.
That is democracy, and that is your freedom of choice.
I believe that we have very good legislation.
I have tried to make the process very transparent.
I have tried, as Mrs. Costette also said, to bring together different opinions.

Because I am concerned that we create legislation that is good for everyone, for consumers in the European Union, for the industry that has to work with this legislation, and ultimately for all those who benefit from it.
And when I tell my colleague Schnellhardt, I say again, yes, the DEO works differently for everyone, but the statement "keeps you dry" is still made.
That is why it is important that the statements regarding my wrinkle depth around the eyes after a week in Strasbourg are reasonably realistic and reliable.
I would like to express my thanks once again to the Commissioner, also for the explanations he has provided, to my fellow Members and to my assistant, who has done most of the work.
Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the report by our colleague Mr Van Nistelrooij on the Green Paper and the future form of cohesion policy is certainly one of the most significant reports from the Committee of the Regions in recent years.
We agree with the basic concept of the Green Paper, which states that territorial cohesion is about promoting the polycentric development of the EU.
to ensure overall sustainable development of the territories with different characteristics and features, while preserving their diversity.
It is correct that in the next planning period, a more comprehensive system of phased assistance will be introduced for transition regions that cross the 75% threshold.
20 of the protein crop product will be exceeded, a framework must be created so that these regions receive a clear status and thus have more security in their development.
In colleague Crewe's report on the obstacles to the absorption of the Structural Funds, the most significant shortcomings faced by applicants are rightly listed.

Obstacles to accessing the Structural Funds include, for example, excessive administrative burdens, too many complex regulations, and slow and cumbersome centralized administration in the Member States.
Numerous recommendations are made to the Commission regarding effective measures to be taken to overcome these obstacles.
I would like to single out and emphasize two such measures.
Currently, project managers must retain their project documentation for a period of ten years, in order to have it available for inspections that may be carried out by the Commission.
This is particularly an excessive bureaucratic effort for smaller projects.
It is true that this is now to be reduced to a period of three years. Secondly, the EU Commission's evaluation criteria for innovative projects cause significant problems.
Innovative projects cannot be evaluated using the same criteria as other projects.
It is simply necessary for something different to happen here.

Madam President, when Europe takes money into its hands, and above all when the Member States take a great deal of money into their hands to help the automotive industry in its crisis situation, it cannot only be about securing jobs and the status quo here and preventing bankruptcies, but it is also about a number of other concerns.
The most important ones have been mentioned.
It is about helping people to find employment, and they also need to secure this employment in the long term.
And for that, it is necessary that we promote new technologies, innovation, and above all sustainability in the transportation system more strongly than we have done so far.

We should therefore link all our measures to these objectives so that we do not have to face criticism in a few years' time. We should have thought about all this many years ago, and then we would not be in the next and new crisis.
Madam President, it would be kind of you to grant me the extra half a minute that my Green colleague, Mrs Breyer, has just received.
The Commission had put forward a good proposal to update the regulation on novel foods.

Unfortunately, some proposed amendments attempt to supplement this proposal with provisions that are not compatible with the objectives of the regulation or even seek to interfere with existing case law.
The obligation of food business operators to monitor novel foods with a view to animal health and welfare would simply overwhelm traders.
And once again, there is an attempt to undermine the existing GMO laws, namely the demand for special labeling of such novel foods derived from animals that were fed genetically modified feed.
We have heard it. I think:
In principle, anything that affects the GMO legislation should not be included in the Noble Food Regulation.
I say this even though I myself, for example, had submitted a proposal to specifically exclude new plant species from the definition of novel foods.
But it cannot be that interested parties in this House misuse the Nobil Food regulation for electioneering purposes.
This appears to be the case with proposed amendments 62 and 90, for which the Greens have requested a recorded vote.
Who, dear colleagues, do you want to expose in this way?
My group has always been in favor of the consumer's right to know what is in their food.
Why, then, should one not indicate a nano origin in the declaration of ingredients?
And although Amendment 62 clumsily attempts to anticipate my report on food labeling, I must tell you that I consider this labeling from Noble Food to be entirely compatible with my report.

I therefore recommend that my group approve the aforementioned motions and will include references to the part of the Noble Food Regulation dealing with labeling in my report on the Food Labeling Regulation.
This is possible because we postponed the first reading on food labeling to the next legislative term, against the wishes of the Greens.
But now it is clear to everyone how advantageous this postponement was.
Briefly, cloning is animal cruelty.
We are against it.
Nevertheless, food products must be included in this regulation, because otherwise they would be in a
Madam President, it is quite simple.
If anyone does not want this man to chair the solemn opening session of the European Parliament, they should support my motion to amend the rules of procedure.

Madam President, Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, one thing is clear from the outset: in my view, the distribution of food to those in need, especially in these economically challenging times, is not up for debate in the upcoming vote on our colleague Tschikersky's report.
That is why I would like to make it clear from the outset that it was not easy to find a common line within our group.
I therefore respect the personal decision of each group colleague to deviate from this and not to agree with the rejection of the report that we have planned.
Why can I not agree with the outcome of the committee vote in this form?
There are a number of reasons for this, which have nothing, absolutely nothing, to do with helping those in need in the European Union during these economically difficult times.

On the contrary, the amendments submitted by my colleague Nils Busk on behalf of the ALDE group, but unfortunately found not to be admissible, were intended to place the existing system on a sustainable footing.
Because the current system is an anachronism from the days of agricultural overproduction, which fortunately belong to the past.
Thanks to the successful decoupling of direct payments, intervention stocks have steadily declined in recent years, so that today up to 85% of food products must be purchased on the open market.
However, this has fundamentally changed the nature of the program and led to the loss of its agricultural policy dimension.
However, since we are now dealing with a social program, we need to establish an appropriate legal basis for it.
Herewith, we share the assessment of the Council's Legal Service, which, instead of Article 37 of the EC Treaty on the common agricultural policy, merely states
considers Article 308 as a legal basis to be possible, because otherwise it would clearly be an infringement on the national competences of the Member States.
Given the inadmissibility of our amendments, the only solution can be a new draft from the European Commission.
This should continue to adhere to the principle of co-financing, because only on-site can the sense and nonsense of such programs be evaluated in the interests of all as peace sites.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, we too welcome the European Commission's proposal and this Green Paper in principle.

There is, and this is not a topic of debate, a mass phenomenon, which has been described by the various previous speakers, where relatively small damages occur among a large number of affected individuals.
The damage to the individual affected is small, but when added up overall, it is significant.
An instrument is needed to tackle this problem.
In my opinion, it is right that people think about something like that.

I also very much welcome the fact, to keep things positive, that the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has placed a crucial emphasis in its Green Paper on the question of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

This is a major difference compared to the White Paper of the Directorate-General for Competition, which was also discussed here in the House yesterday and which has so far completely ignored this possibility of out-of-court dispute resolution mechanisms.
I think the Directorate-General for Consumer Protection has gone further in its Green Paper than its competition colleagues.
However, I also want to make two things very clear, which in my opinion should be understood as critical remarks.
In a few minutes, at twelve o'clock, this Parliament will vote on my report on the White Paper from the Directorate-General for Competition.
We will demand from the European Commission, with an overwhelming majority in this House, that a horizontal approach be adopted in dealing with this issue.
It cannot be that we end up with sectoral instruments, one for consumer protection, one for antitrust law, one for the capital market, and perhaps another one for the environment.

Perhaps one more for social affairs, and they all contradict each other, they all interfere with the legal systems of the member states and ultimately lead to a legal and political mess that no practitioner can handle anymore.
We have had such examples many times in the past.
I am only thinking of the debate on the Professional Qualifications Directive, which we later also summarized in one instrument because this fragmentation was no longer tenable.
The Commission should not make the same mistake here.
It should promote the horizontal approach from the outset.
This is the clear stance of the Parliament, and it will become evident in a few months, in a few minutes, right here.

And one last point: I am also very pleased that we have reached a consensus that we do not want an American-style litigation industry with a turnover of 240 billion US dollars per year, where ultimately only lawyers profit and consumers gain nothing from it.
We want genuine rule of law in Europe and to remain true to our traditional systems and our understanding of law.
Dear colleagues, there are many ways to cope with the lasting consequences of the unexpected financial and economic crisis.

This revision package, this legislative measure as part of the European Economic Recovery Program, is designed as a good response, albeit not entirely sufficient, but it is, first and foremost, a good response to this temporary, albeit exceptionally critical situation.
It also involves, among other things, promoting greater simplification of procedures and greater flexibility in the application of existing ones.
We have implemented the provisions under the Structural Funds Regulation in response to a demand, dear colleagues, that the European Parliament has repeatedly put forward in recent years.

It is also to be welcomed, and I would like to particularly emphasize this, that a change in Article 7 on the eligibility of expenditure should enable the Member States and regions of the EU to do so.
to invest structural policy funding in energy efficiency and renewable energy in residential construction, and that these measures should not only be available to low-income households.
The relevant amendment rightly deletes the line on low-income households and instead introduces a ceiling of 4 of the total EAFRD allocation for each Member State for such expenditure.
This is just one of the many proposed improvements.
In short, once this overall package is implemented, it will accelerate spending and thus provide additional liquidity for the implementation of necessary measures.
There are provisions from the Structural Funds of ERDF, ESF and Cohesion Fund and a simplification of the regulations that enable the rapid implementation of the programmes.
A, in my opinion, more effective, a, in my opinion, more effective contribution, although still not sufficient, not sufficient contribution to coping with the current crisis situation.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, I fundamentally welcome the European Ecolabel.
It is right that we are making a new attempt to further disseminate this Community eco-label.
I also think it's right that we continue to rely on volunteerism in the future.
In the future, the mark will only be successful if there are clear criteria and standards that require the acquisition of this mark.
Here I appeal to the EU Commission to develop reasonable, clear, and understandable criteria.
The incentive concept must be at the forefront.
It would be unfortunate if the establishment of the environmental label fails due to bureaucratic obstacles.
Ultimately, it is the consumer who decides on success or failure, because it is with them that acceptance must be achieved.

Although I personally am very fond of the Blue Angel, which we have in Germany, in the end it should not be a matter of taste, but rather it is important that the consumer is immediately informed about the special properties of a product.
Added value for consumers will only be created if the Member States abandon their own symbols and a uniform symbol is introduced at European level.
A jumble of symbols confuses the consumer and does not inform him.
A sign, a statement. That's what we should work on together. Thank you very much.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that during this legislative period, we have made significant progress together in the discharge procedures for the European institutions.
I regret, however, that it has taken so long, because in principle, we have only now addressed everything that was already evident with the resignation of the Commission in 1999, i.e., ten years ago.

This shows that we still need to improve our working methods and procedures, and ensure that the necessary transparency is achieved more quickly, so that citizens can find out how their tax money is being used.
I would particularly like to thank my colleague Mr Casaca, with whom I had the honour of working on the parliamentary discharge for the EPP Group.

I deeply regret this, which is why I quickly took another look to see that a colleague who expresses himself very intensively about various matters of the European Parliament in the press does not participate in the committee discussions, the committee votes, or the plenary debate here.
I want to say this very clearly at this point, so that it is preserved and remains preserved for posterity. We are well aware that there were a number of problems here.

It was and is the Members of Parliament who are here now who have ensured that the necessary reforms have been achieved in the interests of the Members of Parliament in the last five years in a wide range of areas.
And for that, a heartfelt thank you to everyone. We did what was necessary, and we made sure that everything was not only widely reported in the media, but that people also cooperated.
Thank you for the serious cooperation.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the ODI report, for which I would like to thank the rapporteur, is a real step forward because it includes innovative elements, such as naming and shaming, a milestone in budgetary control.
Targeted criticism instead of blanket accusations.
The fact that the Socialist Group in particular is now backing down and prefers to sweep the truth under the carpet is a scandal and a disservice to our oversight duties.
But the credibility of Parliament is at stake, and I appeal to my colleagues not to allow this to happen.
A word about our most troubled children, Romania and Bulgaria.
The Commission's failure in preparing for the accessions is most tangible here.
We have lost a lot of money.
The Commission watched for a long time and only froze funds in 2008: for Bulgaria, more than one billion euros, and for Romania, around 142 million euros.
Freezing money is not a solution to the problems.
The cooperation and verification mechanism, for which the Commission President himself is responsible, is a paper tiger, and the progress reports do not deserve the name.
The Audi report suggests ways in which things could be improved.
The EU Commission has misled Parliament about the readiness of these countries to join, and the Commissioner for Enlargement should actually draw consequences from this.
However, our focus is on managing future contributions, which is why this topic remains on the agenda.
Our group will share the discharges with the Commission, but I personally will deny the discharges to the Commission because of this.
Unfortunately, the Commission's reform zeal, which could be glimpsed again last year, has already faded once more.
Stalemate in the fight against fraud, nothing on prevention, more ethics not wanted, etc.
The Commission, and Commissioner Kallas in particular, should be aware of one thing: anyone who wants to be part of the new Commission will need the support of Parliament.
Mr President, yes, we have a problem with copyright, and we have a problem with the remuneration of artists.
That is correct, and we need to take action and do something about it.
But when we take action, it's about really responding to the challenges of the digital age and not flogging dead horses.
I will explain why I came to this word.
Firstly, the proposal that is before us actually only fulfills one promise, and that is the promise to promote the music industry.
When we get to the point of figuring out what happens to the artists themselves and their income, and we calculate it through, we find that
such low average amounts that it is by no means sufficient for an artist's livelihood, in a way that he can make a living from it.
Moreover, this money does not reach the artists directly.
And the fund is too small to achieve anything.
An artist I discussed this with told me that there is a redistribution here from the living to the dead.
I have to disagree. It's a redistribution from the artists to the producers, to the music industry, but only to the big ones.
All in all, Commissioner, this proposal is not suitable.
We need to find better ones.
We need to create something like a flat rate, for example.
The suggestions you make regarding the "use it or lose it" clause also remain theoretical rights.
Please let us do something sensible and well-founded, as the artists recommended and requested in our hearing in the Committee on Legal Affairs.
Mr President, I share the rapporteur, Gilles Sabary's, regret that the Commission has not pursued its original plan for an integrated action plan.
There are many good reasons why all parties involved, from local communities to the European Union, are striving to improve urban traffic conditions.
We know that most people in Europe live in cities and that the current traffic conditions are far from optimal.
Therefore, in principle, I agree with the plan and the report by my colleague Mr Savary to draw up appropriate integrated proposals from the Parliament's initiative.
I thank him for his commitment and also for the concrete suggestions.
At the same time, however, I would like to make it very clear that what many fear or believe they must fear will not happen.
No one wants to take away the right of municipalities, local and regional authorities, to shape their own traffic conditions.
From the European side, we merely want to contribute to ensuring that reasonable common rules are followed here, if a municipality, if a city, if a regional entity deems it reasonable.
The principle of subsidiarity is not compromised.
What we want to do here is to protect this principle.
It therefore remains that we strive, in the interest of citizens, to ensure that not when a citizen travels 10 km
When he continues his journey through Europe, he encounters a traffic-calmed zone that he thinks he knows from his home town, only to find completely different rules there.

No one wants to impose city tolls or other regulations on any communities, but if they are actually implemented here, then they should also be made available to citizens within a recognizable framework.
For more than a hundred years, we have agreed on the usefulness of common approaches when it comes to traffic signs.
This should also be the case in the future with this topic.
Mr President, we have been dealing with urban transport in the EU for a long time now.
Why, really?

We are not competent for this. The jurisdiction was originally constructed because about 80% of the population lives in urban areas, and because of the climate debate, they now want to address the issue.
Fortunately, we were able to reduce the European Commission's ambitions to an action plan for urban transport through our protest.
I thank Commissioner Tajani for his insight.
After all, subsidizing does indeed mean supporting rather than prescribing, but as an Italian, he knows this better than I do as a German with only a basic knowledge of Latin.
My primary concern is that our report, the report of the Parliament, emphasizes strict adherence to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality.
Legislative measures at the European level are inadmissible for urban traffic.
Supportive measures, that is our task.
A collection of ideas and the promotion of the exchange of best practices makes sense.
Not everyone has to reinvent the wheel.
Our cities need tailor-made solutions, but these can only be developed by the local actors, because they are the ones who know what is necessary.
The municipalities must meet very different situations. They therefore need sufficient room for manoeuvre, also in order to keep inner-city trade vital.
This is important for a city's attractiveness.
It is therefore important not to exclude motorized individual traffic and to focus more on urban logistics.
I would therefore like to see research into urban last-mile delivery promoted.
That relieves a city.
It is also important that demographic change is taken into account.
Our society is becoming older after all.
Mobility needs and housing requirements are changing.
We need a supply of everyday goods close to where people live if we want to reduce traffic, and this is also a challenge for the retail sector.
Anything else would only require a green field.
In conclusion, we do not need an observation point for urban traffic.
Such a post would cost a lot of money and produce a lot of paper that would only be filed away in Brussels.
Madam President, I fully support the Commission's goal of establishing a legal framework for the coordinated introduction and use of intelligent transport systems in road traffic.

My years-long personal struggle for the standard introduction of eCall, the electronic emergency call system, makes the urgency clear to me almost every day. But intelligent traffic systems can do much more.
They serve environmental compatibility, efficiency improvement, increased safety, and non-discriminatory competitiveness in road freight and passenger transport.

In addition, you support the comodality by developing interfaces to other modes of transport such as rail, waterways, and air travel, where the integration of intelligent transport systems has already begun.
All of this cannot be achieved by the Member States alone, but only as a Community task.

Intelligent transport systems, based on EU-wide binding fundamental standards and regulations for minimum quality, improve the environment for innovation and create planning security, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
I particularly welcome the planned open, vehicle-integrated platform for intelligent transport systems services.

The action plan finally includes a timeline for the introduction of individual systems A for road safety, such as ESP and eCall, and B for continuity in traffic management, for example for information.
Tolling or parking management can avoid search traffic C. The use of real-time road, traffic, and travel data will benefit not only professional drivers, but all road users.
The directive sets out detailed requirements for the EU-wide, uniformly binding, coordinated introduction of intelligent transport systems and their application in the Member States.
It also ensures the handling of personal data.
But beware: The introduction of intelligent traffic systems incurs high costs, as infrastructures and vehicles must first be equipped with the necessary information and communication technologies.
We still know too little about the willingness and ability of potential users to pay.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we clearly support aid for people with rare diseases.
But Amendment 15 is completely ethically unacceptable.
There must never again be a debate in Europe about life worth living and life not worth living.
There should be no political or social pressure in Europe on parents to consciously choose against having a disabled child.
The selection of embryos would be a major ethical breach.
Therefore, this amendment must be rejected, and it is not enough to simply eliminate the word that unfortunately corresponds to fascist language use.
but it would still be a matter of fact that there is a selection of embryos.
And it would be intolerable if this amendment, which speaks of a selection of embryos, were to become a springboard for a new ethic in Europe.
We must resolutely oppose genetic discrimination.
Therefore, Amendment A 15 must be rejected in its entirety, otherwise our group would unfortunately also be forced to vote against this report, which is otherwise quite positive.
Mr President, I voted against granting discharge to the Commission in the discharge vote for the first time since I have been a Member of this House, and I would like to
I will outline my reasons. I am primarily concerned with the way the European Commission has handled and managed the accession of the two new countries, Romania and Bulgaria.
We are dealing with a multitude of problems in Romania and Bulgaria, with a high level of corruption, with a lot of money, with a lot of European money that has disappeared.
The European Commission only began to freeze these funds in 2008.
We lost a lot of money in 2007 and are now dealing with barely existing control systems, or with control systems that only function intermittently.
In Romania, we are dealing with a high rate of corruption and problems with the judiciary.
All of this is to be blamed on the pre-accession process.

My goal is to set an example, to also tell the European Commission that it must proceed differently for future accessions, and to also tell it that, if it has already been observed in other countries, it could certainly be more successful if it so desires.
I would like to call on the Commission to help the two countries in building financial control systems that deserve this name and to eliminate the systemic weaknesses in these two countries.
Otherwise, we will have a long-term problem and a perpetual cause for concern for all of Europe.

Madam President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that behind me, in the area of the right-wing radicals, there are people who are not Members of Parliament, and as far as I can see, they are indeed using their voting cards.
Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I expressly welcome Horst Schnellhardt's draft report and thank him for his excellent work.
Following the numerous crises of recent years involving products of animal origin that pose a risk to human and animal health, comprehensive legal regulation is essential.
A revision of the current regulations has become necessary.
We still need to ensure a high level of security.
Although we generally agree with the report, I see some points that make me think.
The regulation has been made less stringent in many respects, thereby slightly relaxing the trade in animal by-products.
There are some examples. There is permission to use certain Category I material in pet food.
Category 2 or 3 materials can be decontaminated more easily under official supervision, regardless of their risk level, with a low volume of waste per week.
However, the risk of animal by-products of any category is only partly determined by the quantity.
The European Commission will still issue the implementing regulation, and the draft, like the previous one, contains many authorisations for the Commission.

This means that the Commission can make comprehensive and fundamental regulations on the handling of animal by-products through the comitology procedure. This means that Parliament is left out, as unfortunately often happens.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Afghanistan has a difficult history behind it.
I believe that the families there are particularly close-knit and that the woman in the family plays an important role.
That is why economic development is also very important, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises in particular should be promoted especially.
And, of course, modern infrastructure is also necessary, which helps the country to develop better quite simply.

And I believe that infrastructure projects in particular could help to create greater understanding among each other, and of course, through the means of information and communication technology, a different worldview could slowly take hold there while fully preserving their identity.
Marine pollution only becomes a focus of interest when a spectacular incident occurs, and then there is intense discussion about the threat to our seas from this ongoing pollution.
Unfortunately, in the meantime, this often recedes into the background.
The constant and repeated violations, which contribute just as much and dramatically to the threat not only to our seas but also to our coasts, were to be taken seriously by us.
I would like to thank my colleagues, with whom we were able to discuss this, for the fact that we all consistently upheld the position that our sea must be protected.
I speak here as a citizen of a landlocked country, yet as a European, I feel a responsibility to protect our seas from ongoing pollution caused by cheap economic interests.
to protect interests and to integrate the principles of the third maritime package, which is urgently necessary, as the Committee on Legal Affairs has also proposed.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Obiol Sigmar, on his excellent report.
Mr President, the situation regarding respect for human rights is very poor in many countries around the world.
But also here in Europe, if we think for example of Belarus.
Therefore, the European Union must significantly intensify its efforts by implementing human rights policy in all areas and setting clear standards.
In our understanding, human rights are indivisible.
This can be achieved, for example, during negotiations for a new agreement with Russia by including a binding human rights clause that influences all areas of negotiation.
Furthermore, I would like to advocate once again for the Subcommittee on Human Rights to become a main committee.
Okay! The EVP EDF Group calls on the government and the Chinese Communist Party to conduct the upcoming human rights dialogue in a constructive manner.
This would significantly ease the relationship between the EU and China.
We have a genuine interest in improving bilateral relations.
But this dialogue must also be conducted honestly.
Therefore, we will have to maintain our legitimate demands on China.
In our view as civil rights activists, he should be released immediately.
Thus, discussions with the Dalai Lama as the religious leader of the Tibetans are to be resumed.
And so the Chinese region of Tibet must be made immediately accessible to journalists and UN human rights experts.
In my opinion, the People's Republic of China has shown before the Olympic Games that it can grant more press freedom, for example, without endangering the stability of the country.
Now she should have the courage to tackle new reforms - reforms on re-education camps, the rights of the accused, the death penalty, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly.
They should address these human rights and engage in dialogue with us.
Madam President! Madam Vice-President! We also welcome with great pleasure and extend our heartfelt congratulations on today's decision by the Czech Senate.
President Klaus responded, among other things, by claiming that the Lisbon Treaty was still dead because it had been rejected by the referendum in Ireland.

In doing so, he rides as a political zombie, attacking majority decisions of his own parliament and the Senate, and confirming his disgraceful and sectarian attitude in other areas of politics as well.
Fortunately, after the positive votes, he only makes a fool of himself.
We Greens are positive and constructive towards the European integration process, of course also with critical remarks where necessary.
Once again, heartfelt thanks to the Czech Senate, Parliament, and Government.
Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, last week we heard from Mr Machmalbach in a Committee on Foreign Affairs which, to my delight as a new Member, was convened.
An Iranian film director told us quite clearly that there were 20% of democracy in Iran before this election, and after this election, which he considered a coup, there is no democracy at all.
I also agree with this description. It was indeed an electoral coup, which, through massive electoral fraud, deprived the majority of the Iranian population, who had voted for change, of their right.
Mr President of the Council, I am particularly interested in one thing: there will be an inauguration for the re-elected Mr Ahmadinejad in mid-August.
What is currently being discussed in the Council and with the Member States?
Will there be an official formal representation of the European Union and also of the member states here?
I hope there won't be any, because I think that after this coup d'tat, there should be no official representation of the European Union or
There are no member states, as much as I advocate for further dialogue, but at this inauguration, I think no one is officially represented by the European Union.
What is your position on this?
How is that currently being handled?
Mr President! Mr President! Mr President! Mr President! Mr President!
There is the growing social inequality, there are the dangerous and non-solidaristic macroeconomic imbalances between the member states, and there is Europe's dependence on rising resource prices.

The citizens of Europe deserve a Commission that repeatedly puts these deeper causes on the agenda, instead of taboos, instead of doing the opposite, instead of shifting the responsibility onto the member states.
We need genuine European coordination of economic and fiscal policy.
We need fiscal cooperation in Europe that puts an end to tax dumping.
Only then will it be possible to halt social division and finance the necessary ecological investments.
We need a policy that consistently promotes green technologies and lifestyles so that the EU's dependence on finite resources decreases sharply.
This is an ecological green revolution. I don't find any of this in your program, Mr. Barroso.
That is the reason why I cannot vote for her.
Mr Barroso, imagine you are a
You would stand for election in Europe, but you alone, no other candidate. What percentage of the votes would you get?
What would the citizens do?
They would have been listening to you today and would have seen that you promised everyone everything.
Hopefully, you would also get the information about what you did five years ago.
You have promised most of them a great deal.
You have to compare what you have promised before, what you are promising now, and what is to be expected.
I think that is very, very little.
They stand for the old, failed Europe, for their contribution to the financial crisis, because the Commission has failed, for their lack of commitment to climate issues, and so on.
I would side with the majority of European citizens because I believe they would not get more than 10 or 12 or 15 of the votes.
Mr President, I would like to speak in favour of maintaining the new proposal, because after all, it is clear that the negotiations in Honduras have failed.
There is no joint proposal for this election.
This election is illegitimate because the current president came to power through a coup.
That is to say, I ask the plenary to give its approval to the Presidium's proposal for this change, that the elections be removed.
Mr President, democracy needs a revolution, and it is never wrong, Mr Dartmouth, to speak out for transparency, Mr Verhofstadt.
And you, in the Swedish Presidency, could be a shining example and really tell us how it will have gone.
It is about the very undignified horse-trading for top positions in the European project, and here too Mr Barroso could take the lead in appointing the Commissioner.
Germany and Austria provide a negative example in this regard, but unfortunately others do too.
Qualified people are sitting here in the hall, but they have no chance of gaining access.

Could you please be brave now that the Lisbon Treaty has been adopted, and be honest and say that we need much clearer decision-making structures, transparent decision-making structures for the Commission and the opposition parties?
It should be possible to find the right people here from the European Parliament with so much expertise and not to find them in any of the federal states.
Mr President, the topic we are discussing here this evening has already been on the agenda of the European Parliament several times.
As is well known, the Commission bases the granting of the aid on the conditions set by the International Monetary Fund.
That has already been mentioned a few times.
Against this background, there have been repeated requests from the EP to the Commission.

In November 2008, the EP called on the Commission to present an analysis of the effects of the behavior of banks that had transferred their assets from the Member States that had recently joined at that time.
On 24 April this year, the EP reiterated this demand.

Furthermore, the EP has demanded to be informed about the letters of intent concluded in detail between the Commission and the Member States receiving aid, which outline the conditions for the aid in detail.
To the best of my knowledge, these requests have not been answered to this day.
My first question, therefore, is: Is it true that these requests have not been answered so far?
If that is true, then my second question is: Why have these requests not been answered so far?
My third question is then: When can we expect a response to these requests?
Ladies and gentlemen, the GUE/NGL will not be supporting this resolution.
The Stockholm Programme completely misses the mark on the real challenges of the present.
The core error is that a Europe of rights is being established, which is supposed to be granted to EU citizens, but not to other people living in Europe.
The same citizens and human rights are not to be granted to them.
On the one hand, the EU wants to join the Charter of Human Rights, which we welcome, but on the other hand, migrants are sorted out according to the principle of legal or illegal.
Frontex is being massively upgraded to combat so-called illegal migration, and I tell you, this completely distorts the view of an unbiased immigration policy.
This is where Stockholm fails.
Another problem is the completely unbalanced relationship between security and freedom.
Yes, there is no freedom without security, but there is also no security without freedom. Freedom is not a bargaining chip, but a universal legal right of every human being.

Stockholm, on the other hand, symbolizes the EU's security obsession, in which huge supranational databases are created without adequate control mechanisms, merging intelligence and police data across Europe.
This makes the right to informational self-determination of people, waste paper, and the vision of a transparent person a reality.
Allow me, finally, as an East German representative, to state that 20 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, it is unbearable for me to witness Europe increasingly becoming a fortress.
Mr President, Commissioner, you are right. The railway system is a very safe system compared to other modes of transport.

While there are many positive aspects, liberalization in the form of fragmentation of individual companies, separation of infrastructure and operations, outsourcing of maintenance work, and leasing of equipment and personnel has indeed brought about a great deal of uncertainty.
In my opinion, it must be ensured that the national safety authorities issue safety certificates and authorisations in accordance with ERA regulations, following the procedure of the Railway Agency.
Are there enough controls?
For example, it is ensured that the staff training, certifications, and working conditions are properly monitored.
In this context, what is the position on the introduction of a uniform Community certificate?
What about the European train driver's licence?
Efforts regarding ERTS must be further increased.
The recently created implementation plan you outlined must be binding and must not be delayed due to financial or nationalistic considerations.
Efforts to implement the TSI technical specifications must be continued and expanded.
This would be a significant advancement in the homologation of the material and would provide a higher level of safety in the maintenance of the material.
Many of the recent train accidents and near misses have been attributed to poor maintenance.
For cost reasons, the intensity is particularly neglected and the intervals of maintenance work are extended.
What about a Europe-wide certification system for maintenance workshops?
In my opinion, everything must be done to prevent each individual Member State from reverting to their old rules and acting differently and arbitrarily once again.
Border crossings between individual member states are particularly a security risk.
How does the Commission intend to deal with this problem in the short term?
And when you draw up your balance sheet, I want you to take the social aspects into account.
We need a revolution of democracy. Mr President, Commissioner, good morning in this new world of the Lisbon Treaty. This is an opportunity for you.
I have been following your reports here in this house for eleven years, first as a journalist, and ultimately they are very similar.
Now, however, you have the opportunity to look forward.

Make use of the expertise of this House, it is not entirely coincidental that it is gathered here in the hall right now. I see colleague Sndergaard, I see colleague Tchachimakachis, there is Mr Staes, there is my colleague from our list, Mr Ehrenhauser, and let us relaunch the work of the Court of Auditors.
Look at what works elsewhere, in Germany, where the cost-effectiveness and relevance of expenditures can be assessed, or in Austria.

I would like you to present a concept, perhaps as part of an own-initiative report that is now coming before Parliament, on how to significantly improve what you are doing so that you can actually fulfill your responsibilities.
We need a revolution of democracy that brings people into the world.
I remember very well that the debates we hear today had already begun in this House ten years ago.
Commissioner, I would strongly urge you to really take to heart what comes from ALDEZIR, as well as from the Greens and some left-wing Members of Parliament.

Don't you see that with the approach the European Union has taken to the negotiations, and is still taking, we cannot rectify the imbalance as a fair broker? I think that, in connection with what we are currently experiencing in Copenhagen in these hours and days, we actually need a new approach.
In many ways, the developing countries are no longer developing countries in what they are doing today.
Emerging countries, developed countries, and very self-assured.

If Europe fails to manage to make a fresh start with fair conditions, then we will end up where we do not want to be, namely with protectionism and the consequences that followed in 1933, including in Europe.
I would just like to use the blue card for a clarification.
Support in Austria is not only granted to one person.

Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a microfinance instrument for the unemployed, those at risk of unemployment, and above all for people who do not have access to normal credit markets, is a good intention and is supported in principle by our group.
However, what the Commission and the Council have achieved so far in this process in terms of performance is simply insufficient, partly incorrect, and cannot be supported by our group.
The first point of criticism is the issue of financial resources.
What is on the table in terms of financial resources is not financial resources for a program to combat unemployment. This cannot be called a microfinance program; at best, it is nano-finance.
Secondly, we are fundamentally opposed to such sleight of hand, which has no effect, comes at the expense of other programs, and thus fizzles out without end.
Thirdly, we also believe that the sustainability and success of such a program must organically include mentoring and coaching.
Many new start-ups, especially in the microfinance sector, fail, so the programme must also ensure this is addressed.
Fourthly, it must be ensured that social security benefits in the Member States are not withdrawn for the use of this program, otherwise it will be ineffective.
This means that unemployment cannot be combated sustainably.
We will reject it in this form.
Mr. President! Today, after eight years, we basically all know that the military-focused Afghanistan strategy to date has failed.
The imbalance between military operations on the one hand and insufficient resources for civilian purposes effectively prevents an improvement in the living conditions in Afghanistan.
And that is why our most important message as UNGL is that a radical change in strategy is needed.
We need a radical change of strategy away from the military and above all towards the people.
This means that 40% of Afghans are unemployed. More than half of them live in extreme poverty, without access to healthcare or adequate education.
The social question must be brought to the forefront, and that is what we expect from the Council, the Commission, and all those involved.
This naturally includes strengthening responsible government action, strengthening agriculture, and integrating former Taliban fighters.
But I tell you quite honestly: anyone who only goes half way down this path and reverts to military adventures is squandering every opportunity.
It is five minutes before 12 o'clock.
Madam President! My question is along the lines of: Is it not sensible to prevent unemployment altogether?
