Can you see public tasks that could be assigned to the unemployed?
And above all, how could we strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises, and encourage the founding of new ones?
are there opportunities to apply methods and best practices across countries to create more and new businesses?
We need a revolution of democracy.
As an admirer of so many Swedish traditions, I was all the more disappointed in the balance sheet of their activities.
Unfortunately, it was not a presidency of the people, but a presidency of council princes and also a presidency of big investors; all of Wallstrm, it was not Malstrm.
I remember you well, Madam Member of the European Parliament, from that time, when you were still a Member.
Now they were something else.
I very much hope that when you return, you will pick up where you left off, inspired by parliamentary democracy.
Why didn't you say goodbye too late?
Why are we now dealing with a quasi-directorship at the EU level, and under the objectives of the Swedes with their transparency?
Please use your future to return to where you have already been.
Mr President, this debate is a crucial debate about the character of the European Union.
Is it the market or social policy?
The Commission's current considerations regarding the future of cohesion policy are unacceptable.
The Structural Funds must be strengthened, not reduced.
Europe must do more, not less, to overcome economic and social development disparities.

I'll say it quite openly: The renationalization, even just of parts of the current cohesion policy, would also have serious consequences for disadvantaged regions in Germany, for example in Eastern Germany.
After the last round of enlargement of the European Union, the differences between the regions within the Union have indeed grown.
It is also important to me that socioeconomic conditions in regions that are just above the 75 threshold of GDP per capita are also recognized.
An abrupt cessation of funding after 2013 would be disastrous for these regions.
Ladies and gentlemen, of course, strengthening specific urban funding and city-related funding by the European Union is also extremely important.
This is important because there are significant economic and financial potentials there, and the crisis has hit particularly hard in this region.
A final word on the border regions.
As an East German representative, I tell you, we need to invest a lot, a lot there, and do a lot.
And I have great concerns that the Commission will fail.

Mr President, regional structural support is an essential instrument in European integration, and Objective 2 funding in particular has been perceived by people in the past as a driving force for local structural and economic development in many regions.
It is an important element for coping with structural change in the regions and also in the municipalities.
Here, Europe is truly tangible for the citizens, because it has a real impact on their daily lives.
However, we need simpler, clearer, and more transparent structures for the cohesion funds and better controls to ensure that the funds are used sustainably and efficiently.
Cohesion, the convergence in social and economic development, is a key objective in the EU, and therefore we must not weaken this instrument in the future, but rather we must strengthen it.
Cohesion policy in Europe needs more clarity, more transparency, efficiency, and also the self-responsibility of the individual member states.
And that is why it is important to stick to the system of additive support.
However, we do not want a renationalisation of structural funding.
Therefore, I would like to ask the Commission to ensure that the funding criteria from 2013 meet these requirements.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have two points of order to raise. Mr President, I would ask you to arrange things in the order that I believe will make for a good debate.
First of all, I have a request for the entire house.
This refers to an urgency that we will discuss this afternoon.
This is the case of Ms. Amitu Haidar.
We have an emergency on the agenda.
I ask my colleagues to trust me in the following approach. Some colleagues who have been intensively involved in this case know
I don't have more details to share right now, but I'm among those who know that it's imminent, and we will have a solution to this case later today.
Prominent EU government representatives are working on a positive solution.
It would therefore be sensible for us to remove this urgency from the agenda this afternoon, because any further debate would only hinder the work being done by some diplomatic channels there.
Therefore, my request is that the House agrees to exceptionally remove this urgency from the agenda, because we will be more helpful in resolving the case than if we were to discuss it.
That would be my first request.
I will present the second request immediately afterwards.

Madam President, it seems to me that it is somewhat symptomatic for us, for the EU in general, but also for Parliament in particular, that we reflexively engage in discussions about situations in countries whose circumstances are not new.
Unfortunately, it is often the case that events occur overnight, leading to a sudden outpouring of political demands here, which I sometimes find somewhat questionable.
I believe it does not behoove us to use a failed airplane attack alone to initiate a general debate about Yemen.
I believe we should be aware that it suits us well to consider a strategy for dealing with this situation.

I also believe that the situation in Yemen requires a thorough analysis, namely that it is a failed state in which a government no longer has control over large parts of the country, and we should analyze for ourselves what risks this poses for Europe.
The risks seem to be that terrorists are being trained there, and the risks also seem to be emerging on the coast of Yemen, where piracy is obviously taking place.
That is why it is up to us, and perhaps also to Mrs Ashton, to consider what we can do to counteract these risks.
In my view, the answer is primarily: How can we support the government in Yemen in regaining control over the country and mitigating these risks?

All other discussions about the long-term development of the country must of course also be held, but I do not believe it is truly sensible, and that we will be taken seriously, if we now propose a list of demands across all political issues, from freedom of the media to women's rights here in Parliament.
I believe that this will not achieve its goal in Yemen, but rather we should focus on what kind of concrete help we can provide in the current situation to solve an acute problem.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the massacre on 23 November last year in the province of Maguindanao in the Philippines was a black day for human rights and a barbaric act of terror.
57 dead, raped women, injured, they speak a bloody language.
As a journalist, I am particularly struck by the fact that 30 journalists were among the dead.
According to the renowned International Crisis Group, no other documented case has ever seen more journalists murdered in a single instance.
For this reason, it is appropriate for the European Parliament to find clear words, as we do today in the draft resolution.

However, as the EPP, we demand that the present text be mitigated in three places through separate voting, because we should support the Philippine government in its fight against terror and violence and therefore refrain from making accusatory remarks towards the government.
Therefore, on behalf of the EPP, I request a separate vote on recital F, which accuses the Philippines of displaying all the signs of a non-functioning legal system.
Secondly, quote: In point two, we would like to remove the assumption of so-called initial delays in the investigation.
Finally, point 6 claims that there are missing persons who are being held in Philippine prisons.
This, too, is currently an unsubstantiated allegation and should, in our opinion, be deleted.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think it is good that the Social Democratic Group has thoroughly examined this report.

However, I would like to point out that in December 2008, we, as a Parliament, adopted a resolution with almost unanimous support, in which we called on the European Commission to submit exactly the kind of proposal that we are now discussing here.
And the Parliament must also be held to what it has decided on, and what has been the declared will of this House for years.
We have resolved the open questions through a compromise in the Legal Affairs Committee, because there are naturally always concerns with every legislative proposal here or there.
This compromise is, I may say quite clearly, ready for a decision.
I still understand that it can, of course, make sense to further expand the circle of those who support this report.
And if colleague Schulz's efforts are aimed at expanding the circle of supporters, I have no objection to postponing the decision until the next plenary session in March.
That is my personal position.
This is not the position of the group, which explicitly decided otherwise this morning.
But I think we should give the socialists a chance to come to their senses here, so that they too can do something to relieve the burden on small businesses and reduce bureaucracy.
I understand that.
Mr. Almunia was in charge.
I had asked about your interventions, but you can repeat what you yourself did right now.
Did I understand correctly, Mr. Barroso, that the member states are to blame for the Greek crisis because they refused to follow your proposals?
Could you please tell us which governments, leaders, and which member states were involved?
Welcome here in this house!
In my opinion, the loss of trust in Copenhagen was one of the major problems.
This could theoretically continue worldwide, but also within the European Union.
My question is for you: How are we moving forward with the instruments we decided on last year?
I have a knot in my stomach about the ETS because I'm not entirely sure how the Commission will now handle benchmarks, for example, or carbon leakage, following the decision in Copenhagen.
And the second question is: There is a proposal by the French government to impose taxes on importers from the
from the third world, where we also need to integrate them into the ITS system in order to expand the market and allow these countries to participate in this system.
Do you have an opinion on this?
Madam President! The issue here is that we, as the European Union, must pursue a clear strategy and prevent a gold or oil rush.
Europe must actively get involved here.
Europe can demonstrate its strength as a partner by speaking with one voice.
It is about shipping above and below water, it is about fishing, it is about resources in the form of primary energy sources and raw materials.
Here, together with the other partners in the Arctic, we need solid and reliable agreements.
We need cooperation instead of confrontation.
We need dialogue in the field of environmental protection to preserve natural resources and nature.
We need dialogue in the field of animal welfare to preserve biodiversity. We need protection and respect for the inhabitants and their human rights.
If we implement positive resource management together with our partners in the Arctic, we will have the opportunity to forge new political paths in this region.
This will also be a first acid test for our common foreign policy, where we can prove that we Europeans are pursuing common goals.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the G20 summit in Pittsburgh has provided a good basis.
He has called for economic recovery plans to promote decent work that contributes to securing and creating jobs, and has given priority to employment growth.

The European Ministers of Labour are therefore called upon to urge the G20 members, firstly, not to scale back their economic stimulus packages, but to use them to a greater extent and more strongly to create jobs, and secondly, to implement financially secured short-time work schemes.
to combat job losses, thirdly, to use public investment to create jobs and promote sustainable ecological growth, and fourthly, to strengthen and expand social security systems to ensure access.
This also secures purchasing power in the domestic market and employment, and combats poverty.

The collaboration with the social partners is particularly recommended to the European labor ministers in order to strengthen the social dialogue even more, as the Commissioner would like to see it strengthened.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking Mr Leichtfried for an excellent report that conveys sound and valuable content.
What is it ultimately about?
The aim is to strengthen transparency, consumer protection, safety and coordination, as well as quality management.
However, I would caution against setting up a new authority to deal with these issues.
I see subsidiarity in the report as a positive element, and it should definitely be retained.
For me, it is also very important to clearly distinguish between taxes and fees, and all tasks that are official should be identifiable as such.
Not by the police, whether it's counter-terrorism or similar, all these measures are clearly to be financed from tax money and not from user fees.
If individual nation states then have a vital interest in taking additional security measures, then I also see them as being chargeable in this area.
Those who commission security in the public sector have to pay for it.
I see it differently, however, in the technical or personal sphere, which can certainly be at the expense of the passenger, provided it is clearly declared what it is about.
It is also noteworthy, however, that in the impact assessment presented to us by the Commission, an amount of approximately 0.1% of the total transport fee is calculated for these measures.
We should not start too high, then.
I believe that we can also reach a viable compromise with the Federal Republic of Germany, which has extraordinary concerns in the area of subsidiarity.
I hope the final result will be very close to our proposal.
Mr President, Madam Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council! The evaluation of passenger data is an attempt to prevent the fight against global terrorism, similar to the SWIFT case.
to reconcile serious crime with the fundamental rights of every individual to protect privacy and also informational self-determination.
However, we must also be aware that in the age of mobility, there will be no adequate security in Europe and worldwide without effective and rapid data exchange.
In the digital age, we must also ensure special protection with regard to informational self-determination and privacy.
That is why I also believe it is necessary to make a more precise distinction between the data needed to combat crime and the data that is sensitive to privacy.
And for me, it is actually beyond question that we must firmly integrate controls, legal remedies, rights to information, claims for damages, and the length of data storage into the agreement.
In the push method, it must be determined whether exceptions can or must be made in urgent cases.
And when it comes to the use of passenger data, we should also include serious crime.
And for me, this includes crimes such as child pornography, human trafficking, murder, rape, and drug trafficking.
And in my opinion, that would also be a contribution to protecting the personal rights of those affected.
I think it's good that we postponed the decision on the passenger data agreements in question in order to create a basic model for all future agreements of this kind.
We must also develop and present to the Commission a negotiating framework that takes our own ideas on data protection into account.
Perhaps there might also be room in the future to consider conducting the fight against terrorism and crime together with our transatlantic partners in a joint institution.
And that would certainly also be a step towards countering globalized crime on a global scale.
Mr President, we have rightly pointed out in our opening remarks the importance of the EIB.
For example, colleague Kadenbach spoke of the much-needed contribution to social convergence.
I would like to put that into a political context.
We are witnessing with great concern that in an increasing number of countries, far-right parties are gaining support.
They do this because social convergence in the European Union is not working out the way we all hoped.
In this context, these extreme right-wingers very, very often appear as wolves in sheep's clothing, thereby masking a massive, cynical contempt for humanity that lies behind their actions.
Last example, Mr. President, I too know your political stance. What Mr. Mlzer just did: he gave a very nice speech, but in the middle of it, he called a political opponent, me, a psychopath.
That is the language of Hitler fascism, that is the way they work. Political opponents have already been dehumanized in this way.

I ask you to take appropriate action against this, and I ask the colleagues from the EIB to continue their work, to become even more transparent in the area of transparency, because their approach is also an aid to the emerging new fascism.
Policy coherence for development means that we do not take away with one hand what we give with the other.

For example, it makes little sense to invest development aid in building up agriculture in developing countries if we are simultaneously destroying local markets through direct or indirect export subsidies.
We can also advocate for better healthcare as much as we want, if we hinder the trade of generics or drive up the prices of medications to unaffordable levels through patent extensions.

And while agrofuels may reduce CO2 emissions in the EU to some extent, they lead to deforestation and land use changes in developing countries, resulting in more climate change, which we were trying to avoid, not to mention the displacement of indigenous populations, loss of biodiversity, and reduced arable land for food production.
At the moment, that is, the EU as such, is not particularly coherent.
The EU has long recognized in theory that policy measures should not contradict each other.
The Lisbon Treaty enshrines policy coherence in the interest of development.
Article 208 states: When implementing policies that may affect developing countries, the Union shall take into account the objectives of development cooperation.
We must measure ourselves against this demand.
This year we are reviewing the progress made towards achieving the Millennium Goals.
It is clear: without policy coherence, we will not succeed in fulfilling our promises.

We must be aware of this responsibility, all of us who make and implement laws. Before we decide on a measure, there must be an impact assessment so that we can even recognize what negative effects European legislation may have on developing countries.
We need expertise in the Council, Commission and Parliament that can identify inconsistencies.
The Commission's work programme on policy coherence is a good step in this direction.
And now it depends on how this plan is implemented.

Policy coherence for development means that we must take greater account of the interests of local people in fisheries reform and not subordinate them to the interests of European fishing conglomerates.
It means that we need to dry up tax havens into which funds from developing countries flow.
This means that we cannot agree to ACTA if there remains a suspicion that this agreement could hinder access to medicines or technologies in developing countries.
So far, the Commission has not been able to dispel this suspicion.

Policy coherence also means that, in the creation of the diplomatic service, development policy must remain a strong, independent policy area, and the powers of the development commissioner must be expanded, not restricted.
And it also means that we enable fair trade in the allocation of contracts in the municipalities, as my colleague Heide Rhle has proposed.
In many cases, we need to keep a close eye on the Commissioners and the Council to ensure they develop coherent policies.
In many cases, however, it is also up to us Members of Parliament to be coherent in the interest of development.
We need to network better between committees, and we need a permanent rapporteur.
The report, which the Development Committee has unanimously adopted, makes many good suggestions and takes us a big step forward.
I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, the Ombudsman and all the NGOs for their assistance and cooperation, and I hope that our joint report can also be adopted by the plenary tomorrow.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have noted from the voting list that you, Mr President, intend to declare motion 2 inadmissible.
I ask you to reconsider this.
It is indeed true that Article 229 of the Treaty stipulates that a session of the European Parliament takes place on the second Tuesday of March.
However, this is not in contradiction to the motion that has been tabled here by my group.
My group's motion aims to move the Strasbourg week from the tenth week to the eleventh week.
This does not prevent you from holding a plenary session on the second Tuesday in March.
However, we want Strasbourg week to be in the eleventh week, so I say there is no illegitimacy here.
I would ask you to reconsider this. Thank you.

Mr President of the Commission, following the questions from my colleague Manfred Weber, Commissioner Malmstrm informed the college that there are major concerns in this House about the current state of negotiations.
That is why the Commission is aware that what it has decided today is certainly not what Parliament considers to be sufficient progress.

Are you aware, Mr President, that you have today adopted something that, if implemented as such, would mean that employees of a private company, SWIFT for example, have more control rights than officials of the European Union?
Has Mrs. Maimstrm informed herself about these matters?
If so, how were you able to decide?
If not, why didn't Mrs Malmstrm inform you about it?
For the kind descriptions of your debate about the EU members
That was not the answer.
That's why I'll try again to be more precise, and I ask you to answer very precisely.

Did Mrs Malmstrm tell you during the debate in the Commission before the College's decision-making that there was a risk that Parliament would vote against the text that you are now presenting as an agreement?
Or did Mrs Malmstrm tell you: With this text, we will get a parliamentary majority.
I repeat very precisely: Did Mrs. Malmstrm say that we will get a parliamentary majority with this text, or did she say that the parliamentary majority is not certain with this text?
I would be grateful if you could be precise.
Madam President, dear colleagues, we have been discussing the issue of driving times and working hours in road transport for months.
And I wonder what arguments will now be put forward to prove that everything we have been discussing for months is nonsense.
The latest argument is: We urgently need to change something here so that nothing changes.
Don't you see, dear Mrs. Bauer, how absurd this argumentation has become, how riddled it is with lies and half-truths?
This debate is about nothing other than an extension of working hours for self-employed individuals.
For the past 150 years, labor law has essentially been about protecting people from excessively long working hours.
This applies to both self-employed individuals and employed workers.
It doesn't matter whether it's a self-employed person who is overworked, or whether an employer is overloading an employed driver.
It is about protecting people from themselves and from excessively long working hours, partly also from employers and clients.
Secondly, in terms of road safety, it is claimed here that nothing can happen.
Ladies and gentlemen, we are not at a DIY store and we are not amateur craftsmen. We cannot make laws based on the principle of "let's see what comes out of it."
Everyone knows that excessively long working hours are designed to be accident-prone, especially in road traffic with major consequences.
Third point: Who is going to enforce such a differentiated system, as you envision, on our roads in the future?
Today, a state labor judge cannot verify whether someone is apparently self-employed or truly self-employed without extensive review of the case files.
Let's put an end to this nonsense, it's about fair competition.
It is not about setting a precedent today or tomorrow for the future debate on extending working hours.
Don't play games like that with this house. Thank you.

Madam President! Today, as I have done for many years, I am advocating for road safety, an improvement in the working conditions of our professional drivers, and the enhancement of their professional image.

And quite clearly: today it is not about the traffic safety regulations for driving and rest periods that all self-employed and employed professional drivers must adhere to, today it is about the regulation of working hours.
It is primarily an employee protection regulation, thus serving only the social protection of drivers and not at all road safety.
We don't need to protect the self-employed from themselves.

It is neither possible to monitor the working hours of self-employed truck and bus drivers without significant bureaucratic effort, nor is there a justifiable reason for such monitoring to take place.
Limiting self-employed professional firefighters, and perhaps in the future also self-employed craftsmen, architects, or members of parliament, in their permissible working hours is the wrong signal.
Rather, the Member States should ensure that bogus self-employment is combated under the
fought against the female and male drivers.
Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur, but also to our shadow rapporteur. I believe that a good report has been produced here.
The essential message for me is that both sides, who are currently making life difficult in Bosnia and Herzegovina, finally have insight and are retreating from their extreme positions.

One extreme position is to repeatedly question Bosnia and the integrity of the country, and to threaten referendums that will achieve nothing but can create a mood and hatred, and the other extreme position is to question the basic structure of DETEN.
Does the food need to be adapted?
Yes, that's right.
It has already been adopted and still needs to happen.
And if it is repeatedly said from one side that the office of the High Commissioner should be dissolved, then I agree with that.
But the party that demands this must create the conditions for it to come to pass, so that the politicians in the country itself take responsibility.
That must be our goal, but politicians must also take responsibility.
And hopefully, in the next elections, voters will also choose those politicians who are willing to take responsibility for their own country.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, just a few days ago, we were horrified to see on television images of vast areas of Poland and other Central European countries being flooded by water.
People have perished in the floods, and our deepest sympathy goes out to their families. Villages, towns, agricultural land, and infrastructure have been destroyed.
The images on television have already been replaced by other images, but the massive damage still needs to be laboriously cleared up.
In dealing with damage of this scale, these countries should also experience the solidarity of the countries of the European Union.
After the 1997 flood disaster, Poland and this time also other Central European countries have once again been affected by a flood disaster.
We cannot yet regulate the weather, and flooding is a characteristic feature of rivers at certain times.
But the questions we need to ask are whether, in the awareness that these natural events can always occur, the right preventive measures are in place against them.
whether damage was caused by such natural events and whether, for example, landscape planning adequately addressed issues of sustainable disaster protection.
When aid is provided, it should first and foremost benefit those directly affected by the natural disaster in order to secure their livelihood.

And then, in the context of international cooperation, because natural disasters do not stop at national borders, more should be done at the European level, coordinated by the member states, to prevent damage caused by natural disasters.
The flood protection along the Oder River, which has so far been jointly developed by Polish and German authorities, demonstrates that joint preventive measures can provide protection.
But we are far from finished yet.
We don't need a European disaster protection agency.
The protection of a country against disasters should primarily be the responsibility of its government, which should include the development of disaster plans.

But the coordination of aid in the event of damage or incidents should also be efficiently coordinated at the European level, and those organizations that provide quick and unbureaucratic aid on a voluntary basis should not be left to bear the costs.
Therefore, I support Commissioner Georgieva's plans to implement these quickly as well.
Mr President, unfortunately my debilitating illness has so far prevented me from speaking out in the international arena with the clarity I have done on other European issues.
But in a minute, Mr President of the Commission!
You are here in a historic time.
They will be measured in the financial markets, the most pressing concern, by whether they succeed in implementing regulations that actually close loopholes.
At present, everything that comes from the Commission and what we have in Parliament so far does not rule that out.

There are no necessary improvements there; they will then be remembered in history as someone who, when the house was already burning fiercely, did not provide the necessary extinguishing materials, and certainly not new construction materials.
Point two: Equity capital. If it is not possible to stop this disastrous, devastating shadow banking system, and not just to contain it, you will be depriving...
the real economy and also billions of citizens around the world not only their own basis for action in the economic sphere, but also their trust in everything that is called democracy.
Because then, suddenly, China and the totalitarian regimes, which already ensure that their banks are controlled, are in a better position than the European Union.
Point Three: Of course, we need a system that minimizes systemic risks, which means implementing burdensome, progressive tax regulations so that if a bank becomes too big, it must be shut down.

In 2007 and 2008, Libya voted against the United Nations General Assembly resolutions calling for a moratorium on executions, and repeated requests from human rights organizations yielded no official response.
For this reason, it is very important to us that the individuals who were executed are finally officially identified.
Every execution is one too many.
We reject executions and the death penalty.
It is inhumane, unhuman, and every one is one too many.
Therefore, in our resolution, we make a very clear request that we change this, that we disclose it, and that we now work together to ensure that a change takes place here.

No more hidden figures, but open information about what is happening here, and a humane punishment for real offenders, but not an exaggerated punishment for those who deal critically with the regime in Tripoli.
Mr President, I wanted to support the motion of my colleague Cohn Bendit on behalf of our group.
Now it is exactly like that.
This is a highly sensitive, very delicate issue, where it is certainly sensible to find a broad parliamentary majority.
Therefore, it would be good if the report could be postponed and an attempt could be made to work out any possible consensus.
That is why we support this
Ladies and gentlemen, due to the limited time available, I would like to confine myself to the Kanchan report.
It is undisputed that passenger rights and, consequently, consumer rights must be implemented in bus transport.
However, I would like to emphasize once again the problems that small and medium-sized enterprises are currently facing, especially from the perspective of the Federal Republic of Germany.
Public transport and regional transport cannot be separated, especially in rural areas, as they often serve a radius of about 50 kilometres together.
Secondly, it is not possible for small and medium-sized enterprises to receive advance payments for services that are not contingent on debt.
Here we have the principle of liability, which has proven itself very well so far and has thus kept the fares stable.

Thirdly, I cannot imagine that delays not caused by the entrepreneur would have to be paid by the entrepreneur, just as liability can only apply to circumstances for which the entrepreneur is responsible.
Mr President, first of all, a heartfelt thank you to Matthieu Grosch for this profound report and the enormous amount of work he has put into it.

A Europe without dividing borders is not conceivable without a functioning transport system, and the European economy would not be successful, indeed not even conceivable, without a powerful transport system, without powerful, future-proof transport systems by land, sea, and air.
In particular, when it comes to environmentally friendly rail transport, we need even more community spirit and less nationalistic egoism.
For a sustainable future of transportation, all modes of transport must address the challenges in society regarding environmental protection and the economy.
The report provides valuable and guiding insights.
However, I cannot agree with the report on one point: creating a transport fund from cohesion policy funds is something I cannot support.
Why?
Certainly, traffic is a special carrier of cohesion in Europe. However, a separate fund from the cohesion policy funds would not meet the expectations it raises.
We must place a one-sided burden on the Cohesion Fund and not relieve the Member States, which are particularly challenged in ensuring a sustainable future for transport, too much.
And we have just set up a special committee in Parliament to debate the future shape of the European Union's cohesion and structural funds, whose work should not be prioritized.
I therefore ask that you also agree to the amendment to the report.
And furthermore, I believe that when we talk about sustainability and the future of transportation systems, magnetic levitation technology should also be given a future and a chance.
Madam President, my esteemed colleagues, ladies and gentlemen, although we have a common internal market, we have fragmented supervision.
It is obvious that this cannot work.
We need strong central European structures that utilize bodies with expertise and detailed knowledge of the member states, but also have the authority to intervene in emergencies.
I believe that, given the enormous tax burden imposed by this crisis, citizens expect swift, quick, and appropriate decisions to be made.
Citizens are not interested in the power games played at the national level, where the only question is.
The most important thing that citizens want is for decisions to be made effectively and for problems to be solved.

And this is objectively the case, so that when it comes to measures in an emergency situation, this must be centrally regulated and decided at the European level, if the coordination between the member states is not sufficient and does not work.
This is in line with the decisions of the G20 and the G8 heads of state and government, unfortunately not at the level of the Council.
The council makes him small, small, little Karo.
This is not an acceptable policy for citizens.
We expect the Council to take action.

Ladies and gentlemen Commissioners, dear colleagues, one sometimes wonders what we have actually been doing for the past year with all these discussions and debates, and the many meetings in the trialogue, where I could have imagined spending my time in a more enjoyable way.

And at this point, more than a year after the European elections, when we were still proclaiming in the streets and squares how we wanted to tame the financial markets, we are actually facing a very meager to non-existent result.
And the problem has already been described.
We are dealing with markets that operate globally today.
The member states still believe that they are able to enforce rules in this area with their national supervisory structures.
And precisely because that didn't work, he also contributed to the financial crisis not having triggered it, but contributing to it having also hit Europe.

And that's why I have to ask myself when this realization, which is often expressed in Sunday sermons, will be translated into political action, when it suddenly becomes a matter of protecting stock market places, when it becomes a matter of protecting banking structures and no longer protecting the citizens.

We in the European Parliament have dedicated ourselves to this task, and I hope that the Member States will also dedicate themselves to this task, because they share the responsibility for implementing proper supervisory rules for citizens, ensuring that individuals' savings remain secure in the long term.
Of course, I hope, gentlemen Commissioners, that the Commission will now really do everything to ensure that we achieve a good result as quickly as possible, in the interests of the people of Europe.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we in this European Parliament have a responsibility to ensure strong regulation of the financial markets.
All that we proposed was greatly watered down in the trialogues.
Council and government do not want strong intervention rights.
Giegold is right to call what is happening at the moment "tower-building thinking".
The intention does not seem to be strict regulation, but rather to design the system to be a little more fail-safe.
We will end up with a fragmented supervisory structure that will not be able to exercise real control over the financial markets.
Inadequate conclusions are being drawn from this financial crisis, from this economic crisis, and in doing so, the next crisis is already being prepared.
Many national economies, even in Europe, will not survive the next blows, with all the social and economic consequences for the people in Europe.
But you expect that this predatory beast, financial market capitalism, will be recaptured and the primacy of politics will be restored.
When the CEO of Unicredit Bank, Alessandro Profumo, stated over the weekend, "We need a strong and unified European financial supervisory authority and a common set of rules for"
When he speaks in the Member States and advocates for stricter capital rules, he is appealing to this Parliament to actually establish these rules.
It is up to this European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to urgently implement effective regulation; it would only be the first step towards a status quo.
Finally, let the big promises be followed by actions. My faction stands for strong European regulation.
Anything else but regulation would be a danger to the euro, to a united EU, and to democracy.
Bad timing for this debate.
I would have liked to have seen the Dutch team win, even if it was the last time in this World Cup.
Probably a bad omen, because now we're not allowed to watch and then they probably won't win anyway.

But on the subject of Commissioner, you are giving the right signal. Commissioner, Mr. President, we are concluding today or tomorrow, to be precise, a legislative package that we have been discussing for more than two years.
This is not only due to the controversy, but also to a European election in between and the entry into force of a new EU treaty, which has led us to have to adjust some things.

But I believe that if we were to draw a conclusion from this debate today, I would conclude that we should now vote on a compromise that is well worth saying yes to, even if one might do so with a clenched fist in one's pocket in one place or another.
I would like to highlight two aspects.
One is the environmental requirements for industrial plants.
The issue here is that we need to better enforce the best available technology in Europe.
I believe that we have found an exceptional compromise in the current proposal, which provides the EU Commission, Mr Potonik, and this is clearly addressed to you, with the necessary tools.

In the coming years, we must pay closer and more careful attention than before to ensuring that the approximately 52 industrial plants affected in Europe ultimately make better use of the best available technology than they do today.
I have heard many arguments in this debate.
I would like to address one point and reflect it here, because I simply cannot understand it.
I was often told that using the best available technology is too expensive and that we are thereby endangering the competitiveness of European industry, especially during a crisis.
I don't like to remember my past, but I come from the former GDR, from East Germany.
The economic and ecological collapse of the GDR was also due to the fact that for decades, investment in state-of-the-art technology had been neglected.

I believe that every industry, every industrial company, is called upon to invest in the latest technology because of its existence, because otherwise it loses competitiveness and, of course, also reduces pollutant emissions as a side effect.
I think we have the opportunity today to enact a law that improves this starting situation.
The second part of the directive, and this is a bit of the clenched fist I mentioned, is the large combustion plants.

Once again, as we did in the last directive, we are discussing renewed exemptions until 2020, and in some cases 2023, for large combustion plants that do not have to meet environmental standards, particularly air pollutant limit values.
I am addressing the Council here, but perhaps also a little bit all of us, that we need to think very carefully about how sensible it actually is that we do this regularly.

We welcome ambitious environmental targets, we discuss them and welcome them here, but whenever it comes to implementing them, translating them into concrete legislation, then a tragedy begins in Europe.
Then the member states suddenly realize what it costs, what bills need to be paid, and then those who have made advance payments are usually punished.
There are, in fact, a number of member states that already meet the requirements today and will be left out in the rain in the end.
I'll say it again here: both in industrial plants and in large-scale combustion plants, which are essentially coal-fired power plants, we're not talking about science fiction.
We are not talking about things that are not available, but rather it is the state of the art.
What is available on the market in terms of competitive and cost aspects can be installed in these systems. With this in mind, we conclude
Today, I abhor a legislative package that I believe is better than what is currently in effect, and that is why I encourage all of us to vote in favor of it.

I would also like to thank my colleagues who have been involved in this over the past two years, often under very difficult circumstances, for their support, their contributions, and above all, for the fact that almost all of the major groups have co-signed this compromise.
Mr President, three interesting things have happened while we have been debating. Firstly, it is clear that Europe will become the world champion in football.
A good omen, I believe.
Who should work, who must come in?
I don't actually want to submit any preferences now.
Secondly, Germany is receiving compliments from the UK.
Chris Davis, thank you very much. It doesn't happen every day.
It is worth noting that.
And thirdly, the world is still in order. Even for the Greens, football is more important than environmental protection.
Unfortunately, our colleague Bas Eikud has already left again.
But of course, congratulations to our Dutch friends.
I wanted to mention two aspects of the debate that I have just been following.
First, I understand all the worries and hardships of my Eastern European friends all too well.
As an East German, I am also half Eastern European.
I understand that not every environmental policy step taken in Western European countries over the past decades can now be immediately replicated in Eastern Europe.
High-level environmental protection must be affordable.
Yes, that's correct.

But I believe that even when taking this sentence into account, it is worth agreeing to this compromise, because it does justice to the different starting positions in which many member states find themselves.
And secondly, the argument that using the best available techniques jeopardizes competitiveness, especially in relation to China. This argument is not only false, it is even dangerous.
We must come to terms with the fact that industrial processes in Asia are definitely cheaper than they are here.
And we will only succeed in this competition if we use the best available technology in as many industries as possible.
Those who do not do this lose their competitiveness.
No one is demanding that this law be used to shut down an industrial plant tomorrow.
No one is demanding a leap from zero to one hundred to achieve any pollutant limit value within a week.
We have sufficient transition periods, but to say that one should forgo them for competitive reasons is wrong.
I believe that with this directive, we have not only made a significant shift in environmental policy, but also in industrial policy, which will be worth working on in the coming years.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking my fellow Members from the other groups for their assistance in drafting my report on Kosovo, and also Eva Marr, who has done some very valuable work in the secretariat.

And to you, Commissioner, I also express my thanks for the good cooperation, but also for what you mentioned, that it was important for you to travel to the north of Kosovo, to even spend a night there, and thereby to make it clear to the population that you stand for this population there as well.
They gave a speech at the university and opened the EU building there.

I think that was an important signal to make clear what this European Parliament has already expressed in the past and is expressing again now, namely support for an independent Kosovo on its way into the European Union.
We are currently in a situation where there is once again a so-called important crossroads for Kosovo, for the citizens, especially of all ethnic groups in Kosovo.
In a few weeks, the International Court of Justice will decide and give its opinion on the position regarding the declaration of independence made a little over two years ago.

I hope that this decision, this opinion, will be an opportunity, something like an open window, as it is called in English, to establish regional cooperation on a new basis, but from the perspective of state sovereignty.

I assume that Kosovo is moving towards independence, and it needs to be made clear that the common future for all the states in the region, for Serbia, for Kosovo, and for all others, lies in membership of the European Union, and that on the way there, the problems that still exist must be resolved.
It is also the text of a resolution that makes it clear that the future of Kosovo lies in the European Union.

I am glad that we have a majority in favour, which also calls on the five Member States that have not yet recognised it to do so soon, and that the Commission is once again called upon to begin visa liberalisation as soon as possible.

Because the citizens of the country, especially the young ones, must not have the impression that they live in an isolated state, that they cannot go out, while everyone else in the surrounding area will soon have this future.
I think that's the assignment.
I hope that I will also find a large majority in the plenary tomorrow for this.

I have also tabled a new amendment that expresses strong regret about the outbreaks of violence in recent days and hopes for a swift and independent investigation, without using this as a basis for escalating emotions in the coming days and weeks.
Madam President, distinguished High Representative, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues! The recent events in Kyrgyzstan, the outbreaks of violence, the slaughter of people, the
The arson of houses and the streams of tens of thousands of refugees who left their hometowns and tried to flee the violence, all of this has shaken me and evoked compassion for the victims.
At the same time, these events in Kyrgyzstan also shed light on the situation in Central Asia, which must not leave us in the European Parliament untouched.
On the contrary, we should devote our full attention to the countries in this region.

In this context, we should focus not only on the countries that are rich in natural resources and of particular economic interest to us in Europe, but rather consider all countries on an equal footing within the framework of the Central Asia Strategy adopted in 2007.
That is our obligation.
The Central Asian states, which freed themselves from Tsarist and later Soviet rule less than 20 years ago, are burdened with a heavy legacy.
The arbitrary borders drawn by Stalin, without regard for the home regions of the peoples living there, apparently make cohabitation within and outside the borders of these states more difficult.
Poverty, corruption, disregard for human and minority rights, authoritarian regimes, economic conditions that, for example, in Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan, have driven hundreds of thousands into
If we force labor migration and, as is currently the case in Kyrgyzstan, resort to conflict resolution through the use of force, we leave the future path of these states marked with question marks.
Here, the European Union cannot simply stand by and watch.

If we do not want to lead these countries down a path towards fundamentalist structures, if we do not want to permanently consign the people there to dictatorial regimes, then we need to make a full commitment.
In addition to the urgently needed material aid, we need contact with these states and active support for the democratic forces developing there.
Let us give Prime Minister Rosa Otunbaeva a chance to pacify Kyrgyzstan and establish stable political conditions; let us debate this here and vote on it tomorrow.

The resolutions presented must be followed by actions, so that the people in Kyrgyzstan and the other Central Asian states can feel that we are not leaving them alone on their path to the future or delivering them to undemocratic forces.
The expectations of us Europeans in these countries are high, and we should not disappoint them.
The report was voted down for four reasons.
The architecture of the service has numerous weaknesses, the details of which will continue to cause us great concern.
The second point is that the European Ambassador will manage Commission funds in the future.
This exposes the funds to a variety of risks, and the safeguards for these risks are still absolutely unclear.
The third point is the abrogation of the rights of this Parliament in a Council regulation.
We have de facto co-decision powers in this procedure, and yet we have allowed the Council regulation to infringe on Parliament's rights.
That is why I would like to say, before my dossier, the budget regulation, that I do not feel bound by today's decisions.
The fourth point is the question of how we actually treat each other in Parliament.
In the last period, we decided on a parliamentary reform and procedures that we have now all trampled underfoot, also with the approval of the Presidium and also with the approval of the President.
Why do we implement a parliamentary reform that prescribes procedures if, when it really counts, we already violate them and do not adhere to them?
For these reasons, I cannot agree with this report.
Mr President, Commissioner, I am very much in favour of green genetic engineering, but cloning is something else.
You can't compare it to that at all.
Cloning is animal cruelty. Many colleagues have already said this here.
I also raised this point before the summer break, during the discussion we had. Only a fraction of animal clones are actually viable.
And those who survive, many, many of them die very early and in a very painful way.
They suffer from malformations of extremities, of organs.
They have weakened immune systems, they are susceptible to illness.
This means pain and suffering and this agonizing death.
How can we possibly be responsible for that?
This is how we advocate for animal welfare, and then we want to support such a technique.
No, we do not want that, and that is why we decided in July that we do not want any cloned meat or animal products from cloned animals.
And that is only consistent.

Yes, we know that the products from the cloned animals or their descendants are probably not harmful to health, and I personally assume that they would actually be suitable for human consumption. There is indeed no shortage of meat from conventional production.
Why should we engage in this cloning?
This is completely unnecessary, this cruelty to animals, and the population simply does not want it.
The public does not want these products, and we do not need them either. There is no argument for cloned meat in the European Union.
And that is why we want a very clear regulation explicitly for cloned animals and also for their offspring.
I want a ban on cloning and cloned products in the European Union, and I also believe that we can enforce this.
Of course, this must also apply to imports.
I want to be sure that I am not being secretly served cloned meat because it is not labeled, as has already happened here.
Scotland. I don't believe that all meat can be traced.
For beef, it may be possible.
But with pork, due to the volume produced, it will not be possible to trace whether there was ever a clone in the lineage.
Basically, I think yes, it is a matter of principle, it is an ethical question.
And other colleagues have said it: We must also deal with ethical issues, and we are also responsible for ethical questions.
There is, of course, the issue of animal welfare, but there is also another issue.
Experience shows that I am an animal producer, I studied this, experience shows that all reproductive techniques, once they really worked in animal production, were ultimately also applied to humans.
And so today we must ask ourselves: Do we want and can we accept cloning technology in the not too distant future, and can we also accept it in humans?
Well, I don't want that, and I can't do that either.
And even if a spare part, a clone, could perhaps donate a vital organ to me in the future, a clone of myself, I wouldn't want that.
I don't think that's an exaggerated horror vision.
I believe that this would be possible in the not too distant future if we were to allow cloning.
That is why we urgently need a ban not only on cloning, but also on cloned animals and their offspring throughout the EU.
I am not afraid of the WTO.
We can enforce this.
We don't have to copy everything the USA does, despite all the transatlantic friendship.
Mr President, it is no coincidence that we are finding it so difficult to reach an agreement here, in this case because two incompatible issues are being mixed together.
We probably would have been able to reach a good agreement on trademark protection if we had focused on that.
But the conflation with the Internet as a material entity is also factually incorrect, because new, different strategies are needed here than in substantive law.
This cannot simply be transferred.
Moreover, one must be aware that we pay for every prosecution on the net with infringements of civil rights, because one cannot see or find this out on one's own.
And the third thing is really clear to me: If I put cultural enjoyment on the web under threat of punishment, so that I have practically always had one foot in the firing line.
When I'm in prison, when I'm looking into the net, I won't be able to take advantage of the opportunities that the Internet offers for art, culture, and creativity.
That is why I appeal to you: Let's continue to talk about it.
>> MURAT: That is also a
Mr President, property, whether it is intellectual or physical property, is a fundamental pillar of the market economy.
That is why I believe it is important that we think about how we can resolve this issue among ourselves in a good consensus.
We definitely need one
It must become easier for consumers, self-employed individuals, and small and medium-sized enterprises to obtain the appropriate licenses here.
And it is precisely the availability of licenses for intellectual property rights that are valid throughout the EU that is of particular importance.
We need an internal market for intellectual property.
Above all, we also need the original language to be available throughout Europe.
Every language is an important cultural asset, and it should be possible for licenses granted for a language to be valid throughout Europe and therefore usable by all citizens.
We need interoperability and technical neutrality in order to be able to use this intellectual property accordingly.
And above all, we need sanctions for those who violate competition and trade law.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I have taken note that the Council does not wish to discuss the multiannual financial framework.

I would like to inform the Council that the European Parliament already wants to discuss this and that the Council cannot behave like children in a kindergarten and say that it will not respond to our questions and our proposals.
Secondly, I must ask the Council in this context whether it actually wants Lisbon or whether it does not want Lisbon.
Lisbon is not just a technical change, but means more tasks, means more task completion and therefore also answering related financial questions.
In addition, the Council has made decisions that will lead to new financial expenditures.
This has been carried out by many colleagues.

If the Council wants this and if the Council wants that no more money should be spent, then the Council must also say where exactly it wants to save, how it wants to save, where it wants to reallocate precisely, and not just make general statements.

We must propose percentage shifts and then leave it to the Parliament and the Commission to decide where the inconveniences should be implemented, especially since our options for reallocations and changes to the budget are extremely limited.

The tasks you assign us in addition, however, are so challenging that they do not involve small, insignificant sums, but I will mention only the areas of financial solidity of our states and their corresponding financial difficulties.
But if the program has to be utilized, then these are not small amounts that can be easily reallocated.

The same applies to ITER, the same applies to issues of internal security, the same applies to major research issues, and the same applies to questions when I address the key areas of focus for Parliament, namely in the fields of youth education and research.
In part, we are dealing with inadequate implementation, and in part, we are also dealing with a lack of transparency in the allocation of funds.
All these questions need to be addressed and worked on in concrete terms, and not answered by silence on the part of the Council.
Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen, I have a problem with parts of the debate.
When we talk about mountains, islands and sparsely populated regions, I get the impression from individual contributions that they are ex territorial and directly subordinate to the European Union.
But that is not the case.
Each of these territories belongs to a Member State, which are sovereign.
And the implementation of European decisions and objectives is still the responsibility of the Member States, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

And when I look at the European level, we have always paid special attention to these areas - mountain regions, sparsely populated areas, islands - in Commission communications up to the Lisbon Treaty.
And here in Parliament, many decisions have been made to support this region.
When I hear many complaints here now that there are still shortcomings in the regions, I ask myself: How have the member states dealt with the impulses we have sent out from the European level?
And what have the regions themselves done about it, and have they taken advantage of the European funding opportunities?

A new strategy is needed here. So I already feel sorry for the officials at DG Regio who have to incorporate the multitude of problems of islands, mountains and sparsely populated areas into a single strategy.

At the same time, we are experiencing an inflation of strategies - Danube, Baltic Sea, Black Sea, climate change, and so on - that soon we will need a strategy for the strategies in order to keep track of them all.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let's put aside the fun and games! I think what is really at issue - and this has been mentioned today, and I am very grateful to Commissioner Hahn for bringing it up - is that we must fight to ensure that there is a cohesion policy and a regional policy at European level after 2013.
This is the focus of our work, and it is in this area that we should also convince our colleagues in Parliament that this will be the case.
And in a continuation of cohesion and regional policy beyond 2013, mountains, islands and the other regions will also find their place.
However, we should not oppose individual motions for resolutions on the subject, for which there is currently no reason.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank the colleagues who have worked so intensively on this project, especially Mr Bilal Quadras.
This is proof that European politics is capable of responding to crises and offering solutions that help to move things forward.
We have had this situation of supply security several times.
The problem of supply security has thus become clearer and more evident.
We have been forced to act, and we have.

We have found solutions that were not easy, that also mean new instruments, and that, I find, are interesting not only because they create infrastructure standards in Europe, not only because they create common rules for prevention and emergency plans, not only because they provide certainty, as the Commissioner just said.

This has shown, and continues to show, that we can offer people 30 days of security in the future, but it has also shown that we are capable of finding compromises, compromises that then lead to actionable solutions.

It is challenging along the way, but it is now becoming clear that both the role and responsibility of companies in building networks and being accountable for them are in focus, as well as the flexibility of policymakers who say, "We won't force things that ultimately won't be profitable or wise."

are no longer reasonable. For example, flexibility in the returns, in the necessary returns, but not to say everything and always and at all costs, but also the necessity or the possibility to be able to assess individual cases, as well as strengthening cooperation in the regional area.

And just as important is the reminder that member states must also assume their responsibilities, but if the solutions cannot be found there, the Commission gets an additional task. The Commission, which is strengthened, does not decide alone, but decides when other solutions are no longer possible or has the final say.
Flexibility, solutions that keep the burdens within manageable limits, and last but not least, ensuring that solutions are available - this is the good news from Brussels for the people of Europe.
Mr President, my dear colleagues, my esteemed Commissioners, I do not need to emphasize how important cohesion and regional policy are for living together and growing together in Europe.
However, I also believe that the regional and cohesion policies of the future must increasingly focus on cities.
Because cities are an important driving force in the development of Europe.
At the same time, however, you are currently experiencing ecological, economic, and social problems in particular.
Therefore, my very specific question to Commissioner Hahn is: What possibilities do you see for highlighting the urban dimensions?

Quite specifically, Commissioner! You recently hinted at an event here in this house that you could imagine a certain percentage being reserved from the regional funds, precisely to emphasize the urban dimension.
Are these considerations still relevant?
If so, how high could this percentage possibly be?

Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for initiating a new debate here as a former Minister for Economic Affairs and Innovation, which I believe can make a significant contribution to growth in Europe.
If every small and medium-sized enterprise in Europe created an additional job, we would no longer have any unemployed people in Europe.
We should therefore consider how we can enable small and medium-sized enterprises to hire new workers and become actively involved in international export markets.
But research infrastructure is also an important concern, as is infrastructure in the transport sector.
The Commission has major tasks ahead of it here, particularly in restructuring the East-West connection, for example, Paris-Budapest, or the North-South connection.
Additional jobs can be created here, which we urgently need in Europe at present.

Madam President, dear colleagues, there is no doubt that we have made progress in recent years in achieving gender equality. Nevertheless, there are still many women who are relegated to low-skilled jobs.
This applies not only to activities that are traditionally carried out within the family.
In the deregulation of recent years, employment with social security coverage has often been transformed into atypical, precarious, and insecure employment relationships.
There, especially women.
European employment trends from 2000 to 2010 include 60 new precarious and atypical employment relationships, with two-thirds of these being women.
Women are often denied democratic participation due to their part-time employment and precarious employment in companies.
However, women today are far more engaged and better educated than in all previous generations.
They still earn 25 percent less than men on average.

We have dealt intensively with this issue in the employment committee and developed good proposals for the issue of female employment, including their inclusion regardless of the status of their work.

This means social security systems, the creation of childcare facilities, the alignment of pensions and social systems towards independent living, and the design of work according to the principles of good work.
And all of this has essentially been incorporated into the report on precarious employment of women.
The employment committee is satisfied with the outcome of this work and requests approval for the report presented.
Madam President! Mr President-in-Office of the Council! Landmines will probably continue to pose a major problem in the distant future.
Do you think it is possible to initiate your own research programs to track down landmines?
This is not just a European problem, it is a global problem.
Can you imagine identifying suitable institutions here that are involved in research programs in this field?

Colleagues, in the transatlantic dialogue, there are many things that unite us, such as fundamental values and the basic rights of freedom and democracy. However, there are also many things that divide us, namely the application and concretization of these respective rights when it comes to transatlantic relations.
This contradiction becomes particularly evident when it comes to security issues.
Data protection is a source of constant misunderstandings, we have known this for a long time.
And that is why the framework agreement, if we manage to get a very good one, will be a huge step forward.
We must find a solution here that enables citizens on both sides of the Atlantic to assert their rights with the other partner.
A second important point where we have similar foundations but very different approaches is climate protection.
That is why I very much hope that it becomes a topic and that it is discussed in detail.
The European Union must not use the transatlantic dialogue to weaken its own promises and commitments.
The Investment Fund Manager introduces a degree of transparency and regulation for the first time into this opaque thicket of hedge funds and alternative investment funds.
Unfortunately, these rules have remained incomplete.
It is still possible to access the common market with unregulated products through passive distribution.
In essence, market access for these products is not effectively restricted.
Europe has thus missed an opportunity to extend its rules internationally and to achieve uniform regulation.
Secondly, unfortunately, and contrary to Parliament's wishes, there was no effective debt brake at the European level for the funds.
It is still left to national rules to limit how high the debt of the funds can be, and that means that the consequences of the crisis are not being drawn at this point.
There will be a national downward race in terms of regulation.
What is crucial for us once again is that the plundering of companies by private equity funds is not effectively prevented.
Of course, there are private equity investments that make sense for companies.
But the rules that have now been made are unfortunately far from sufficient.
The information rights of employees, who rightly expect this, as well as the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises against this form of exploitation, are also not effective.
That is why it is very difficult to justify this to the voters in this case.
Unfortunately, it is. The responsibility for this does not lie with the parliament; it lies particularly with intensive lobbying by the relevant industry, successful above all in Britain.
The French government, but unfortunately I must say also partly the German government, and we had representation of these lobbies here in Parliament, rather in the form of the liberal group.
We cannot agree to this proposal because it would set a precedent for Parliament's failure to enforce effective rules.
We cannot possibly stand before our voters with our heads held high and say that we have succeeded in effectively regulating this shadow economy.
We hope that we will make more progress when revising the directive.
Thank you once again, especially for the cooperation here with my colleagues in Parliament.
Mr President, first of all, my sincere thanks to my colleague Mr Balz for his cooperation.
I can only underline that. Even with differing positions, it was a good collaboration.
Many believed - I want to emphasize this again - that the crisis of the Eurozone was over.
Ireland shows that this has not been the case.
Europe is still voluntarily surrendering itself to the financial markets.
The EU member states must continue to sell their government bonds on the financial markets and earn the trust of speculators through suicidal savings.
Over the weekend, we had to observe once again where this leads.

This time it was not the allegedly deceitful Greeks, but the model pupil Ireland, who was driven into the European rescue fund to save its banking system, which was also long considered exemplary, exemplary in its deregulation.
Meanwhile, the financial sector already seemed to be anticipating Portugal's capitulation, with its interest rates continuing to rise.
The ECB shares responsibility for this drama.
It has failed and continues to fail to offer a civilized alternative to the state casino by issuing Eurobonds.
While one half of Europe is recovering from the crisis, the ECB watches calmly as the other half continues to fall deeper into poverty and insecurity.
The austerity measures imposed on entire economies may be to the liking of European funds and banking giants, but they are of no help to Ireland, the monetary union, or the ECB.
Mr Trichet, don't listen to Mrs Merkel's simple financing department.
I say: If you want to save the economic and monetary union, don't leave European government bonds hanging in the air.
Introduce Eurobonds before the next victim of speculation falls.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, if you consider how we discussed this Commission proposal in the last legislative period, from total rejection to jubilation, with all the wonderful things being said about us, then I must say that I am thrilled with what is now before us.
And so, a great deal of thanks is due to the rapporteur and his co-rapporteurs for having turned this broad spectrum of opinions into a coherent opinion.
I believe the key word for this is patient-centered care.
So, instead of focusing on the many side effects, they asked themselves: What does the patient need?
I believe it is correct that we have agreed that the patient can obtain information through various means and not just one.
But I would like to emphasize that the doctor will still need to be the patient's trusted person and will certainly have an influence on critical issues.
We guarantee this because we have banned advertising for it and the information that the patient receives has been checked and approved by an authority.
This provides the information with a scientific basis for the time being, and the patient can certainly handle it.
Of course, it's true, not everyone can figure this out.
We can submit it via the Internet, we have various ways, and I believe it is so widely spread that we don't need to worry about it.
I can only hope that the Council finally has the courage to take up this issue.
It is very important, action must be taken quickly.
Patients expect that.
And I believe that we will have accomplished a good work.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, coal is an undisputed part of the energy supply.
It is also undisputed that competitiveness must be ensured and that subsidization cannot be the right approach.
The question now is whether the date of 2014 or 2018 is the correct one.
My colleague Rapka has put forward a number of clever arguments that I don't need to repeat.

My request to the Commission is actually quite simple: There is obviously a large majority in Parliament, across all the committees involved, in favor of affirming that competitiveness must be a criterion.

But that in the matter of the term, one simply creates the necessary flexibility, which is certain to also create the possibility for the member states to implement it, and that the burdens for the people, for jobs, and for economic structures remain manageable.

The only argument that has been mentioned, which incidentally also contradicts the Commission's impact assessment, which also seems to be leaning towards 2018, is the argument that climate policy reasons may play a role here.
I want to emphasize this aspect once again: Whether you burn foreign coal or your own coal, it makes no difference for the climate issue.

And my request to the Commissioner is to consider whether this four-year period, if a new argument arises in the Parliament and the Council, could not lead to the Commission also becoming more flexible.
I just understood the comment to mean that the committee is giving it some thought, and I thank you for that.

Mr President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner! If we must draw a lesson from Copenhagen, where you, Madam Commissioner, held the presidency, it is that the European Union must speak with one voice at such conferences in the future.
We may have differing opinions on this matter, but if we Europeans speak with different voices, our influence will not be credible, and if we are not credible, other people will not follow us.
Why should you?
That is why it is correct that the figures we agreed on at the end of 2002 under Chancellor Merkel must essentially remain in place and form the basis of these negotiations.

I share your opinion that the ambitious 2-degree target should not be seriously questioned today for a significantly lower degree, because this makes the feasibility of these goals extremely difficult and people tend to shy away from them.
I have a great concern that we are questioning our intellectual property.
Our industry also invests money and manpower to develop things.
If we now proceed to loosen the fence around this intellectual property and leave the holes in it as they are at the moment, then the valuable parts, namely our property, will slip away.
I am very much in favor of technology transfer, but our companies must also see a reason to invest in it, and that's why intellectual property must not be watered down.
As for commitments, I also tend to demand serious commitments from our partners worldwide.
But they must be credible, and they must be feasible for these countries.
Otherwise, we will do the exact opposite of what we want, namely, they will distance themselves from us.
Also appearing credibly in Cancn is an important point.
The really big decisions will be made later in Johannesburg, but in Cancn, I believe we should prepare the ground.
I am a farmer by profession.
If the field is not in order, there will be no harvest.
Let's focus on the good land.
Mr President, there was an incident during the debate on the European Council this morning, which I do not wish to address any further, as I was the target of an insult.
But I want to say: There are levels at which I cannot be offended, and where I do not even perceive it as an insult, because in order to offend me, one must have a certain degree of seriousness.
I would, however, like to express my heartfelt thanks for the countless signs of solidarity I have received since then here in this House.
I would like to express my heartfelt thanks to you, dear colleagues from all factions.
I think this is a sign of our shared democratic and pro-European conviction, which the overwhelming majority of this House shares.
For that, my heartfelt thanks.

Mr President, dear Commissioner, dear Minister, dear Mr Gauzs and dear colleagues and shadow rapporteurs, for the first time, I am pleased that we have now taken this step, that for the first time, a sector of the European financial system is being placed under direct European supervision.
This is also a step towards a strong Europe in a single market, for strong control over a sector that has contributed to the crisis.
I would also like to make a comment on this, Mr Barnier. The selection processes for the new authorities are currently underway, and the new authorities are only as good as the staff.
