I can only hope that in the selection of personnel, the focus will truly be on expertise, independence from the financial industry they are supposed to control, and a clear commitment to public interests, and that we will not see national quotas again in the selection process that override these important criteria.
Moreover, there is still much to be done in the area of rating agencies.

We still do not have proper transparency of the information that the rating agencies work with, and we have far too much use of regulatory ratings in the financial industry and in the regulations governing the financial industry.
We have serious conflicts of interest, we clearly have market power held by three major providers, and we have no liability for negligently created content.
That is why I ask you, Commissioner. It is good that the consultation is now underway, and we are eagerly awaiting the results.
I also think that civil society should participate in this consultation, but then it must also be about making a bold proposal.
I am already looking forward to your proposal.
Be as courageous as you have been so far and let us work together to create legislation next year that truly solves the problems that still exist in the rating market on a European level.
We owe that to the citizens.
Mr President, Mr Minister, Mr Barnier, ladies and gentlemen, the damage that rating agencies can cause has been evident in recent months since the beginning of this year.
There is therefore an urgent need for action.
That is why I welcome the directive, particularly the fact that ESMA will be given responsibility for the supervision and registration of credit rating agencies.
I think this is an important and good step forward.
However, numerous good and further-reaching proposals were lost during the negotiations on the report.
I would like to point that out again here.
The appointment of ESMA therefore remains the only real and positive innovation.
The proposals for a public database to create ratings have been dropped, and there is no mention of establishing a public rating agency.
The consistent and continuous review of established ratings by the supervisory authorities has also been overlooked.

The Commission had also proposed promoting unsolicited ratings in order to overcome the disastrous issuer mandates for the evaluation of financial market products. However, nothing has come of this either.
I hope that these aspects will be taken into account in the reports that are still to come on this subject, which Jean Paul Gauz  and also you, Mr Barnier, have spoken about.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would also like to thank those who worked on this report, especially my colleague Mr Benson.
I want to point out two aspects and perhaps make you think a bit.
We agree that energy efficiency and energy conservation are the simplest and most sensible solutions.
The question is: How do we achieve this goal?
And I would like to ask the question: What has actually been achieved by repeatedly approaching people in Parliament with new and higher percentages?
Have we really achieved more and moved more?
Or why and where has energy been used more sparingly?
I learn that the industry, which consumes a lot of energy, is becoming more energy-efficient because it saves money and because it is beneficial for them.
I learn that people, when they know that this device consumes more energy or less energy, when they see that and can decide for themselves what is advantageous, will choose it.
Perhaps the method is not to work with percentages at all, but to proceed correctly through incentives.
Second question: The Commissioner has just very impressively and clearly demonstrated how complicated even the description of the term is. What exactly is it?
How different is this in the member states?
The colleague just pointed out that the member states also have very different situations economically and geographically, totally different.
Is it the right answer to work with a number, to work with a binding number, or is there nothing else we can think of?

I believe that in energy policy, we need to move away from the debates of the past, which rely on simple numbers, binding targets, and so-called miracle solutions to achieve results, because it is clear that we have not achieved enough.
Perhaps we should try the other approach, the differentiated one, the one with different answers that takes into account the different situational conditions, but also achieves an effect.
It's about the effects, not about how we feel.
Mr President, this regulation, which is being discussed today, did not receive much attention in any of the committees for a long time.
But now, at the end, when the result was in, some people in this house woke up.
Unfortunately, some have not appeared for the debate now, it would have been very interesting to hear their opinions as well.
As a former member of the Convention, the spirit of the Convention is still very, very clear in my mind.

which has clearly called in many areas for the European Parliament to be given certain rights in order to have and maintain its credibility within the framework of the institutions and towards the citizens.
In this sense, what the Convention laid down for us was still not a gift.
It was extremely difficult negotiations, led primarily by the Belgian presidency vis--vis the Council, that enabled some important progress to be made.
I recall what my colleague Lehne said earlier: it was precisely the question of the constant possibility of checking whether the Commission has exceeded its powers.
Of course, there are some not entirely ideal regulations, such as international trade agreements, but I can still agree with the outcome.
I thank the Belgian presidency.
She really put her heart and soul into making something happen, and our rapporteur, who negotiated with heart and mind.
13. I would like to make the following statement on behalf of our group. This is a motion that my colleague Gran Frm had tabled on behalf of our group in the Committee on Budgets.
We no longer re-submitted this amendment, but the Green Party faction re-submitted it with 40 signatures from Green Party members of parliament.
We will abstain from voting on this motion.
However, I have reached an agreement with my Green Party colleagues. We are in complete agreement on the matter.
However, since we have fundamentally stated that we, as a group, will not be submitting any new proposed amendments, we will abstain.

However, I would like to explicitly state that we support this point on the financial transaction tax and hope that our colleagues on the other side of the House will support us in the votes in the coming days.
Mr President, I believe it is important that we do not use national tax systems against the internal market.
This is particularly important for cross-border services, where equal treatment is required.
We now have a negative example in Hungary, where retroactive price limits were used to tax the crisis.
This is not acceptable, especially the financial, insurance and trade industries, but also energy is heavily affected here.
I hope that this will not also be used in the field of health services in the future.
I would also like to ask President Orbn to review these regulations, because they are completely contrary to the concept of the internal market.
It is important that the EU addresses the problems of migration and asylum law.
The Commission has submitted corresponding proposals.
At present, there is still no precise analysis of the implementation of the existing legal regulations.
There are also hardly any well-developed calculations and analyses available for the new proposals.
I may state that the EPP unreservedly affirms the right to asylum and the right to protection for those in need of protection.
Unfortunately, considering reality also leads us to the problem that the right to asylum is claimed for entirely different reasons or even deliberately misused.
The right to asylum and subsidiary protection is not an instrument for general immigration into the 27 member states.
We must also ensure that organized human traffickers do not get a chance to profit billions from people's fates by exploiting our asylum laws.
Asylum procedures must be carried out in a qualified and careful manner.
Persecuted individuals must have the guarantee of finding protection within the EU.
That is why the Commission has provided for corresponding obligations in the new regulations.
I consider many of them to be correct, such as interpreters, proper health care, and consideration of special protection needs.
However, I also want to mention points that I consider problematic.
The authorities of the member states are given far too few opportunities to combat abuse.
The possibility of conducting expedited procedures and border procedures should be unduly restricted.

If an applicant seriously violates his cooperation obligations, there are hardly any possibilities for sanctions, quite the contrary. If he disappears illegally, the member state should no longer be able to terminate his procedure negatively. If he reappears, an extended range of procedural options should be available to him.
Even if the application is clearly unfounded, an accelerated procedure should still be possible after the second follow-up application.
This means significant cost increases.
The free legal advice in the form of a lawyer is currently also a significant cost increase for the states, according to the wording of the Commission's draft.
I simply ask the Commission to reconsider the consequences of its proposals on practical reality, financial impacts, and the problems for the administrations of the Member States.
We want a high standard, but it must also be feasible and, above all, must not set particularly hard-pressed member states impossible tasks.
Mr President, thank you very much for allowing me to take the floor once again.
I have a big request for you, Commissioner Fle.
I want to start by saying that false assumptions lead to incorrect cost estimates.
We currently do not have declining numbers in the area of asylum seekers, but rather significantly increasing numbers.
This has to do with visa facilitations, for example, for Serbia and Macedonia.
We are currently also experiencing a massive increase in the abuse of asylum rights in an attempt to enter a country in the European Union.

If one starts from the false assumption that disputing the first procedure in a higher-qualified reform would save costs in further instances, one automatically assumes that all member states have a poor first procedure, so to speak.
But that is not the case.
If you raise the standards overall, it consequently means that this will lead to increased costs.
Raising quality standards for everyone and also complicating procedures is something I am happy to discuss, but in practical reality, it leads to higher costs.

That is why I would like to reiterate my heartfelt request to genuinely take the concerns of the countries seriously, because the practical reports from the countries are partly available and are being provided.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report commends the Commission for its successful competition policy.
However, it must not be forgotten that unregulated competition can also contribute to rising unemployment and the growing gap between rich and poor.
Unfettered competition still takes precedence over people's social needs in the European Union.
The creed for free markets cannot obscure the fact that they not only repeatedly fail, but are incapable of establishing social justice on a lasting basis.
A few procedures regarding competition distortions and price regulations simply do not solve this problem.
A fair and at the same time socially responsible internal market only works with strong and fair regulation.
More is urgently needed for this.
For example, it is not acceptable to subject more and more public services to private sector competition.
The report formulates recommendations for the Commission's future competition policy.
Much stronger consumer protection, the removal of public services from competition rules, and the control of cartelsall of this is urgently needed.
Furthermore, a contractual clause for secure social progress would be necessary, which would at least be on an equal footing with the competition rules in Europe.
Mr President, it is a truly important moment that today we are commemorating the Holocaust of Roma and Sinti for the first time in the European Parliament.
Let me begin with the farewell letter that a 14-year-old boy wrote to Robert Reinhardt in 1943 before his deportation from a German children's home to Auschwitz.
He wrote: "I have found my parents again.
We are on the transport to the concentration camp.
I have mentally prepared myself to the point where I can endure death.
I would like to thank you once again for everything you have done for me.
Greetings to all, see you in heaven!
Aier Oberg

Ladies and gentlemen, this boy did not return, like 500 other Roma and Sinti, and although Roma and Sinti were among the first victims of industrial-scale mass killings, together with Jews, 66 years later, the full truth about it remains unspoken.
And the complicity of the majority society is often covered up.
We need the whole truth about this chapter of history.
The Holocaust of Roma and Sinti must be recognized and punished as a crime against humanity so that this history does not repeat itself.
We must fight against the prejudices against these people with passion.
We must put a stop to racist abuse and acts of violence, such as those that took place in Hungary the year before last, and we must do so with civil courage.
Freedom, equality, and solidarity are not privileges for a select few, but the rights of all, because human and citizens' rights are indivisible.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues, in my view, the issue now is to really use the possibilities of the law on the internet.
We have pushed the concept of strong financial supervision in Europe to its limits, and we have doubts as to whether these possibilities are really being exploited institutionally.
We see flaws in the process. To date, we, as a parliament, have not received the list of candidates in advance, but only the final result.
It would be simple for you to send us the current ones for the executive directors.

We have clearly seen the lack of gender equality in the appointment of positions, and we have doubts, due to certain incidents in the process, that the member states are truly appointing this institution in the European interest.
This and the other points in our letter justify asking a fundamental question.
But beyond that, it is of course about the suitability of the individual persons, and each person must be assessed individually and according to their competencies.
There, we see two major problems.

We have heard in the hearings that one of the candidates questioned the fact that it is a European institution, instead speaking of a network of supervisory authorities, and was not prepared to correct this even when asked.
When asked whether they are prepared to make all lobby contacts with the financial industry transparent, we did not receive any clear statements.
We have sent a letter to all three candidates, and for us, the outcome of the vote depends on whether we receive clear and comprehensive responses to it.
Mr President! Mr President! We, as the Social Democratic Group, wish to table the same motion.
However, I would like to recommend to my colleague Mauro and the distinguished House that we phrase it a bit more precisely.
We are dealing with a truly enormous influx.

Today, Italy, like any other country in the Mediterranean region, is certainly overwhelmed by the task of managing the current problem on its own, and it is certain that Italy will not be the only country confronted with the massive influx of refugees.
We can assume that Malta, Greece, and Spain will also be confronted with this problem in the foreseeable future.

Therefore, we would like to request that we formulate the title of the debate very precisely, namely in a Commission statement on immediate measures by the European Union to support Italy and other EU countries affected by the influx of refugees.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I expressly welcome the outcome of the conciliation procedure.

The implementation of the regulation will ensure that, in the bus transport sector, a high level of protection comparable to that of other modes of transport is now established for all passengers, including those with limited mobility.

Firstly, it achieves high levels of safety for people, secondly, it ensures a high general level of consumer protection, and thirdly, it takes into account the special circumstances of a transport sector that is predominantly characterized by small and medium-sized enterprises.

This means that the extreme demands, which would have made bus transport almost completely impossible due to excessive requirements, are off the table, as are demands where the majority of the member states would have fallen completely outside the scope of the regulation.
Bus transport services that benefit citizens in general must also offer a high quality of service to disabled people and those with reduced mobility.
They should be entitled to assistance, and in the interest of social integration, this should be free of charge.
Madam President, I would like to congratulate everyone, especially my colleague Mr Kancsjan, for his efforts in the difficult and lengthy process of drafting a compromise on this challenging issue.
There were successes that have already been mentioned, but there were also disappointments, such as the scope and other subtleties that have already been discussed.
With this compromise for bus transport, we have covered passenger rights for all modes of transport.
The next necessary step is to create a common, coherent and efficient framework programme for all passenger rights.
Fair and clearly defined rights are of particular importance for the EU's credibility among European citizens.
And in order to be credible, the coherence of rights for the different modes of transport must therefore be respected.
It is unacceptable that fundamentally different criteria apply to the rights of air passengers than, for example, to those of train passengers.

That is why it is particularly important when drafting a framework programme not to focus on the lowest and weakest standards, but rather to keep ambitious goals in mind for the benefit of the citizens.

Madam President, Mr President, dear colleagues, we are in the midst of a major economic crisis, we have been talking about it for months, and that is all true, but we usually just discuss it in headlines and then carry on making decisions as if nothing had happened.
I believe it is because we in Parliament are not specific enough or honest enough in our behavior, but rather it is a headline-grabbing policy that is being pursued.
What is actually being done to promote growth and stability?
Do we ourselves contribute to managing finances more orderly and wisely?
Do we really critically examine whether we are making the right expenditures, or does each of us not have a new idea every day about where more money can be spent?

If we do not have the strength to concentrate the financial resources on future projects, that is, to engage in debate and decision-making, then it is pointless to talk about innovation and research without providing the necessary funds.
That is relatively dishonest.
And if we want to stimulate the economy, we must also pursue a policy that stimulates the economy and doesn't spend all day thinking about how to disrupt industry or the economy.
We cheerfully continue to make decisions, constantly demanding new decisions today as well, which disrupt the economy in its development.
Does anyone really believe that the issue of binding energy efficiency targets, to name just one example, contributes to driving the economy forward?
Do you really believe that we have stimulated the economy with our decisions, which we have often made in connection with energy?
Or have we disturbed them?
I would like us to have a more honest conversation about this and then make a few fewer decisions, but perhaps make the decisions that really move things forward.
It is more exhausting, it will also mean more hard work and more disputes, but that is the essence of democracy.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the demand for a financial transaction tax is not new; opponents of globalisation have been calling for such a tax for several years now.
But even five years ago, hardly anyone would have believed that it could be implemented in the foreseeable future.
But this week it is on the agenda in the European Parliament, along with a CO2 tax and Eurobonds, and I think that's a good thing.
I can only welcome and support the financial instruments that Anni Podimata proposes in her report, and I think we will vote in favor of them accordingly.
They are urgently needed instruments.
So far, the consolidation of public finances has focused solely on cutting spending.
The reduction in public spending primarily affects workers, pensioners, and the poor, i.e., those who rely on the welfare state.
The revenue side of the public sector has so far been completely overlooked.
It is the second adjustment that can be made to consolidate public finances.
Above all, however, the revenue side also allows for the main contributors to the public debt crisis to be adequately involved in the reduction of public debt.
To consolidate public finances, an increase in tax revenues is simply indispensable.

In fact, the high level of public debt is primarily a result of the nationalization of private debt, namely the assumption of debts by private banks and the financing of the subsequent financial crisis by the public sector.
The states are therefore by no means solely responsible for the debt crisis.
It is therefore not only logical, but also politically necessary, to ask the financial sector to contribute.
With the financial transaction tax, this sector would finally be held accountable as the main cause of public debt and would contribute to the reduction of this debt.
This is an important political signal sent out by this report, if it is adopted as it was presented.
But we also consider Eurobonds to be a sensible and therefore necessary instrument.
They contribute more to reducing debt than all sanctions or more or less well-intentioned advice.

The complaints of some surplus countries that their interest burdens would increase as a result of Eurobonds are not acceptable, because at the same time these surplus countries also earn money through their exports to the deficit countries.
This can then be criticized as a transfer union.
But anyone who wants a social Europe, who wants the EU to remain united in the future, must at least agree in principle to a transfer union.
In conclusion, I would like to say to the Commission that I hope it will finally present the proposals for a financial transaction tax that have been demanded for over a year now. Thank you.
Mr President, Madam President, the rescue umbrellas are meant to protect EU member states from insolvency.
However, they burden people with brutal austerity programs and let the perpetrators off scot-free. Moreover, the Commission is now also interfering in national wage policies.
Mr President, it is absurd, and it brings a tear to your eye when you hear this formal argument here: that it was all not meant to be a social policy measure.
This position is completely unacceptable. Wage policy is not the EU's responsibility. This policy of the Commission is in blatant contradiction to the idea of this European Union.
The European Union was never a project for downward wage competition and social dumping.
It can be read there about wage rigidity, which is to be reduced.
I only want to talk about white issues. Wages should reflect market conditions.
Ladies and gentlemen, when blind people talk about color, people who formulate something like that have no idea about collective bargaining systems.
They interfere with collective bargaining autonomy and reduce the much-vaunted autonomy of the social partners and social dialogue to absurdity.
I want to make it clear: This Parliament is called upon to ensure the preservation of autonomous collective bargaining, protect social dialogue, and prevent further erosion of social security.
We need measures against a counterproductive austerity policy and punitive actions. Thank you.
You are a clever man, but you have not answered my question.

That is why I am asking again: When Mr. Oettinger says that we currently suspect that certain plants that are still in operation will not survive our stress tests, I interpret this to mean that you are aware that these plants are so poorly secured that they will not meet the criteria.
Why don't you take action today?
Because in my eyes, that is a real danger.
Mr President, I would actually like to ask the two representatives from the Council and the Commission why they believe they need to present their arguments on this topic using speech bubbles.
I believe it helps no one if it is not explicitly stated that, in preparation for the Istanbul Conference, the Member States of the European Union and the European Union itself
must finally fully comply with their obligations for development aid, and it cannot be tolerated in any way that Member States are increasingly shirking this responsibility.
It is unacceptable that one billion people still go hungry every day, and that most of them live in LDCs, the poorest countries in the world.

It is unacceptable that a large portion of our development aid is not going towards the promotion and development of agricultural structures, but that this proportion has rapidly decreased in recent years, with one billion people suffering from hunger.
And then talking about it. We hope that the LDCs become more shock-resistant. I'm beginning to think that's a slow process.
I urge you to address the problems in a concrete and clear manner and to assume concrete obligations in order to actually help the LDC.
Mr President, public procurement law and the awarding of public contracts are an essential component of the internal market.

Mr Barnier, if you say that you also want to promote social integration in this context, then I have to ask: I have heard little about the protection of social rights, I have heard little about the protection of collective agreements.
That is one of the basic rules that you, as you say, do not want to question yourself.

If one wants to protect basic rules, one must ensure in the future that elementary social standards are protected when awarding public contracts, that collective agreements are not undermined, and that wage dumping is prevented.
This is part of a modernized public procurement law.
I expressly state that fundamental social rights must no longer be subordinated to economic freedoms and free competition.
Either we want a social Europe, or we want lasting conflicts with the people who are turning away from this Europe, in which they do not see their interests safeguarded.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner Kroes, radio frequencies are a precious and limited resource that must be managed with care, foresight, and from a societal perspective.
That is why the radio spectrum policy programme is of particular importance.
Radio frequencies must be used efficiently, taking into account economic, social and cultural aspects.
To achieve this, the technical capabilities must be fully utilized in all band areas to generate the highest possible efficiency.

The basis of radio frequency policy must be the telecommunications package adopted last year, as it also stipulates that the radio frequency management of the EU and its member states must equally meet cultural, social, and economic interests.
This must be taken into account, especially when harmonizing the use of frequencies in the EU.
In this context, I would like to point out that the implementation of the digital dividend 1 is being carried out at very different speeds in the Member States.
Further opening of the UAF band, especially below 800 MHz, should therefore only be considered after taking into account the experience gained in clearing this band.
Many technical and financial issues have not yet been conclusively resolved.

And the issue of interference and the question of cost compensation for cultural institutions and local authorities in the technical conversion, for example in the field of wireless microphones, has not yet been satisfactorily resolved.
When distributing frequency bands, the various interests must be weighed against each other responsibly.

The widespread provision of mobile broadband networks is, on the one hand, a fundamental requirement in the interests of European citizens, but at the same time, the development of public and private broadcasting must continue to be taken into account as an important instrument for information and cultural diversity.
We need to set the course for technological development, Europe's positioning in the field of digital information technology, and cultural diversity.
Mr President, dear Mr Rehn, I would like to say first of all that you have described it. The situation has worsened.
The Eurozone is experiencing a widening gap between countries that are recovering and those that are weaker.
And the costs of supporting the weaker countries are continuing to rise.

In this situation, I have a few questions for you. As Commissioner for Monetary Affairs, I ask you: On day two, liabilities and claims between the central banks in the ECB system have accumulated to over 400 billion euros.
This is because the banks are still not adequately financed by the capital market.
How do you assess these liabilities that are not provided for in the Eurosystem?
The big problem, why we are not making progress with the restructuring of the debt, is that the banking system, as Mrs. Ford also said, is not set up correctly.
The proposal for a European restructuring system has been delayed.
When will the Commission present this?
And as Commissioner for Economic and Monetary Affairs, how do you assess this delay?
What do you do to make it go faster?
Then we saw, as we Greens had predicted for a long time, that the measures taken against Greece would not work for Portugal as long as the macroeconomic conditions in the Eurozone were not improved.
We still have absolutely rising interest burdens from a macroeconomic perspective for these countries.
We have seen increasing capital exports and capital flight in some of these countries.
And we still have a lack of demand from several European partner countries, especially from the strong Eurozone countries.
And we have rising resource and food prices, at least if you take out the recent ups and downs.

In addition to the bailouts for these countries and the financial assistance, I wonder what measures are being taken to provide macroeconomic relief to the weaker countries in areas such as taxes, external demand, and interest rates.
And she
I would therefore encourage you to propose a strong package that improves the macroeconomic conditions of these countries in the Eurozone.

And finally, in my opinion, the measures have hit the weakest in Greece, Portugal, and Spain against the spirit of the EU treaty, while the stronger, the wealthy, have not yet been called upon to bear any of the burden.
What measures are you taking to ensure that the wealthy are also called upon to contribute to the costs of this crisis?
Mr President, Mrs Kinga Gncz is a Member of my group.
One can be against Ferenc Juchani, one can be for Ferenc Juchani.
One can reject Kinga Gnns as a politician or be in favor of her.
This can certainly be determined freely and independently by anyone, whether they are in favor of or against a person's political beliefs.
The debate we are having here is about the last dictatorship in Europe.
And we are taking you through one of the most brutal and bloody dictators on the European continent.
I find it absolutely unacceptable that an elected democratic member of my group is compared to a bloodthirsty dictator.

I believe that Parliament must also reject this, especially from the representative of a party that is known for its hatred and persecution of the Roma minority in Hungary, which is unparalleled in Europe.
If one person here does not have the right to criticize Mrs. Kinga Gncz, then it is Mrs.
Mr President, my esteemed colleagues, dear visitors, Europe's cultural diversity is a valuable asset that must be preserved and further developed in the future.
In order for this to be possible, we must address the challenges of the digital age not only in the information and knowledge society, but above all in the cultural and creative sector.
Cultural diversity is not only an ideal value, but it also represents a significant economic factor.
In the EU, approximately five million people are employed in the cultural sector.
This corresponds to approximately 2.5 percent of total employment.
The cultural sector is a growth sector that is developing faster than many other areas of the economy.

The development of information and communication technologies is driven by the content provided by the cultural sector, just as the nature and quality of content have changed and evolved through technology.
We therefore need to create framework conditions for the cultural and creative industries in which they can develop sustainably in the face of the challenges of the digital age.
We need a modern, accessible and legally secure system in which everyone can develop equally.
Culture and the creative industry are a driving force for Europe.
That is why we must also focus on this area in the field of school and vocational education.
We must impart cultural and creative competencies to young people and also in the offerings of lifelong learning.
However, we must also better strengthen the entrepreneurial skills of cultural workers, not just their business competencies, but also their media literacy in the field of new technologies.
We need framework conditions in which artists can create and secure their livelihood.
Therefore, we will have to intensively address the issues of copyright, social security, and intellectual property, as well as open access to information and content, in order to
to ensure the creative and cultural industries thrive in a digital environment in the future and to preserve Europe's cultural diversity and heritage as a key feature of the European Union.

Mr President, dear colleague Kellam, dear colleagues from the Baltic countries, dear colleagues! Today we are commemorating in a special way the expulsions and mass deportations from the Baltic countries.
These expulsions are among the darkest events in European history.
And indeed, the past century was not only and not least called a century of expulsions, and not without reason.
And today we all bow our heads in respect for the victims of these inhumane acts.
In this context, we demand a comprehensive investigation of Soviet history and, in particular, the atrocities of Stalinism.

Russia today should not understand this as a political attack, but as support for the re-evaluation of its own history, which, like the history of other European countries, is marked by both light and dark sides.
But just as we think of the victims from the Baltic countries, we think of the Armenians who were expelled from Turkey at the beginning of the following century.
We commemorate the so-called population exchange between Turkey and Greece.
Deporatations in Europe reached a particular peak in the middle of the century under the Nazi regime and the communist regime of the Soviet Union.
The expulsions after World War II also left deep wounds, as did the expulsions during the Yugoslav wars.
We must also not forget, however, that many colonial powers were characterized by expulsions.
We must demand a serious examination of the various forms of displacement and the specious justifications for them.
This also includes clarifying guilt and punishing the guilty, insofar as this is still possible, as is currently the case with Mladic.

But the crucial answer is European unity, especially through and with the independent Baltic countries, and a clear commitment to continuing the European unification process that has not yet been completed.
And this historical task is what we owe not only to ourselves, but especially to the victims of the many expulsions in Europe.
Many female politicians from all countries in Europe, both East and West, have worked on this.
For example, consider the Gdask Declaration, signed by Polish President Bosniewski and German Federal President Raus.
And because we want to learn from the past, we must be vigilant even towards the first signs of displacement, as in the case of the Roma.

We must reject all statements, such as sending the Arab immigrants back across the Mediterranean in boats, and we must resist when some want to abolish Europe's borderless achievements and bring back a new, narrow-minded nationalism.
Let us bow in Erfurt before all the victims of expulsion and deportation, but let us unanimously commit ourselves to the continuation of European unity as the only real guarantee against
This is a policy that has brought so much misfortune to people in Europe and beyond in the last century. Never forget, never again were demands that arose immediately after the Second World War.
They have lost none of their validity; they are best preserved in a united Europe.

Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, I had the opportunity to witness the referendum on the independence of South Sudan as a parliamentary election observer, and I was impressed by the overwhelming support of the South Sudanese people for determining the future of their country themselves.
I also saw the great expectations among the people, who saw their country's independence as liberation from slavery.

Thousands, perhaps tens of thousands of so-called internally displaced persons, who were driven by the decades-long fighting in the south to the refugee camps in the north, set out on their way to their former South Sudanese homeland.

And of course, in addition to the independence of the country, the people of South Sudan want above all to live in peace and pursue a path towards a happier future after all those decades of conflict, during which millions of South Sudanese had to lose their lives.
On July 9, the new state of South Sudan is set to officially become independent and expand the family of nations in our world.
The starting conditions are as bad as they can be, and a lot has already been said about that here.
70 of the people live as Norbanizing cattle breeders, 80 are illiterate. The conflict over Abyei is escalating into a military conflict.
There were already dead and wounded there.

As if that were not enough, rivalries between tribes and armed groups in South Sudan are also increasing, and according to estimates by observers, more than 1 million people have already lost their lives since January.
The wounded and mutilated are barely counted.
Sudan was already among the failed states.
There is a danger that the state of South Sudan is already beginning as a failed state.
I am firmly convinced that Europe has a great responsibility towards this region.

Given the colonial past of the countries there, the European Union's common foreign policy, in cooperation with the UN and the African Union, is called upon to take action here, and it can prove itself here as well.
This is not just about money, but also about supporting the fragile, emerging civil society.

And we must negotiate toughly with those who hold the fate of the country in their hands, namely the tribal leaders and the leaders of the military groups, so that they do not disappoint the hopes of their people in the country.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I am very grateful to my colleague Mr Bartolozzi for having made Mongolia the subject of a debate in the European Parliament with his initiative to table this question.
While the former Soviet states of Central Asia are now discussed in Parliament from various perspectives, Mongolia and its situation have only received very limited attention here.
It was Mongolia, quite wrongly, that as a state of the former communist bloc, was relatively quick to take advantage of its independence and embarked on a path towards democratising its society.

As early as 1992, the Mongolians adopted a democratic constitution, and since then, several elections have taken place, which, according to observers, have generally had a democratic and correct course, which is far from being a matter of course for the states in this region.

The Mongolian government has been trying for several years to combat corruption by law, and in 2010, it imposed a moratorium on the death penalty, something that even some major democratic countries have not yet managed to achieve.
Nevertheless, the three million inhabitants of this large country, dominated by extreme climatic conditions, are suffering from the consequences of an ongoing transformation process.
Thus, a rural population that still lives predominantly in a nomadic fashion is crowding into the few cities that are not prepared for this in terms of infrastructure.
The country's mineral resources are not extracted in an environmentally friendly manner.
Energy problems complicate civil and economic life.
Sandwiched between its large neighbors Russia and China, Mongolia is at risk of becoming even more dependent on these countries than it already is.

Mongolia's efforts and successes in democratizing its societyand here I see the glass as half full rather than half emptyshould be recognized, as they are exemplary for the region and demonstrate what is possible despite a difficult past.
Mongolia should continue to receive our support, not only through aid programs, but also by the European Union being directly present in the Mongolian capital with an

I take the representation as a sign that the fate of Mongolia is not indifferent to us Europeans and that European interests will no longer be represented by the embassy in Beijing. One more sentence, please.
I am very disappointed that the Conference of Presidents was not prepared to lend additional emphasis to this concern by allowing the adoption of a parliamentary resolution.
But, dear colleague, of course I recognize this right.
I just assume, and I hope you also acknowledge the right, that the position of the Dutch government is not proclaimed ex cathedra, but is open to discussion in a multinational democracy.
I have absolute respect for Mr. Rtte, who is responsible for 2.7 increases in the EU budget
I have taken note of that, and I am pleased that you have listened to me attentively, because in this Parliament, the positions of all governments are openly discussed.
I didn't quite understand the meaning of your question, but what I thought I heard is that you also profess your commitment to democracy.
That is, after all, progress.
First, I reacted so excitedly because I am still upset that we were unable to get a joint resolution on security here, because the absolutization of a position was more important than unity.

Secondly, I explained at the time in the debate, and I will reiterate this now, that I too have learned and now see that we need to do more, exert more pressure, and show more initiative in the area of increased safety regulations for European nuclear power plants.
That is precisely why I am in favor of the joint resolution, and that is why I am in favor of supporting the Commissioner and not constantly attacking him.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as for the intermediate category, I would certainly have imagined other solutions at the outset, Mr Pieper, especially since the regions that currently have the highest claims and will no longer have them after 2013 will receive a transitional arrangement.
However, the discussion revealed that we need to take into account other regions that have been particularly affected by the crisis.
We are talking about 51 regions at present.
And given the large number of affected regions, it would be downright negligent not to establish an intermediate category.
Only in this way can a reliable framework be established for the responsible promotion of these regions, which must overcome development deficits through their own efforts.
Otherwise, the Pipa report reveals both a lot of light and a lot of shadow.

We criticise, among other things, the lack of a clear commitment to a much more decisive fight against poverty and consider the formulations contained herein, linking cohesion policy to conditionalities that force member states to implement reforms, to be unclear and open to very broad interpretation.
Point by point, cohesion policy must remain an instrument of social balance and solidarity, and this in all regions.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, internal regional cooperation is becoming increasingly important in the future.
Cross-border cooperation and macro-regional collaboration are extremely important in an increasingly interconnected Europe for achieving the 2020 goals.
Border regions still face special challenges today.

Cross-border concepts and projects in areas such as infrastructure, business cooperation, research collaboration, labor market development, and further education are the driving force behind large parts of the European Union.
We need clear and simplified structures for the management of interregional projects.
Different national requirements among project partners often make cooperation and the realization of concrete sustainable projects more difficult.
It is an important step that the PIPE report includes the demand to increase the proportion for interregional cooperation under Objective 7 to 7, and I would like to strongly support this.
Madam President, esteemed Commissioner, dear colleagues, after nearly three years of intensive work, after well over 3 amendments, after countless conversations and discussions,

After the most difficult technical negotiations and political trilogues, it is now up for a vote: the political package, the major compromise between the European Parliament and the Council of Ministers on the future labeling of food products.
This regulation aims to provide consumers with more and better information about food products, enabling them to make informed purchasing decisions.
But that's not all. The European food industry is also expected to benefit.
The goal is legal certainty, deregulation, and better legislation.
This is particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, and it is important to know that the food sector in the European Union consists of over 80% of SMEs.
At the same time, this labeling must be suitable for every food and every non-alcoholic beverage, from basic foodstuffs to highly processed ready-made meals.
That is why mandatory labeling in traffic light colors is not possible, because this labeling is not suitable for staple foods.

Despite all the difficulties, despite all the political and ideological differences in Parliament, despite all the national egoisms of the member states, the compromise that has now been reached is still impressive.
Allergens will be recognizable at first glance.
The plant origin of vegetable oils is indicated.
There is origin labeling for pork, poultry, lamb, and goat meat.

For other products, a follow-up assessment will determine whether and how the origin can be indicated, for example for milk and dairy products, i.e., products that consist of a main ingredient, meat in processed form.
Imitation products, etc., must be clearly marked on the front, and the same applies to molded meat and molded fish, which are composed of and glued together from small pieces.
Nor may packaging create the impression that something is inside that is not actually there.
If a picture of fruit is on a yogurt, there must also be fruit in it, not just coloring and flavorings.
In addition, the mandatory declaration of the most important nutrients is always given per 100 grams or 100 milliliters for reasons of comparability.
Added water in meat must be labeled, the date of the first freezing in meat and fish, and many other details.
But most importantly, all information must be legible.

We have defined readability, we have established a minimum font size, and we have instructed the Commission to establish binding rules for additional factors, such as the contrast between the font and the background.
At the same time, we protect the craft industry from excessive costs and bureaucracy.
Unpre-packaged fresh produce must provide allergen information, but not the full nutritional information that can be determined through expensive analyses.

The Commission originally wanted this, but it would have destroyed our national and regional characteristics and specialties, it would have led to a European uniformity, and that's why we prevented it.
But now we have all reached an agreement, and the reputable consumer protectionists are quite satisfied with what has been achieved.

I would therefore like to thank all those involved, the shadow rapporteurs of the committee, and in particular Commissioner Dalli for his statements, which he will hopefully be making shortly and which will help to resolve the deadlock that has developed in our political discourse.

And I am particularly grateful to the Hungarian Presidency of the Council, which has achieved something that was almost no longer to be expected - almost the squaring of the circle - the agreement on this regulation.
Mr President, Commissioner, Polish Presidency, allow me to join in your thanks to the rapporteur, Mrs Ojala Sender.
As mentioned earlier, the Council had been blocking progress on this issue since 2008, until a compromise was finally reached under the Belgian presidency.
As mentioned, improved data exchange between member states will enable cross-border prosecution of various traffic offenses throughout Europe in the future.
The primary goal must be to increase road safety and reduce the number of traffic fatalities and injuries.

Together with Dieter Koch's own-initiative report on road safety, which makes a number of very specific proposals, this directive, with its repressive nature, can also contribute to better compliance with these rules.
I no longer need to go into the rules, as they have already been presented positively here.
The change in the legal basis from European transport policy to police cooperation has finally allowed the Council to draft a common position.
However, this means that some countries, such as Great Britain, Ireland, and Denmark, are excluded.
As a result, once again, not all European citizens are treated equally.
Citizens must be aware of the data protection rights they have.
We have tried to strengthen this aspect so that access to the collected data, its transmission and its storage are regulated as strictly as possible.
We also placed great importance on the information.
Mr President, although the current text does not fully meet the expectations of Parliament, I am nevertheless optimistic that this is a first step in the right direction.
I hope that in the coming years we can build on this foundation to take a step towards greater harmonization of European traffic regulations.
The revision clause added by Parliament would definitely allow such a procedure.
I deeply regret that this text has now become embroiled in the institutional conflict between the Council and Parliament over the correlation tables.
During the trialogues, we agreed to find an overall compromise on this issue with the joint declaration.
I would just like to remind you that the European Road Transport Union will be meeting tomorrow.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, my heartfelt thanks to my colleague Mrs Mac-Matthias for this report.

Many thanks also to the colleagues who have prepared the reports beforehand, Mrs. Mrkis and Mrs. Carvalho. This is a follow-up, and the day is approaching when we will not only be making political decisions.
We must not only state this here, but also prove that we are serious about the focus on research and innovation, which is the crucial question for the future viability of the European Union.
That is why I am very grateful that the representative of the Committee on Budgets also pointed out that adequate and good financial resources in this area are an important issue.

We will soon have to settle the dispute as to whether we have the strength to provide the necessary financial resources to ensure that this area of research and innovation truly becomes a central priority.
It is of central importance for the question of whether and how Europe will develop in the future.
By then, it will no longer be enough to deliver grand and small Sunday speeches; instead, facts will have to be presented.
Second point: We ourselves cannot avoid looking at whether we can use our resources more effectively, and this is very well highlighted in the report.
How do we achieve simplification in the procedure?
Where do we get the speed from?
We are making research funding more effective.
How can we create a stronger structure and greater simplification in the sometimes still complex maze of different research funding?
Sometimes less is more; few projects, but a lot of money invested, ultimately have a higher impact.
That is why I am grateful that we have once again taken a step forward in this report.

Of course, the European Research Council and the European Institute of Innovation and Technology will play a special role, and of course, the area of small and medium-sized enterprises is an important one.

I have read it again. We must also have a solution for the states that are not yet as advanced, while maintaining excellence as the principle, which must remain correct and imperative, and the only principle in the future.
And in this report, the idea of a possible competition also emerges, which could perhaps be used to promote new top research centers in neighboring regions.
And that is an important task that still needs to be solved.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, in view of the current extraordinary situation resulting from the financial, economic, and budgetary crisis, decisions at the European level should focus on urgent and essential issues.
This is the only way to restore the trust of our citizens in the seriousness of our actions.
My report is about the strategy to prevent endless human suffering, resulting from approximately 35 deaths annually and over
2.5 million often severe injuries as a result of road traffic accidents, as well as the prevention of associated economic damage of 130 billion euros annually.
The number of deaths alone is equivalent to that which would be mourned in the crash of 250 fully occupied medium-sized commercial airplanes.
What wouldn't we do to prevent that?
The costs of accident consequences significantly exceed the annual total budget of the European Union.
That is why I am sure that it is appropriate for us to take sustainable action in this area.

Thanks to the constructive cooperation of all shadow rapporteurs and many of my fellow Members, we have succeeded for the first time in this report to develop a unified, holistic, coherent approach to improving road safety.
It takes into account the contents of the UN Road Safety Charter 2010 as well as the contents and objectives of the road safety work of the EU member states and broader circles of civil society.
Firstly, it includes ambitious, yet realistic goals for the period up to 2020, and the SEERUM vision for the period beyond.
For example, the goal is to reduce the number of accident fatalities by 50% by 2020, the number of children killed by 60%, and the number of seriously injured people by 40%.
This is in the very best interest of every individual in our society, as well as our economy.
We recommend that the Member States break down the objectives and methods into their own territory and expect them to develop their own road safety action programmes.
Secondly, it specifies who is responsible for each activity and measure.
This is by no means just the European Union.

In the context of subsidiarity, the holistic approach means that Member States, regional or local authorities, and even individual road users must take responsibility in line with their duty to cooperate.
And thirdly, it includes how, i.e. with which instruments, activities, and measures the goals are to be achieved.
Legislative proposals at the European level are just one strategy.
We cannot and do not want to do without guidelines, recommendations, and assignments.
Particular attention has been paid to subsidiarity, which means that responsibilities and areas of competence have been clearly defined, even where they are shared.
We appreciate the Commission's diverse activities.

However, since they come from a wide variety of directorates-general, such as transport, economy, consumer protection, environment, communication, research and development, internal market, and others, they are not always coherent, often uncoordinated, and sometimes even contradict each other.
This is why we propose the appointment of a road safety coordinator within the European Commission.
This sustainably avoids the establishment of a road safety agency, but greatly increases the efficiency of the European Commission.
Both the selection of measures and their evaluation require a scientifically grounded approach based on comparable, high-quality data, definitions, and statistics.
We therefore call for, among other things, a harmonised analysis of injury and accident causes, as well as EU-wide data exchange while maintaining a high level of personal data protection.
Six main fields of action were identified.
They concern humans as road users, traffic regulations, vehicles, infrastructure, their intelligent networking, and the special consideration of vulnerable road users.
I request approval for tomorrow.
Madam President! We should focus on urgent and essential issues in traffic safety.
I am very convinced of this, and in my view, this primarily concerns the two biggest attention-distractors in traffic: alcohol and excessive speed.
The European Union also needs to have something to say about this and not just propose technical measures, which in my opinion are good but far from sufficient.
The lack of attention, the problem of inattentive drivers, is particularly dramatic, especially in cities.
That's why the speed has to be reduced here.
I was very pleasantly surprised that there was a broad majority in favor of recommending Tempo 30.

must be given special consideration, and that is included, and I think it is important and good that vulnerable road users are finally being brought into focus, and I hope that these measures will finally be implemented.
That seems pointless to me, but I would like to extend an invitation to you.
I have never seen him in the discussions about Rio or about other major global conferences, but I have always heard him speaking here in the plenary.
I would really like to ask you, Mr. Colleague, to come to the committee!
Engage with us, submit your proposals, and we will continue to discuss the statement with you.
And the contribution to the discussion you just made, we can't really do anything with that.
Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your introductory remarks.
However, these general statements are not an answer to the questions that were asked.
Because the questions are aimed at ensuring that we quickly arrive at results.
The industries that we want to exempt from these additional burdens or where we want to establish fair conditions need planning security.
We therefore need decisions soon.
We need swift decisions, reliable decisions and also clear statements from the Commission.
This process has been going on for a very, very long time.

We all knew that this was a very complicated procedure that we were embarking on, but back then, in the compromise on the Emissions Trading Directive, we also said, "We're doing this with the Emissions Trading Directive."
Only on the condition that the industries in Europe, which are thereby excessively burdened, can experience relief, because otherwise they cannot compete with other areas of the world.
And I expect that what was the basis for the deal back then, the basis for the decision in Parliament, with the Council, with the Commission, will also be implemented in this way.

I'm a bit concerned that along the way, the circle of those affected is getting smaller, that people are becoming more and more narrow-minded in their perspective, that they are excluding more and more areas.

But it's not just about steel, it's about aluminum, you know that, it's about many other areas of chemistry, etc. And that what was the political basis for the decision back then is simply not being implemented in reality.
Commissioner, you rightly pointed out that the situation for industry in Europe has not become easier since this decision, but rather more difficult.
We have a completely new situation, we have a much more competitive environment.
We are all fighting for this and are saying in Sunday sermons that industry is a very important area for the future development of Europe.
Yesterday we heard wise speeches.

I expect the Parliament - I believe - that what was agreed back then will also be implemented now, and this for the benefit of the industries, not the industries, but the people who work in these companies, the jobs and thus also the future opportunities for Europe.
Do you know of any example that would actually justify the effort of spending many millions, indeed billions, to develop these body scanners?
Are there examples that prove that this has increased safety?
Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the Council representative for the very clear description of the current situation.
We have constantly heard in this debate that it is about improving the situation for working women who have to decide for a child.
In my opinion, the directive is too focused on increasing maternity protection to 20 weeks.
But do we really believe that the decision to have a child can be reduced to 20 weeks of maternity leave?

As a mother of three children, I am well aware that comprehensive concepts and good offers for families are necessary to positively influence the decision to have a child and to establish equal opportunities for women.
The present draft of the guidelines does not do justice to the diverse, and in some cases very good, proposal and overall concepts in some Member States.
We need flexible solutions that are tailored to the situation in the member states and societies and the resulting needs of families.
Maximum demands and wishful thinking do not lead to a solution here.
That is why we must first develop a solid and realistic basis for negotiations here in Parliament.
And the comprehensive protection of mothers and the well-being of children have the highest priority there.
This can be ensured in different ways with different models.
Those who want to get somewhere by charging headfirst into a wall won't necessarily reach their destination faster.
A lack of willingness to compromise does not open doors or build bridges.
A moderate proposal would be a better solution and provide more maternity protection to move forward here.

I believe that we really need to look for a new approach, based on the Commission's draft directive, to significantly improve maternity protection for women and also protection for children in their first months of life, with more flexibility for different concepts in individual Member States.
This does not work with the draft that is before us today, which certainly did not have the broad majority support, as some colleagues have tried to make clear today.

I would like to see a bit more flexibility and a bit more realism here, and a bit of a better look at what the member states have already achieved today, without questioning our fundamental demands for that.
Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to make a few comments on the tax agreement between Germany and Switzerland, as others have already done.
Instead of putting a stop to tax evasion, which would be sensible, and instead of plugging the loopholes for tax evaders, they have produced a Swiss cheese with large holes.
The planned transition period of five months gives tax evaders plenty of time to transfer money from Switzerland to other tax havens.
Since foundations and trusts are not covered by the agreement, it is also sufficient to convert the assets stored in Switzerland into foundation assets.
The relevant forms are available at Swiss banks.
The tax authorities in Germany recently received information about several tax evaders who are hiding their assets in Switzerland.
The agreement now grants these individuals amnesty, and the tax investigators are no longer allowed to use the information they have.
What kind of agreement is this that chains the tax negotiations?
A promotional video for Swiss banks states accordingly about this agreement: "In the future, customers will benefit even more from the values of the Swiss financial center."

This agreement is obviously lacking not only the necessary coordination at the EU level, but it also contradicts the EU's efforts to increase transparency in tax matters, to make tax collection more efficient in the member states, and above all to combat and prevent tax fraud.
Therefore, in our view, this cannot be acceptable.
We support this agreement and we ask the EU to also stand up against it if necessary.
Mr President, thank you very much. In accordance with the rules of procedure of our House and in consultation with the groups, I request the referral of this work back to the committees.
Madam President, I am pleased that we have succeeded in getting a sustainable, effective directive off the ground with Roberta Angelilli's report, and I would like to thank her for that.
The directive represents a significant step in the fight against child abuse.
However, we must not lose sight of one thing: the vast majority of crimes still occur within children's immediate social environment.
The perpetrators are found in family schools and circles of acquaintances.
And here we are still at the beginning of our educational work.

That is why our children need to be empowered - strong enough to have the courage to confide in a trusted person in an emergency, but also strong enough to recognize dangers such as grooming when using the internet.
We must therefore work together to ensure that media literacy plays a greater role in the education of our children.
Education is of utmost importance here, as many teachers and parents are unaware of what their children can do with computers or mobile phones.
And I believe there is a great need to catch up.

It is therefore to be welcomed that the present report also places great emphasis on prevention, since the authorities, as well as schools and families, must do everything in their power to prevent such heinous crimes from occurring in the first place.
As a result, the EU also needs better negotiation strategies with third countries, such as the USA and Russia.

And pages stored outside the EU can only be deleted effectively and quickly if we also work closely with these countries in the search for the perpetrators and jointly send out a clear signal to respect children's rights against sexual abuse.
Once the perpetrator has been apprehended, the legislator has unfortunately often been surprisingly lenient, suspending the majority of crimes on probation.
In future, the severity of the offence will be taken into greater account here.
Overall, however, it is important that the public debate continues, as the topic has a wide range of dimensions.

Prevention, victim protection, technical development, as well as extinguishing before blocking, legal proceedings, education, and intensive scientific documentation of the facts must continue to be advanced even after tomorrow's vote.
The fact is that we must by no means fold our arms and do nothing.
Rather, we must take on the responsibility to act, each and every one of us, and ensure prevention and education.
Mr President, for years, the volume of the EU budget has remained at approximately the same level.
The EU's tasks have constantly expanded, and the financial requirements have increased significantly.
Thus, necessary new institutions have been created for financial market supervision.
However, in order for these institutions to effectively carry out their tasks, they need to be well-funded.
As a result of the financial and banking crisis, the economic weaknesses of some EU member states have become undeniable.
To strengthen the economy of these countries, a comprehensive economic stimulus program would be necessary.
Some economic experts even speak of the need for a Marshall Plan for the crisis-ridden EU countries.
And secondly, the EU does not need austerity programs that destroy growth, but rather a growth-promoting spending program that secures jobs and income for workers and young people in the EU.
But what is the Council doing in this situation?
It shortens the Commission proposal, which already falls far short of what is needed.

If a reasonable increase in the budget is not feasible in the current political climate, then Parliament and the Commission should do everything in their power to at least prevent the cuts proposed by the Council.
Madam President! Madam President! Madam President! Madam President! Madam President! Madam President!

Do we want a Union where the glue is truly also the understanding that we say, "It is not indifferent to us whether people have to live in poverty in any country, a member state of the European Union"?
Do we share the responsibility to fight against poverty and social exclusion?
Or do we opt for a union as outlined by colleagues from the far-right group in this Parliament?

Sometimes I believe that with the attitude of the member states and especially some governments of these member states, we are dangerously close to this vision of a European Union as formulated by the right-wing extremists.
They just don't need to do anything together, use any common tools, set any common indicators, and use vague wording whenever possible.
The Third Report makes this very clear on many points, and I believe that we need to become much stronger in this area.
What we need is an immediate halt to the sell-off of public goods, the sell-off of social security systems.
We need social and ecological minimum standards.
As winter approaches, it cannot happen again that people end up on the streets, are evicted, and ultimately freeze to death because of rising energy prices.
Here we share a common responsibility, the responsibility as the European Union.
We must stand up for that, and not for this nationalist nonsense that we have heard from the right wing.

What advice would we have given to our colleagues in 1931 or 1938, when there was a depression, when the financial markets had already undermined the democracies and when they were heading towards wars?
I think two things would be necessary - two emergency measures. We need something like a transitional government.
Do what you need to do quickly, don't let yourself be slowed down, regulate every product, every institution, and every player like this
Mrs Merkel has said. But a transitional government alone, which enforces the fiscal emergency program, cannot have a future if there is no democratic emergency program.

That means in this case, of course, we need a new European community, of course, we need other treaties, of course, we need a system that works, but it only gains legitimacy if there are popular votes.

And we need to start campaigning now because the situation has become so dramatic that a complete change of thinking is necessary before the right-wingers, before the national dividers, regain control over something that has already been built up.
Madam President, there is no doubt that this esteemed House is committed to transparency and openness towards the citizens.
Of course, my EPP group does that too.
But the present report goes far beyond the actual goal.
Existing legislation and interinstitutional agreements are ignored, and the protection of competitive processes, sensitive and personal data is disregarded.
This is a massive violation of data protection, which we otherwise always advocate for.
Should we now give up the privacy of the world public?
This is precisely the danger with the present report, because administrative procedures and decisions, which also include personnel issues, for example, are to be published.
The same applies to the protection of trade secrets and sensitive information in the context of approval procedures, court proceedings and competition proceedings.

With its vague, unclear, and overly broad definitions, the report allows public access to such documents as well, since a document is defined as any data or content that is in any way related to the policies, measures, or decisions of all EU bodies and institutions.
This also largely includes preparatory, confidential and secret documents, as well as all related information.
And so this definition encompasses not only documents, but also information.
Information from ongoing interinstitutional procedures, such as informal trilogue negotiations, must also be published.
Do you know, Mr. Rapporteur, what that really means?

It means public access to the proceedings, it means public influence on the decision-making process, then we might as well just bring in the lobbyists and let them negotiate. But does the citizen really want that?
I can't imagine that.
In addition, documents related to non-legislative procedures, measures of internal administrative organizations, etc., are also to be published. Where is the public interest in that?
Or would it not rather hinder our work?
I think this report is not in the interests of our citizens.
It would bring about a flood of useless information.
He would make our work impossible, and above all, as you heard from the Commissioner, he is not acceptable to the other institutions because he violates the existing rules and laws.
You know that, Mr. Rapporteur, and basically, you are working against further transparency and against the citizens.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with such an important and comprehensive topic as the White Paper on the future of transport, there is always a great risk of ending up with a Christmas tree, where everyone tries to accommodate their two or three preferred topics.
When you look at the result that will be put to a vote tomorrow, you can undoubtedly congratulate our rapporteur Matthieu Grosch.

He has managed to develop a good, coherent and manageable result from several hundred proposed amendments, which sets the main focus for the future of transport on safety, environmental protection, energy and technology.
I expressly welcome the fact that such important issues as the social, health, and labor law conditions of employees are adequately mentioned here.

This is particularly important in view of the impending shortage of skilled workers in the transport sector, which must be actively addressed if bottlenecks in well-trained professionals are to be prevented in the future.
further opening up of cabotage in road transport only on the condition that social dumping and unfair conditions are prevented.
I also welcome the fact that the aspect of improving road safety is given an important place here.
The safety on our roads is an issue that we must continue to address in the future.
I have a more critical view of other points.
That's why I would have liked a statement on the Modern Shift, where more traffic would be moved from the roads to the railways and waterways.
And for this reason, I do not think the discussion about the Gigaliner is the best solution for more sustainability.
Further liberalization of the railway sector and the opening up of national passenger transport should also be critically evaluated and reconsidered.
There are still technical harmonization and fair competition conditions to be resolved here.
But as I said, in this report I hope that the expectations of Parliament will not remain a pious wish list, but that a goal will be achieved by 2020 and our proposals will have become a reality.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is only 20 years ago that the Central Asian states gained their state independence as a result of the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Coming from a dictatorship, the establishment of democratic and rule-of-law structures in these states remains a lasting challenge.
Nevertheless, these states are important trading partners of the EU and its member states due to their wealth of mineral resources and raw materials.
It is therefore only logical to regulate the EU's relations with these states within the framework of partnership and cooperation agreements.
Partnership and cooperation agreements are intended to promote collaboration and lead to cooperative action, but not to unilateral stigmatization.
Child labor, and especially forced child labor, is unfortunately still a widespread problem in many countries around the world that needs to be combated.

However, it should be noted that in many agriculturally dominated European regions, it was customary to extend the school holidays for children during harvest time and to give children from farming families the opportunity to help with the harvest, which no one would today describe as forced labor.
2. However, if there are signs of child labor in Uzbekistan during the cotton harvest, consequences must be drawn.

The same consequence must then apply to all other countries where child labor still exists, including those where we pursue economic interests of a completely different magnitude, such as in India or China.
We should not apply double standards here.

Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I can only join those in these ranks who have already offered their congratulations to the Presidency-in-Office of the Council.
In difficult times, they were not only an honest broker, but also a European broker.

I think it was very comforting to feel that in these difficult times, when we have political currents in a number of member states that suggest to people that one could achieve more alone than together.
They have placed the commonalities at the forefront.
It was also very refreshing to see that you have also found approval among the people in Poland in the domestic political debate with this clear European agenda.
It wasn't exactly easy in this context.
And also for that, the highest respect for what you have achieved.
In the past six months, we have been able to make significant progress, particularly in the area of financial market regulation.

If I may single out one area of focus that I was able to negotiate myself, namely the issue of regulation for short selling and uncovered credit default swaps on government bonds, where the Commission has not dared to propose strict regulations, where everyone has told us
