Member states were told that they would not prevail, and yet, thanks to the Polish presidency of the Council, it was possible to sanction a highly speculative instrument and, where necessary, to ban it in order to contribute to greater stability in the financial markets.
I would like to express my sincere thanks to your Finance Minister and the Secretary of State, who have brought this about through a laborious discussion process between Parliament and the Council.
This is an example of what can be achieved together in the interests of security and stability in Europe.
Mr President, thank you very much for that.
Since yesterday, the new surveillance mechanism for economic imbalances has been in effect.
In the meantime, the specific content regulations are also available.
Which developments does the Commission now consider dangerous, and which economic problems does it want to see corrected?
The Commission considers an annual increase in unit labor costs in eurozone countries of more than 3% to be a problem.
A threshold value for falling wages, on the other hand, is not planned.
Cheap, dear Commission, does not automatically mean good.
It is not enough to train the member states to achieve prosperity at the expense of their trading partners.
Without investments in education, health, and energy efficiency, we can exploit our workers to the bone, but we won't be writing any economic success stories that way.
Another example from the Scoreword: The loss of export market shares should be reviewed and sanctioned.
That's nonsense!
As global trade increases, Europe's share statistically speaking inevitably decreases.
The indicator therefore penalizes countries that are already integrated into global trade.
That is why we believe the Commission should withdraw this basket and subject it to a complete overhaul.

Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by joining in the thanks to our rapporteur and everyone who worked on the report, because it is not routine, even if one has to deal with competition policy for the fortieth time on the basis of a Commission report.
I would like to thank the Commissioner very much, because 2010 was the year when you were fully responsible for competition policy for the first time, for the very comprehensive presentation.
However, I would like to express the hope, and you have just addressed this in your contribution, that we will see some progress in the area of subsidies, public subsidies, in the banking sector.
should have come, because now, due to the new stress test by the European Banking Authority, a new capitalization in the banking sector is once again being demanded.
I do not believe that all of this contributes to the stability of the banking system, when on the one hand we still have a large number of unresolved or unfinished old cases.
We have, and in fact, new cases have already arisen as a result of the pressure being built up to increase the equity ratio, particularly in the area of private banks.

So, here is my truly urgent request, Commissioner, to reach a swift solution that also contributes to stabilizing the banking sector in such a way that it can also meet the challenges in the international environment.
The second major issue, diffusion control, will continue to be a pressing concern for us in the coming years.
Here, too, I can only urge the Commission to continue along the clear and transparent path it has taken so far in the context of merger control.

I believe that it is in the interest of all parties involved, especially consumers, that we ensure in the area of merger control that competition is possible even in larger or different structures - I don't want to evaluate that.
With that in mind, I'd like to thank everyone who has worked on this, and I hope, Commissioner, that we will soon reach a solution, particularly in the banking sector.

Commissioner, you have just hit the nail on the head by jointly acknowledging that we are capable of launching a third industrial revolution in Europe if we realize that we can seize the opportunities for sustainability as an industrial opportunity.
Then you also spoke of resources, and that brings to mind a thought that I have completely forgotten about today.
I forgot about the human resources in my office.
And Mrs. Philipp, allow me to say that you have worked like a horse, with wonderful results; you were a key person in this matter.
I would like to express my gratitude for that.
Mr President, in order to exercise freedom of speech in Parliament, you also need a functioning microphone system.
My button for turning on the microphone has broken.
I would like to request that a technician restores freedom of speech.
Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, it amazes me that we always have to remind ourselves what is actually meant by structural and cohesion policy.

Cohesion and structural policy is one of the central policy areas of the European Union and, by definition, it is intended to strengthen economic and social cohesion within the Community, while promoting growth and employment in underdeveloped regions in particular.
The necessity and success of cohesion and structural policy have been proven, especially in the years of the crisis.
The situation looks even more difficult in many regions. As far as economic development is concerned, these funds would not be available.
The implementation of Structural Funds support is carried out on the basis of operational programmes - as already mentioned - in which the support strategy of the respective region is described.
The European Union, Member States and regions are working together in partnership here, thereby creating genuine European added value.
The success of cohesion and structural policy is also based on the reliability of the programmes and the funds made available and allocated.

That is why I am very surprised when Member States, and also the Commission, as we are now seeing, repeatedly attempt to use the Structural Funds as a piggy bank for all sorts of current policy approaches.

This does not do justice to the sense and purpose of cohesion policy and, moreover, creates uncertainty for the actors in the regions who are already working on achieving the goals on the basis of long-term strategies and contracts.
Certainly, combating youth unemployment and promoting economic growth are important goals.

However, this will only be achieved if the partnership-based cooperation between the regions, the Member States and the Commission is maintained and the actors in the regions are involved and remain involved.
Because only they have the knowledge of what needs to be done in their regions.
Cohesion and structural policy is the unifying, partnership-based, and solidarity-driven bond of action between the individual policy levels in the European Union.
It makes the solidarity of Europe visible on the ground in the regions, and it should not be abandoned lightly due to political quick fixes.

Mr President, Commissioner, I support the compromise found in Kodzko, which aims to strengthen the negotiating power of dairy farmers vis--vis the processing industry, even though I am aware that it does not solve all the problems currently facing dairy farmers in some Member States.
As early as 50 years ago, Commissioner Mantzold had provided preferential measures for the creation of producer associations as part of the CAP.
In my country, Luxembourg, the dairy industry is the main pillar of our agriculture due to the high proportion of grassland.
Our agriculture and our farmers have long understood that the best solution is to join together in a cooperative that handles the processing of milk itself.
Five member states voted against the compromise in the Council for precisely this reason, as it does not meet its requirements as a soft lending instrument.

The European Commission has the right of initiative when it comes to legislative proposals, which is why I would like to urge you to submit a legislative proposal to the Council and the European Parliament in 2012 to correct this obvious and costly error in the system.

A linear reduction in the superlevy by 2015, which is applied to each kilo of milk delivered, or the abolition of the fat correction, could at least mitigate the negative effects of the expiring regulation without harming the unaffected member states.
However, the present milk package is also intended as a final report by the High Level Group, which aims to ensure a smooth transition away from milk quotas.
It is astonishing that milk quotas are not mentioned at all in this report.
Young and ambitious farmers in Luxembourg and four other member states are trying to prepare for the liberalization of the milk market and expand their production.
If you want to compete on the global market after 2015, you can only do so by purchasing additional quotas now, just before the end of the milk quota system.
This is an enormous additional and unnecessary capital expenditure that puts them at a disadvantage compared to their counterparts in 22 member states.
Question: Are you aware that we have had common bonds for a long time?
And that the resolution does not speak about Eurobonds in general, but about very different options.
And are you aware that not all of these options require a contract amendment?
I find it questionable that you have once again isolated generalities about Eurobonds here.
We should not give up the level of detail that we have achieved with Mrs Gulaar's good proposal.
I would like to hear a bit more differentiation in your statements and am curious to hear what you have to say about it.
But it is time, I will only say very briefly, dear colleague Gouault, this is not an evaluation I have made here.
I just want to point out that the last Italian government bond before Italy joined the euro was yielding 10%.
And there was no outcry in Italy, and no one said that other countries should now take over.
It was self-evident that one had to pay high interest rates.

And now suddenly, because we have had ten years of low interest rates and have become excessively indebted, because money has become cheap for investments as well as for public spending, we want to extend the use of Eurobonds.
This is a trap we can't get out of, and I stand by that.
Mr President, Commissioner, your answer has really rather disappointed me.

They obviously want to stick to the old system, where complicated negotiations have to be conducted per country and where, in turn, no further access to literature is granted, meaning that no additional opportunities are created for the blind and visually impaired.
This is all the more sad for me because the European Union is now blocking progress in the VIPO, while all the other or many other contracting parties would be willing to move forward.
A huge opportunity is being missed here.

They are not fighting for more rights for copyright holders here, but against people who should be guaranteed equal access to cultural goods under the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and that they can also participate fully in these cultural goods.
I appeal to you: please dismantle barriers and agree to a binding contract.

Mr President, the discussion here in this House shows that we actually represent the entire spectrum, on the one hand those who want no restrictions at all, and on the other hand those who associate every form of immigration with the threat of mass immigration.
These are the two extremes within this house.
I believe that family reunification must be considered with great reason and rationality.
On the one hand, there are indeed problems in member states where measures are taken that are too restrictive.
Because family reunification cannot be burdened with so many obstacles that in the end no one can be reunited.
On the other hand, it is entirely justified that member states demand language skills, that they demand integration, but also that they demand a willingness to integrate within a state.
Secondly, the Member States naturally have the right, and we should not push these problems to one side, to articulate the problems that arise in the context of family reunification.

If countries like Greece or Malta, or even Romania or Italy, are no longer allowed to articulate the problems they have in this context, then I no longer know if we are democratic if we simply ignore the problems.
I don't think we need another directive just yet
We need to. I think we should discuss the problems carefully and then think about how we can eliminate them.
The constant re-production of guidelines does not lead to an improvement of the guidelines and their implementation.
We currently have some implementation problems.

However, I also fully understand that we first need to address the fact that we should not create a new directive and add something to it before we have thoroughly discussed the issues of the old directive in any way.
I am in favor of listening to the member states and at the same time respecting the fundamental right to family reunification.
And if one does this with reason and understanding, then I also believe that we will find a good path.
Mr President! Pomil, Sanim, Pomilich! Remember before you think, advises the Polish aphorist Stanisaw Jergelec, and this recommendation would do us good in this Parliament at times.

A few weeks after the resolution on the Central Asia strategy was passed in this house, in which the Central Asian states were given failing grades, strike events are now also taking place in Jena Ozen.
reflecting on the situation in Kazakhstan, without waiting for the results of the ongoing investigations, which are being carried out with international participation.
As much as the dead are to be lamented, and the injured and detained have the right to an investigation of the events that followed, the background remains unclear.

Even Vladimir Koslov, chairman of the unregistered opposition party ALGA, thought so. This was a group of other people. The unrest is not in the interest of the strikers, because it only provides a reason to take violent action against them.
The Central Asia expert Arkady Dubnov also suggested that it was not impossible that parts of the Kazakh opposition living abroad would also get involved.
On the other hand, it could well suit someone in the Kazakh capital Astana to maintain the tensions.
After all, the power elite in Kazakhstan are already fighting over the succession of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.
We had the opportunity to speak with the Kazakh opposition in the presence of the Kazakh ambassador here in Parliament.

UN Special Envoy Miroslav Jenscha announced today that he is impressed by the Kazakh government's observation of the events by Jana Ozen, and that it is necessary to uncover the true background of UNRWA.
We should take the Khazarian authorities at their word, judge them by their actions, but not jump to reflexive pre-condemnation.
As I understand it correctly, the statement you made today is: Yes, the Commission is fighting for the continuation of the food program for the most needy people in the European Union.
She will do everything to bring concrete ideas to the table in the foreseeable future, A where the program will be exactly located, B how financing will be carried out.
I believe this is urgently necessary, and I think that we share the responsibility of ensuring that this food program actually becomes a reality.
Not because I consider it the ultima ratio, but because in my view it is a signal to show people that we still have a basic sense of the necessary solidarity with those in need.

of the living conditions of people in the European Union who unfortunately have not been able to participate in development and who have become the first and greatest victims of the way the European Union has dealt with the crisis.
I am thinking here of Greece, I am thinking of Spain, I am thinking of other countries where exactly what we do as the European Union primarily affects the poorest of the poor.
We are setting an example, but unfortunately it is no longer enough.
I therefore think that it is urgently necessary that we do not only consider the 18 million people in the European Union who are currently dependent on food aid.

It is not about making resources available, but rather that we must prioritize this issue. We want to continue to place the fight against poverty at the top of our own agenda, or even place it there for the first time.
We have not conveyed this signal so far.

But in my view, this is the crucial point if we want to make progress here and if we also want to gain the trust of the citizens of our European Union that we are truly creating a social and solidaristic Union.
In that sense, you have our support.
We ourselves, dear colleagues, are also called upon to do something to ensure that the governments that have been reaping the benefits so far must abandon this attitude.
I think that's also a piece of self-commitment for us.
Mr President, esteemed colleague Dohl, I have listened to you attentively.
What you are proposing, namely to introduce a growth test for all expenditure in parallel with the subsidiarity test, means in effect to narrow down the objectives to growth.
I would like to know how you reconcile that with the principles of a Christian Democratic faction, which surely still recognizes goals beyond growth.
It should be common knowledge that the economy cannot give birth to children, raise them, or provide them with a life in an intact natural environment.
This suggests that the priorities need to be changed by the Commission and also by the Council, that they need to be reconsidered.
As a group, we will carefully examine whether what you presented this morning actually corresponds to a change in priorities.
Until now, the motto has been: First the economy, which needs functioning financial markets.
And that was initially what it was all about: to restructure public finances, reduce debt, and keep the markets calm.
And Mr. Daul, who unfortunately is not present right now, I just wanted to say that I would take the same stance as Georges Machait.
Although I didn't understand his answer, I would disagree with him.
I think the measures that have been introduced were simply wrong.
They were not right, it was not right, to focus solely on the economic recovery and completely ignore what was happening to the people.
It was not right to prioritize the stability of the euro above all else and to say, "What happens to the people is completely irrelevant to us."
But it has to be the other way around. First, it's about the people, and then we can continue to talk about euro stabilization.

The speculative attacks on Spain pushed the interest rates for Spanish government bonds above 6 percent and more, bringing them close to the interest rate level at which other countries such as Greece, Portugal, and Ireland sought support from the bailout fund.
The austerity policy, imposed on the member state by the EU, the ECB, and also by the IMF, with drastic reductions in all types of public spending,
The reduction of wages and pensions, the increase in VAT and much more has indeed placed the burden on citizens and has not prevented a new spiral of austerity.
Rigorous cuts in state spending exacerbate the downturn, drive up the national debt ratio, and this must be our shared understanding.
When Mr Draghi recently said that the European social model is finished, I am pleased, Mr Barroso, that you say 'No, we in the Commission do not think like that'.
Then I also expect you to go to Greece, to send your people to Greece, to Portugal, to Ireland, and to register exactly what happens there.
What happens to the people who currently have to fight for their survival?
What is happening or what are we doing together to finally interrupt this suicide spiral that has begun, especially in the most affected debtor countries?
We can't just stand by and watch this happen.
And we are of no benefit from socio-political programs that will work at some point in the future, when other measures have already taken effect.
We must act now Where are your objectives from the 2020 strategy to combat poverty?
What has become of the European Poverty Platform?
It has been set aside.
That was before the crisis.
But now, in the midst of the crisis, people need help, they need support, and they need the European Union to take action.
You don't need empty promises.
We need concrete ideas about what should be done now.
If you do that, you will receive support from my group.
Support all those who have recognized the signs of the times within the Commission and want to change things.
But please don't just carry on like this and say "It will"
But things will not improve if things continue like this. I urge you to present a concrete project, a concrete program, on how we can now actively help the people in the affected countries.
Do something about it!
We will have to do this in our countries so that the funds for the ESF 2013 or 2014 to 2020 or for the other programmes are not blocked or cut.
It is important that the member states fulfill their responsibilities.
Mr President, esteemed colleagues, the current state of public finances and the economy in Europe leaves no room for a fairy tale about tax policy.
The situation in the Council is quite simple: little progress is being made on tax policy proposals.
Why?
Because some countries are against further tax cooperation.
They benefit from aggressive tax planning, they are tax havens themselves.
And the treaties clearly state unanimity in tax matters.
That is why the EU Commission has repeatedly suffered setbacks with its proposals in the past.
They are watered down, they are not moving forward as with the interest rate guideline, and in the case of newer proposals, nothing ambitious has been suggested out of deference.

Therefore, Mr. Schmetter, I ask you to change the strategy, propose strict measures, and then focus on enhanced cooperation to end the deadlock in the Council, as I know your job is not an easy one in this regard.
Mr President, the proposal before us will certainly not prevent a state bankruptcy where it is likely to occur, even with the risk-sharing instruments.
But doing something is still better than doing nothing at all.
And extraordinary situations sometimes require extraordinary measures.

The budget and debt crisis in some states has led to such an extraordinary situation that important projects and measures within the framework of cohesion and structural policy can no longer be implemented because the banking sector is no longer available as a financier and private investors are no longer available.
I consider the proposal to create risk-sharing instruments for the continued funding of projects in structural policy to be an extraordinary measure.
Means of cohesion and structural policy that can be used to provide financial security for countries that want to use these division instruments, for ongoing projects.

I am very grateful to the rapporteur, Danuta Hbner, for her significant contribution to clarifying the Commission's proposal and for once again clearly outlining when and how these instruments should be used.
However, I also believe that these risk-sharing instruments must only be due to the current situation and cannot set a precedent for the future funding period.
Mr President, our group supported the call for an amendment to the 2009 regulation on biometric passports, requiring a review after three years and the submission of four studies.
And this was also because she had repeatedly raised major concerns for data protection reasons and also regarding the verification of the usefulness of biometric data in travel passports.
The belief in perfect identification, the overestimation of this method, and what follows from it, as well as the underestimation of other links in the security chain, are truly problematic.
The handling of biometric data is still subject to this major misconception, namely the assumption that it is unchangeable and most trustworthy.
And that is not true at all.
These data are also modifiable over the course of a person's life.
In children, they look different than in old age.
And that is also why reliable and serious studies and conclusions drawn from them are necessary.
Counterfeiting continues apace.
We have now been able to determine,
As incidents in Great Britain and other countries repeatedly prove, the chips are not at all secure against misuse.
They are broken cheerfully and can cause lasting damage to those affected.
Standards within the EU are also extraordinarily diverse.
The error rate is very, very high, just like in France and the Netherlands.
And time and again, the question must be asked: what good are biometric data to us if documents are being forged and are in circulation?
So if one link in the chain is forged, the original documents are inconsistent, biometric data would not help us further.
The Chaos Computer Club in Germany needed only a few minutes to demonstrate a forgery.

To do this, the friends from the Chaos Computer Club needed the lid of a plastic bottle, a second-hand adhesive, a digital camera, and a bit of wood glue. In just a few minutes, they had cracked the chip. That's all there is to the supposed security.
We expect the Commission to present the studies and, of course, also the results and the consequences that can be derived from them.
Mr Rat, unfortunately, the Commission is not as adequately represented today as I would have wished, out of respect for Parliament.

As a representative from a region that is massively affected by the planned changes, namely the Eifel, after carefully following the debate, I am left wondering whether the unfortunately only marginally viable attempt

whether a standardization of the criteria for disadvantaged areas really meets the needs in these regions, especially since the necessary information is not available for a sensible and responsible decision.
Above all, I wonder whether a sufficient impact assessment was actually carried out.
To do justice to farmers, we need not only biophysical criteria, but also socio-economic criteria.

Therefore, I urge the Commission to reconsider this important aspect with the necessary time, detached from the overall package of the CAP reform, and above all after the necessary documents have been submitted and a careful analysis of the impacts has been carried out.
I do believe that we must work on this, in cooperation with the Asylum Support Office and the Greek authorities, to more quickly identify which persons who have come to Greece may actually be...

They can also be transferred to other countries in the European Union because, firstly, they can definitely never return to their home country and, secondly, they may also bring with them potential and qualifications that can be meaningful and goal-oriented for everyone.
However, essentially, it is also about helping the Greeks to facilitate registration and identification more quickly, in order to expedite the aid processes.

Returning those to their home country who neither have the qualifications nor the right to stay in Greece or the European Union, because they would actually have a chance to remain in their own home countries.
Mr President, Mr Minister, Commissioner, many thanks also to the rapporteur for her always very committed and exemplary work.
I can share much of the criticism that Sophie Infeld has expressed, support it, or have even partially supported it.
But then there always comes a point at which one must take responsibility.
And for the EPP, or for myself, I therefore also maintain that we must now deal with the realities and cannot retreat to ideological or theoretical positions.
The fact is, the USA has been collecting this PNR data for ten years, and there has not been a single complaint.
The fact is that we all do not want to stop data traffic, even if we hold a negative attitude towards it.
They had just carried that out.
The fact is that we do not want air traffic between Europe and the USA to come to a standstill.
And the fact is that the USA has a right to know who is coming into their country.
And the fact is, in my opinion, that the legal services have all told us verbally that this agreement is better than the other agreement and the alternatives.
That is why one must also take responsibility here.
And that's what we were elected for.
Responsibility for the citizens, whom one would otherwise leave alone with less protection and rights?
responsibility for the airlines, which would otherwise be left in absolute legal uncertainty, the Commissioner had also pointed out.
Responsibility also for the EU as a contracting party in matters of data protection and security, and also responsibility for a balanced relationship between security and data protection.
That is why, in summary, we are in favor of this agreement, even though it is not perfect, but we must consider the consequences of agreeing to this agreement.
If you want to better protect citizens and provide them with better data protection, you take on this responsibility and agree to this agreement.
Mr President, Commissioner, the statements you have given us have been very informative.
Thank you very much for that!

Figures sometimes say more than big words, and to date, the European Parliament - you also mentioned this - and the European Patent Office have granted nearly 2 patents for plants and almost 1,200 patents for animals, which were developed with and without the use of genetic engineering.
I would like to mention two outstanding examples: the approval of patents on genetically modified and selectively bred barley, which applies to the entire chain from seed to plant.
This is why our farmers, brewers, producers, and consumers are all affected.
And this example, in my opinion, shows a devastating extent of patenting.
Secondly, do not confuse the so-called Long Life tomato with their Long Life oil, which they use in their diesel engines.
This patent was obtained using a trick by the US corporation Arcadia, which bypassed the valid EU regulations.
It is not the Worden tomato that is patented, but its genetic material, specifically selected enzymes.

This shows the tricks being used here, and that, as you said, Commissioner, in the 1998 directive on biopatents, Article 4 clearly states that plant varieties and animal breeds a and b, which are essentially biological processes for the breeding of plants or animals, are not patentable.
We believe this definition needs to be more precise, it needs to be interpreted more accurately.
Technical procedures that are used to support conventional search should not lead to patentability overall.
We specifically do not patent life.
And we need a clear signal here for more ethics and more honesty in dealing with exhaustion, once again against the patentability of life throughout Europe.
Therefore, Commissioner, we demand a clear statement from the Commission that patents on breeding material and genetic resources are and will remain prohibited in Europe.
Secondly, we demand a clear stance on Article 4 of the Biopatent Directive: No patent on life.
And thirdly, Commissioner, on behalf of many farmers and breeders in Europe, we demand a clear establishment of the breeder and farmer privilege throughout all legislation.
Madam President, I would like to comment on the dismissal of Europol and Eurojust.
There is little, if anything, to claim from Europol here.
The annual financial statements reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects, and all underlying transactions are in accordance with regulations and therefore also lawful.
What is striking, however, is the high level of transfers in relation to the overall low costs incurred.
Europol attributes this to the move to a new headquarters, which is of course understandable.
But Europol says it will take further measures in the future to avoid such high transfers.
Furthermore, Europol intends to commit to monthly monitoring of budget execution starting in 2012.
I recommend that we follow up on this to see if it actually happens.
Against this background, I recommend granting Europol discharge.
Regarding Eurojust, the annual accounts also reflect the financial situation in 2010 in all material respects.
All transactions are also lawful and in accordance with regulations here.
But here too, high operating expenses were carried over to 2011.
According to Eurojust, this was mainly due to an organizational structure project, a new computer infrastructure, and data processing costs.
It is announced that all of this will be improved in the future, and that tender requirements will also be better adhered to.
I recommend that we also review this in the future and, above all, check whether all open positions will actually be filled in the future.
That has been improved.
But if these positions are not filled soon, we would almost have to consider cutting funds, and that would be negative for Eurojust.
I still recommend discharge. Thank you.
Madam President, most esteemed Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what should truly alarm and panic us is not just the sheer number of unemployed youth in Europe, but the trend of unemployment.
The number of young unemployed people rose by 26.5% between 2008 and 2011, notes the International Labour Organization.
It is this development that urgently requires measures. We are not only disconnecting an entire generation from the job market, we are disconnecting an entire generation from a livable future.
If we give young people the feeling of absolute uselessness, we should not be surprised that young people are turning away from this EU because they have no reasonable work and life prospects.

Commissioner, I urgently request that you ensure that decisive countermeasures are initiated. I already recognize some progress, but please make sure that the long-standing mental stagnation does not now turn into operational haste.

When I read that the Commission is launching a program under which young people applying abroad are now to receive financial support, then we are organizing a traveling circus that does not solve the problem.
And on the contrary, it becomes counterproductive, as technicians, doctors, engineers, and nursing staff are then lured away by richer states that are not in this crisis.

What is needed now, in this crisis that is the cause of this development, are offensive measures, namely the dismantling of this austerity madness that is having a negative impact on the economy in Europe.
We need a targeted growth policy, we need to strengthen domestic purchasing power, public investment in education, research, and alternative energies.
That would be the way.
By combining it with European funding, it would then be possible to actually develop an integrated concept that provides young people with a life perspective.
This youth unemployment is also incompatible with the nonsense of wanting to raise the retirement age for people to 70.
We need a different policy that gives young people access to the job market.
That's why I urgently ask, please!
Colleague, you just said that everything that would speak in favor of the financial transaction tax is speculation, and then you came up with very speculative examples yourself.

I would like to know from you what you think, in light of what you have said, about these investigations by the Commission and the Commission's study, which very, very clearly states that, up to now, far too little attention has been paid to the real economy's dependence on...

The financial markets have been informed that 95% of companies are by no means dependent on borrowing money and that it is indeed possible to reverse the negative growth effect that has been discussed so far by allocating corresponding growth incentives to public investments.
Is this just speculation for you, or would you say that such a well-founded, broad-ranging study by the Commission also has its justification and represents a strong argument?

Mr President, yes, ladies and gentlemen, the financial transaction tax is certainly not identical to the Tobin tax, which has been under discussion for many years, but I believe it incorporates essential elements of the Tobin tax.
It at least takes up the idea of involving the financial markets in taxation, taxing them and, above all, also involving them in the costs of the crisis.
I think that is a very important signal to the financial markets.
But this is also a very important signal to the citizens, to our voters.
In a whole series of member states, there were a whole series of actions, petitions, and written initiatives to politicians to finally introduce a financial transaction tax at the European level.
I think that with the majority that is emerging here, Parliament has achieved a great success with this report, with this tax.
Certainly, this is not enough to stabilize and limit the financial markets, as might be necessary, but it is a truly important step that has been taken.
I would like to expressly appeal to the council to take the voices of citizens, voters, seriously and to work towards this goal.
I hope that it will actually come to an introduction, that it will not be blocked in the Council due to the British position or other positions.
I think it is clear that the citizens of the European Union want this tax, and I think it is a great responsibility.

It is now up to the Council to take action, and I would like to use my speaking time to appeal to the Council to do everything in its power to ensure that this tax is actually implemented and becomes a reality.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that despite all the detailed issues that can be discussed and will be discussed further in the legislative process, we should be clear about one thing.
This must be clear: financial markets cannot function according to the model where banks pocket the profits when everything goes well, and taxpayers foot the bill when things go wrong.
And that is why it makes sense to subject financial transactions to a tax.
And it makes sense to do this across borders.

In Europe, or at least in the Eurozone, we will not have upheavals, but we will make a lasting contribution to achieving a stable financial center that generates what financial centers are actually intended for, namely, that companies

Having access to capital means that savers have the opportunity to put something aside or set it aside for retirement, and that the financial markets can once again fulfill the purpose for which they were created, namely to provide added value for the real economy.
What drove us into the financial crisis were products that created no value for the real economy.

That is why it makes sense to contribute through taxation to ensure that this is heavily punished, that it is sanctioned, that it is controlled in the sense that capital once again fulfills its purpose.
That is why I am advocating for this proposal to be adopted today by a large majority.
Mr President, the reform of the generalised system of preferences was indeed necessary.
It is good now that there are longer repayment periods and that there is more security for exporters.
However, the criteria are too imprecise, as the Development Committee has already pointed out.
Unfortunately, the Commission only refers to World Bank registration.
In the past, Parliament has repeatedly expressed strong criticism of the gross domestic product as the sole criterion.
The definition of upper-middle-income countries can refer to countries with a gross domestic product of 4 dollars or up to 12 dollars.
So that is a huge and far too wide a range, and it does not do justice to the realities on the ground in any way.
We certainly do not find it problematic that countries like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait are dropping out.
The reform in this regard was therefore good.
But these countries are high-income countries anyway.
Russia and China, on the other hand, are countries with upper middle incomes, and we certainly don't have to worry about them falling out of the APS.
But this category of countries also includes much poorer countries, such as Namibia and Ecuador.
Up until now, the Commission had at least also applied the criterion of allied countries, i.e., countries that export little or very few goods.
This at least prevents countries that are less dependent on exports and are very, very vulnerable from being rated too high.
Why, then, did the Commission highlight this criterion?
Countries such as the Dominican Republic, Fiji, Gabon, and Botswana, for example, will thus be excluded, even though their economies fall below the vulnerability criterion.
Why didn't the Commission continue with the old criteria, which were already somewhat inadequate anyway?
There is a growing suspicion that the Commission wants to force poorer countries into unfavorable free trade agreements.

The preference system, however, is an instrument for promoting development and cannot be replaced by pure trade instruments, in which the development path of a country or region no longer plays any role at all.
Fortunately, however, our colleagues in the plenary will still have the opportunity to agree to our amendment, which includes vulnerability as a criterion.
However, the new regulation also leads to trade regions being torn apart.
Neighboring countries in customs unions will soon have to follow different rules when exporting to the EU.
This has nothing to do with our goal of regional integration.
The Commission should focus more on developing regions rather than individual countries.
Here too, we Greens have submitted an amendment, which we hope will receive a lot of support.
It is also problematic when countries that have benefited from the APS until yesterday are suddenly dropped from the program overnight.
Transition periods are necessary, and we see in our own countries that a few months are not enough for economic development.

Ultimately, however, we Members of Parliament must also consider whether we want to focus solely on speed when it comes to all draft laws and then work with lopsided compromises, or whether we would rather involve the entire plenary.
I believe that the entire parliament is important for legislation, as is democracy, and it is not the speed that matters, but rather it takes time and democracy to enforce and properly pass laws.

Mr President, High Representative, I was also a member of the European Parliament's election observation mission in the Democratic Republic of Congo and was able to witness the hope and expectation for a better future with which people stood and waited at the polling stations to cast their vote.
We know today that these expectations were not met.
Although the Congo calls itself democratic, these elections were not fair or democratic.
We need to address this issue head-on, as my colleague Mrs Delcheva has done in her report.
Former President Joseph Kabila has declared himself a voter. The opposition is being suppressed.
In the east of the country, violent clashes between government troops and so-called rebels have flared up again, and it is unclear whether third countries like Rwanda are involved.
The civilian population is the one that suffers in every case, and has not been able to live in peace and quiet for decades now.
The country's wealth is squandered in a swamp of corruption, leaving the Congo at the bottom of all international rankings.

The international community of states, particularly the European Union, must use their influence to increase pressure on the President of the Republic of Congo to allow for genuine democracy in his country. He has the opportunity to do so during the next regional elections.

I am pleased that the Congolese army is not harassing the civilian population, but is finally apprehending internationally wanted criminals against humanity like Bosko and Djangga and bringing them to justice.
Internationally, all states should finally commit to no longer supplying any more weapons to the Congo.
Without external pressure, human suffering and poverty in this country will not end.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Tupac is intended to create further enforcement powers against crisis countries in the Eurozone.
The European Semester, which was established as a framework for necessary and improved coordination of financial and economic policy, is to be given teeth.
According to the Commission's wishes, Member States should be forced to accept financial aid.
The Six-Pack has already established extensive sanctioning possibilities that can be imposed on Eurozone countries with financial problems.
The European Semester is already being perceived by citizens more as a dismantling of democracy than as a meaningful economic policy coordination instrument.
At the same time, the German government is openly threatening Greek citizens with expulsion from the Eurozone if they make the wrong decision in Sunday's election.
Why don't we stop these humiliating and undemocratic threats?
In a situation where the Euro crisis has once again dramatically escalatedI am thinking of Spain, of Cyprusit does not help us to publicly shame the member states that are in the midst of the crisis.
We should finally develop solutions. The Tupac rapporteurs have developed some very sensible approaches to this end.
I did get a hint from Elisa Ferreira about the debt relief fund, which would be a worthwhile and sensible measure to combat debt.
But Jean Paul Gauzet's proposal of an orderly state insolvency is also sufficient.
However, it is crucial that Europe makes a joint and solidaric effort to put the Eurozone back on a growth path.
The strong countries in Europe must stop being complacent and pointing fingers at their partner countries.
They need to start doing their homework, investing in growth, and taking responsibility.
Angela Merkel's one-sided austerity policy has simply failed as a solution to the crisis.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in June 2010, the EU heads of state and government finally realised that the European Community needs a more coordinated financial and economic policy.
At the summit, you essentially invented the European Semester.
It is indeed entirely correct that members of an economic and monetary union cannot solely focus on how their policies affect businesses, workers, and consumers in their own country.
A European perspective is necessary.
An internal market without coordination in economic, wage, and social policy presents a great temptation for member states to create short-term growth and jobs at the expense of their neighbors.
Such imbalances can economically, but also politically, bring the monetary union to its knees.
And that is exactly the situation the EU is currently facing.

For years, the German economy has been draining the lifeblood from its neighbors, providing no stimulus through investment and wage growth, instead, Berlin has brought the Eurozone to the brink of ruin with a decade of aggressive export policy.
It is therefore encouraging that the Commission is slowly getting to grips with this core issue of the Euro crisis in its country-specific recommendations and is making corresponding suggestions.

The Federal Republic is quite rightly being called upon to invest more in education, research and childcare, and the Commission is quite rightly being called upon to stop the abuse of mini-jobs and to align wage growth with productivity growth.
This is a late, but important realization.
I hope, Commissioner, Mr Rehn, that you will vigorously advocate this demand to the German government, even if there is no formal procedure for surplus countries.

Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by expressing my thanks to the Commission, and particularly to Commissioner Barnier, for a very simple reason: the experience from the last legislative period, before 2009,

It was clear that, with the exception of a brief moment of awakening when the proposal for the European private company was put forward, Mr. Commissioner McCreevy, the predecessor of Mr. Commissioner Barnier, had essentially put company law to sleep, and that in these five years, this important issue, which is also significant for the internal market, had been neglected.
have progressed.
Fortunately, that has fundamentally changed.

In the meantime, there are a variety of consultation documents from the European Commission, an expert group that has been working on the issue of further developing company law, and we now have a brand new consultation that we, as a Parliament, are naturally also addressing.
The legal committee has decided that we do not want to do this in the form of a report, simply because a report would require additional time and, of course, would also be somewhat more detailed.

We have chosen the method of an oral question to the Commission in order to be able to discuss this issue with the Commission, with Commissioner Barnier, and at the same time to make clear in a subsequent resolution our position from Parliament on what should happen now.
I believe that it is necessary to develop a new action plan for European company law, similar to the one we had about ten years ago, and for many reasons.
There are gaps within European company law, real gaps, which basically mean that the single market is not complete.
I would like to mention as an example the absence of the 14th directive on seat relocation, which in my opinion is still a very typical example of such a gap.
Parliament has twice called in legislative initiative reports for the European Commission to come up with concrete proposals on this matter.
There is also the expert panel appointed by the European Commission itself, which has also expressed the same opinion.
It is simply one of the fundamental freedoms in the internal market that a company must be able to move within the internal market, including with regard to its registered office.
This possibility does not exist today, or only under extremely difficult conditions.

However, against this backdrop, I must also criticize the fact that the European Commission's statement on the 14th Directive so far actually falls well short of Parliament's expectations and, in our opinion, does not meet the standard of a qualified response to a legislative initiative.
I believe we are optimistic that, in the course of further work, if it comes to an action plan, this proposal will hopefully be included in the action plan.
Another important point in corporate law is the question of the further development of corporate law with the aim of reducing burdens for companies.
We already have very concrete proposals from the Commission on the table here, for example on the topic of
Accounting, but I believe there is more to be done and there are other aspects that will also be clarified during the consultation.
And here we are also expecting further proposals from the Commission.
I would also like to ask the Commission to revive the issue of the European Private Company, which is currently stuck in the Council.

If individual member states - and I can say this from my own perspective - if there are individual member states in the EU that are not able to break the deadlock on their own due to a lack of their own decision-making power.

If we want to move Europe forward, then we must consider using the instrument of enhanced cooperation, as we have done with other initiatives such as patents and family law, so that at least all other Europeans have the opportunity to benefit from this possibility.
I would ask the Commission to give this issue some more thought.
Another open issue is the question of applicable law, i.e. a kind of Rome regulation for cross-border problems in company law.
I also believe that this issue requires further investigation and discussion, and I would ask the Commission to do so.
And this is closely related to
We have the insolvency law, but it has already been announced that we will receive a concrete proposal from the European Commission in the foreseeable future.
You see, there is a huge amount of work to be done in corporate law.

I am grateful that Commissioner Barnier has taken the initiative here once again and that it is clear that we will receive significant proposals in the second half of this legislative period, which can also represent progress in shaping the internal market.
I believe that Parliament supports this in principle and in approach.
Of course, we will still need to discuss the details.
But for that, Mr. Dank also thanks the Commission.
And now, of course, we would be pleased if the Commission were to actually take up our initiatives and convert them into concrete proposals.
Commissioner, I very much appreciate your proposal regarding productivity-oriented wage policy.
But you cut a deal with Mrs. Merkel on the minimum wage, and I don't believe you about the question of job creation in the healthcare sector.
How is new work supposed to be created there when the Commission has already forced southern and eastern member states to reduce their hospital capacities by up to half?

How can employment in the healthcare sector grow when, in the new country-specific recommendations for the European Semester, the Commission is forcing some member states to further reduce their healthcare spending?
I fear this point in this plan is merely announcement politics, not a real initiative for new jobs.
On the contrary: even today, due to austerity measures, there is a shortage of medical supplies and medicines, not just in Greece.
I think that those who are constantly setting up new bailouts for banks must now work towards a bailout for the people, especially for securing medical care in the crisis countries.
Mr President, the mood among countless pro-Europeans like myself is one of frightened horror at what is currently happening in Europe.
It is, after all, encouraging that it is now being stated much more clearly what we are dealing with, and that Italy is not being ignored either.

They know for themselves that they are caught in a series of traps, not only in the trap of debt and growth, but also in the trap of trust and in the power trap of the esteemed Commission and also the Council.
Unfortunately, they have so far neglected to actually address the central issue of the separation of the financial sector from the real economy.
Everything we have decided here is repeatedly evaluated in expert opinions as follows: Furthermore, no serious limits have been set on the shadow banking sector.
Furthermore, we are dealing with systemic risks. The issue of "too big to fail" has not been adequately addressed, and there is little need to say anything about the rating agencies.
As you prepare for the summit, I can only urge you to also work on restoring credibility in Europe by seriously addressing the issue of power between the real economy and the financial sector.
In short, they are finally working credibly to ensure that the banks are brought to heel and that the citizens are not always left to bear the burden.

Mr. Colleague Frm, you come from a country that has rejected the euro, but presumably with the central argument that one wants to retain the flexibility of devaluation, especially for socio-political reasons.
In light of the experiences you have now had in Sweden, would you recommend that the Greeks also leave the Eurozone in order to be able to actively use this socio-political instrument of devaluation?
Mr President, I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the shadow rapporteurs and to the rapporteur.
We adopted this report in the Environment Committee with a substantial majority, with 62 votes in favor and zero against, and no abstentions.
This shows that we are actually very, very close together there, also in terms of compromises.

And of course, the top priority in this legislative process must be a high level of protection, a high level of consumer protection, especially for the little ones, for our society, for vulnerable children.
And when it comes to gluten intolerance, this is a problem, especially in kindergartens.
If you take a look around, I have two children of this age, and considering the prevalence of allergies and intolerances there, I believe we were in the right place.
And we should also discuss this with the Council and the Commission during the second reading.
I think that we will then also arrive at a good result.
Mr President, a report about a traffic accident at the weekend involving an HGV driver who fell asleep from exhaustion and drove into a ditch has once again confirmed to me how necessary it is,
how a clear and consistent regulation of driving and rest periods and their control by means of a digital tachograph is important for us, for road safety, but also for the people affected themselves.
The digital tachograph represents a certain innovation, it has new problems, but also old ones.
The new problems arise from new manipulation possibilities, which we also need to control technically.
The old problems are those that we can observe, so to speak, in the control or lack of control in various member states.
But what we are now regulating anew has, in my view, to take into account, first and foremost, that not every time when no journey is recorded automatically results in a rest period.
Because many drivers have to load and unload, and this is naturally also considered working time.
The second problem is that the speed records from the file were removed.
I think that's wrong, because there are also major accident risks here.
We also want to have weight sensors, and we also want to have a hotline so that fraud can be reported, which is anonymous and can be tracked.
What I will also be bringing forward is a motion that animal transport control be included in this regulation.
I think this is important because it is also a central element of our legislation.

Madam President, many thousands of people could still be alive today or would not have any lasting disabilities if professional medical help had been provided quickly enough after their accident, that is, within the first so-called golden hour.
We would be a significant step closer to Vision Zero.
Well, the eCall system we are discussing today cannot prevent accidents, nor does it absolve one from the duty to provide first aid.
It is only used to automatically inform an emergency response center in the event of a serious accident.
In order to prevent misuse and overloading due to minor accidents, it must also establish linguistic contact with the accident vehicle.
Only when the emergency call is confirmed or no one responds anymore, are emergency doctors sent to the accident site, equipped with a few, but life-critical pieces of information.
The responsibility for the functioning of this rescue chain lies subsidiarily with the Member States.
As long as the sensors installed in the vehicle do not detect an accident, the eCall system remains dormant, meaning it does not send any signals or data and is not located anywhere.
From a data protection perspective, it is therefore far superior to a mobile phone.
The system only becomes active when it is automatically awakened by sensors or manually triggered consciously.
It then sends an agreed-upon minimum set of information to an emergency operations center.
Europe-wide uniform standards and specifications will ensure that this data is recognized, evaluated, and handled upon arrival as an emergency call.
Therefore, the member states must also upgrade and expand their rescue circuits accordingly.

We want this eCall emergency call system to be based on the EU's uniform emergency number 112, to be free of charge for the user, to work throughout the EU, and to be compatible with the emergency call systems of neighbouring third countries.
It should be based on an interoperable, technology-neutral, open system architecture.
Other intelligent public transport services, such as real-time traffic information or availability of parking spaces, can also be offered through these systems at a later date.
In recognition of the automotive industry's outstanding achievements in providing private emergency call systems, these should retain their legitimacy alongside the public 112 eCall.
Users can also choose such a system based on comprehensive information.
This can be accompanied by cost and cost distribution.
the use of data for workshops, insurance companies, towing services or other service providers.
Mr President, a small village in Franconia is known for its good beer. This rhyme highlights a small problem that we have created for ourselves today.

Because if this brewery or the beverage retailer is 107 kilometers away from my home, I no longer have a chance that they will continue to offer me their products in the future, without them having to buy a new tachograph, without new bureaucracy.

And that is why, dear colleagues, I voted against this resolution today, because I believe that we should not impose too much on our small and medium-sized entrepreneurs. There were many points that we were able to include, which were positive, thank God.
It was planned to only accept 50 kilometers within the radius of a regional provider.
That was completely absurd of the EU Commission.
So with the 100 kilometers, yes, it's just barely feasible.
But what if it goes beyond that?
So I think it's exaggerated.
And one last point: As a representative of an employees' organization in the CSU, I also say that with this regulation, we are creating complete control over employees.
why
For example, someone who is responsible for construction or who sells beverages or brewery products is completely monitored throughout the entire workday via GPS.
For these reasons, and also for data protection reasons, I consider what we have decided today to be highly questionable, and I would like to reiterate why I voted against it.
Mr President, yes, thank you very much for this question.
Why am I not waiting for this decision?
I waited for the approval of the European People's Party in the Legal Affairs Committee when we were still in the process of asking the necessary questions about legal certainty regarding ACTA.
And there was silence in the forest and refusal.
They did not want that. Now it is obvious that the CJEU is to be used for delay, that is clear.
Why did I say that about the broad scope for interpretation?
Because you asked two questions, I have to answer both of them, unfortunately that's just the way it is.
Because one can read out and interpret anything from these broad formulations, such as Internet surveillance, auxiliary police officers, and ISPs.
And that means legal uncertainty. Legal uncertainty doesn't help our economy either, dear colleague.
Mr Leichtwelle, I would like to ask you: Are you in favour of discussing the modernisation of copyright at European level?
Or are you completely against the rejection of any intellectual property?
And how do you envision the E-Commerce Directive being adapted to modern conditions in the future?
From your statement, I gather that you reject any debate on these issues and do not stand for intellectual property.
Is that correct or what does it look like?
Mr President, it is becoming clear that this is not about individual facts that we need to discuss, but about the fundamental question: How do we stand with democracy and with civil liberties?
And when we look at ACTA, we see that it is in a way symbolic of a lack of transparency, of a lack of democracy, of a violation of fundamental rights, because it was negotiated in secret.

and democracy was achieved in a way, because the free use of the internet simply would no longer be possible afterwards, and neither would the freedom to use generics to the extent that has been possible up to now.
These are the reasons why millions of people have taken to the streets and have already voted against ACTA.
Yes, ACTA has been voted on in the streets, on the Internet, in relation to the Committee on Petitions, in very many countries, not just within the EU.
Also outside the EU. And I believe we must not ignore this vote, which is a vote of direct democracy by many citizens who elected us.
I can only tell you: put ACTA in the files, that would be decent.

Madam President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, as rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have completed two procedures under your presidency: the Financial Regulation, which provides a set of rules for the upcoming MFF period, and the OLAF procedure.
Since November 2008, this regulation has been pending in the Council, and you have brought this process to a close based on the results of the Polish presidency.
I would therefore like to thank you for two truly dedicated financial officers who have worked on these files, and also the Ambassador.
You will be missed, his efficiency as a negotiator will be missed.
They have truly earned themselves a reputation for looking after the financial interests of the European Union.
Thank you very much!
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking here now as the representative of my group and would like to support the motion proposed by my colleague Mr Fjellner.
Ladies and gentlemen, we do not have many raw materials in Europe.
The raw material we have here is our brain and our creativity.
This requires careful handling of the issue of intellectual property rights.
In order to clarify the outstanding issues, the European Commission has submitted this proposal, which it has presented to us, to the European Court of Justice for an opinion.
I believe that respect for the Supreme Court of the European Union alone demands that we wait for this decision.
There is objectively no reason at all to make this decision today.
No one is prevented from voting against it once the Court has presented its decision and its opinion.
But the decision that will then be made will take place in a different consciousness and a different awareness than today.
I don't mean to suggest that the wrong way drivers on the Internet highway should determine our policy, which is why I ask you to support this motion.
Mr President, as always, when Mr Turmes speaks, he is very wise, and one would wish that what he says had much more influence on European policy.
I wanted to follow up on that.
Of course, these project bonds are a good idea, but only if they are sustainable and if the necessary political foundations are established.
We run the risk of using guarantees to hedge against risks that we do not have under political control.

Concretely, the energy transition in Germany would require an 8 km network, but only 100 km of the corresponding long-distance transmission lines have been built, partly because of resistance from citizens, including environmentally conscious ones.
We need to come up with something from politics.
One idea would be to create joint transport corridors, combining not only high-speed rail lines and broadband networks, but also constructing corresponding pipeline networks alongside the highways.
However, this requires a much more comprehensive plan than the one currently envisaged, but I would like to at least suggest this at this point.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider Schengen to be one of the greatest achievements in the European Union. However, I am also aware that a country's borders are and always will be a very sensitive issue for our Member States.
I am aware that the problems between the member states regarding Schengen cannot simply be ignored.
There are various problems.
Ignoring does not make problems better, nor does it solve them.
I live on the border with the Czech Republic, and it would never occur to anyone here to want to close the border just because we're having problems.
But I also ask the Commission for support in this area, not for restrictions and reprimands.
The veil finding has been anchored because we want to ensure security while at the same time allowing freedom of travel.

And if we successfully carry out the veil negotiations, I assume that this will also apply at the borders with the Czech Republic, where one or another drug dealer is involved in many cases, not just a few.

If we try to find a transition in these cases, I think it would be a good idea for the German Minister of the Interior and the Czech Minister to sit down together and solve the problems at the border.
And the Commission should not regulate this, but rather act positively and supportively.

We want to put the populists in their place, but solve the real problems together. That is why I also ask the Council to work together with Parliament to find a solution so that we can successfully pass the Schengen dossiers, so that we have freedom of travel and at the same time ensure the security of citizens.
Mr President, the cases of disproportionate border controls that Parliament lists in its question also show why the Council actually wants to exclude Parliament from Schengen.
The Council wants to continue undermining freedom of travel without involving Parliament or without any form of parliamentary control, without any form of public scrutiny.
No wonder, then, that they prefer to pat themselves on the back in back rooms, away from uncomfortable questions.

It is no wonder that the German government wants to rule out any evaluation of internal borders altogether, without evaluation, and thus does not want to look at how much freedom of travel is being restricted.
However, Schengen does not belong to the governments, but to the people of Europe and therefore also to the European Parliament.

Mr President, esteemed Mr President of the Council of the European Union, esteemed Dimitris Christofias! It is a special moment for me today and for my group to be able to welcome you here in your capacity as President of the Council of the European Union.
And we are also pleased that, for the first time in the history of the European Union, a person is at the helm of the EU whom we can count among our political family.
You are taking over the presidency at a time when the European Union is facing enormous challenges, and it is necessary to set the course for whether the European Union
whether the Union will actually have a future or whether it will prove itself to be a footnote in history, which in my view would be a historic defeat.

After the discussions we have had with you, with the representatives of your government, with the chairmen of the parliamentary groups and parties in your country, I know that you are counting on this
You have prepared the new presidency excellently and are aware of the significance of your task.
But you have also made it clear today that you want to deliberately draw the attention of those in power to the living conditions of people.
I can tell you this: after all that I have heard in recent years, this is the first time that a President of the European Union has done and announced exactly that, and said: This tone

That is why I have long missed it in official speeches when they say: This is about the people, it is about those who are not responsible for us being in this crisis, but who have to bear the greatest burdens.
It is difficult to implement this approach exactly.
I believe, however, that a great deal would already be achieved, and I am quite sure that you will do this, if you primarily encourage people with your presidency and the way you conduct it.
exercise their rights and contribute to ensuring that the Council and the European institutions are fully aware of this task.
We keep talking about the euro and its stability, about the necessity, which I also see, that they are important for the functioning of the European Union and for the Eurozone.
But that is an instrument.
There were political conditions for this, which were defined.

It can never be the goal of the European Union, in order for the euro to function, to accept that people in the European Union must go hungry, that health systems collapse, that municipal administrations have to cease their work.
Something has gone wrong here.
It is not what we can call the goal of the European Union.
I strongly support your demand that it must be about social cohesion, about solidarity between the individual member states, but also between the various population groups.
The European Union must not allow itself to be repeatedly used as an instrument or spokesperson for a specific segment of the population, nor should it present itself in this way.

And one last point I would like to address, of course, to emphasize that everything you have mentioned in your priorities is important to us and that we will support the points that go in this direction, as I have just defined them.
Please do something to ensure that people are no longer afraid.
Fear is the worst advisor for democracies.
And I think that some decisions in recent weeks and months, particularly in the elections in Greece and the referendum votes in Ireland, were also driven by fear.
And if the rulers in the European Union contribute to people being afraid to make their own free decisions, then that is not a good sign for the future of the European Union.
Best of luck with your work!
I believe that we have a very important responsibility here, also as co-rapporteurs together.
The colleague will find it very important to work on this file quickly and reliably in the coming weeks and months.

The eyes of the world are currently on us and on the Council, waiting to see if we will take this step to overcome the banking crisis in Europe through a further step towards European integration, namely through a European banking union.
It should be noted that the Parliament demanded this with a broad majority two years ago.
We have conducted 26 trilogues.
We have taken a step in this direction, but unfortunately not as far as would have been necessary.
Additional billions in bills have been generated as a result.
It is good that the Council has now drawn the necessary conclusions and wants to take this step to further deepen the Eurozone.
It is commendable that the Commission has drawn up the proposals so quickly.
However, there are some difficulties associated with the Council's decision that the ECB should become the eurozone's supervisor.
This leads to unanimity in the Council and means that Parliament does not have codecision powers on this issue.
Based on the experience with the supervisory package, this is not acceptable.

And that is why it is important that we work quickly here, but also that we negotiate this proposal on changes to the ECB together with the necessary changes to the existing supervisory regime as a package, thereby effectively establishing the principle of democratic participation by Parliament.
Democracies also face additional challenges.
The ECB is independent in monetary policy, but not in fiscal policy, for which it has no responsibilities to date.

If it is now to be responsible for banking supervision, Parliament needs full budgetary rights, full control rights, the right to ask questions, the right to appoint, and I am sure that Parliament will fight for these rights by a broad majority.

We will thoroughly discuss the complicated issues in the coming weeks, including those related to the internal market, consumer protection, and the balance between European power and financial responsibility.
Mr President, by proposing to exclude developing countries from the preferred market routes, the Commission is attempting to push these countries into free network agreements.

They are not the free trade agreements that the term economic partnerships suggests, but are only concerned with the interests of the EU and not with the development interests of the partner countries.
This is completely contrary to the EU's goal of reducing poverty and aligning all external policy instruments towards this objective.
Countries such as Cameroon, Ivory Coast, and Namibia would be severely affected by this restriction.
Regional integration projects like those in South Africa would collapse if Kenya were to enter into such an agreement.
South-South cooperation would be at an end.
We cannot advocate for free trade in the world and only mean that other countries should kindly buy our goods.
If the Commission really believes that trade can promote development, then it should not block it.
The development committee of this house has recommended rejecting the Commission's proposal.
And we should support this in the plenary session.
Mr President, there are an enormous number of human rights problems in Central America, as well as in Peru and Colombia.
And we, as EU representatives, cannot simply close our eyes to this.
We will thoroughly examine the roadmap for human rights demanded by the EP in the case of Colombia and Peru, once it is drawn up.
It must have substance and be binding, and include initial results such as the conviction of offenders and the safe return of displaced persons to their land.
And of course it must also be available before the vote on the agreement.
We Greens believe it is right that the Trade Committee is demanding environmental and social standards in the proposed regulation on safeguard clauses, and not just tonnage restrictions for bananas.
The Trilogue must then confirm these, otherwise the regulation is worthless.
In fact, the EU must do much more to keep an eye on the situation on the ground and, above all, the impact on the local population.
And that is why we Greens demand a proper impact assessment before every negotiation, one that not only examines the economic consequences for the EU, but also the impact on human rights.
Mr Barroso, I made it clear in the first round what I wanted to focus on.
I am concerned with my group's expectation of the Commission to fulfill its responsibilities in the relevant bodies, such as the Troika, in order to make it clear that we

We, as a Commission, as a European institution, stand for the fact that people are not driven further into poverty, that working hours are not shortened, and that ecological and social standards are not undermined.
That is your task.

And if we succeed in making this clear, we will also be sending a signal to the people who are protesting by the thousands and hundreds of thousands these days, who have taken to the streets, and with whom we, as a group, also express solidarity, whether in Thessaloniki or in Barcelona.
I heard the news this morning that cancer patients in Greece are protesting and going on strike.
Where have we ended up, where people who are in deep social and personal distress can no longer receive any help and support because the health system has collapsed?
Here we must finally take action.
And I'll say one more thing: an approach that is in the minds of many responsible people is that the people in Greece and in other countries have been living beyond their means.
They must be punished for it today and must endure sanctions.
It is unfit to strengthen a European community, a community of solidarity.
I don't attribute that to you, Mr. Barroso, but this is an approach that is also prevalent in many countries and, unfortunately, is also repeatedly present in my own approach, for example.
Mr President, I admit, I made a mistake.
I would like to make a statement not on this report, but on the Moreira report on the agreement on immediate autonomous trade preferences for Pakistan.
I would then ask to be called up again.
