Madam President, the new directive establishes a framework for dealing with books, newspapers, artworks, films, musical pieces, and TV productions that are protected by copyright, but for which the rights holder cannot be identified, identified as such, or located.
Accordingly, books, films, photos, or other intellectual creations for which no rights holder can be found should also be made available to the public.
And thus a cultural treasure is unearthed.
For us on the Culture Committee, it was particularly important to emphasize the special significance of the diversity of the European Union's cultural heritage in this legislative initiative.

Our museums, libraries, publishers, and broadcasting organizations have countless unused works in their archives, and up until now, these works have not been made available simply because their rights holders are not known.
That changes with the directive.
It will enable the use of this cultural asset in the future, provided that a thorough search is carried out before publication.
This is a very important point, so that it is not said lightly: We cannot find the rights holder.
Because a balance had to be found between the real existing rights of the creators of works and the public's need to be able to use such works, where the legal situation cannot be clarified.
A particular focus for us was also ensuring that both known and unknown rights holders continue to be fully protected.
And where the rights holders cannot be found, the draft makes it possible to use the digitization of orphan works.
Projects such as Europeana and other major European digitization projects, as well as our museums, archives, educational institutions, and public broadcasting will be launched.
In the future, however, it must also be about opening up the orphaned works in the archives of private publishers to the public.
In my opinion, this draft of guidelines and the compromise that has now been reached is indeed a compromise and a first step in the right direction.
I believe that the cultural treasure that is too high has enormous potential.
And we should continue to work on this when revising the directive in two years.
Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would be pleased if we could also include clarity in the 2013 proposal.
We would like to see signals from the Council on how we can expand growth and competitiveness in Europe and, above all, how we can once again provide employment for young people.
Could you please tell us in which budget lines you intend to promote youth employment and focus on entrepreneurship and small and medium-sized enterprises?
We know that the CIP programme is the essential prerequisite for this. I only see cuts by the Council here.
or the Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs programme or the programme for media pluralism, here there are only cuts.
Do you really believe that we can overcome the crisis in Europe by making cuts in areas that guarantee growth and employment?
I heard that the Council is planning to propose a growth and employment package.
Where can this be found in this budget, which has been submitted by the Council?
Mr President, Nordseewerke Emmen had to file for insolvency last Wednesday because a guarantee from the Lower Saxony state government was not unexpectedly renewed.
This company, with 700 skilled jobs, is in the process of transforming from a shipyard to a supplier for offshore wind energy.

And now the idea is that this company can be saved through a mass loan and that jobs can also be saved, because the 700 colleagues at Siak and Nordseewerke have already had to accept significant cuts in their wages.

That is why I ask the Commission to examine this procedure benevolently, but also promptly, so that these 700 jobs are not jeopardized, because these 700 jobs are needed to organize the energy transition and to organize sustainable energy on the seas of Europe.
Please do not let the colleagues there suffer because of the state government's poor crisis management.
The goods from Villueus often look harmless, but in the hands of authoritarian regimes, they can be as dangerous as machine guns or tanks.
We undermine our foreign policy goals when we send surveillance technologies to authoritarian regimes that can use them to control and suppress democratic movements.
It was European mobile phone software from Nokia Siemens Networks that put Iranian security forces in a position to crush the Green protest movement.
Protesters were abducted en masse, arrested, tortured, and sentenced to death.
And that is just one example of many.
In addition, the Commission is said to be promoting these dubious dual-use goods through its catalogue of measures for innovative and competitive security industries.
The goal is to achieve a better utilization of the synergies between security and defense technologies.
We risk literally selling out human rights, as well as our security interests, for the sake of a questionable industrial policy.
That is why I would like to ask you to approve the amendments from us, the Social Democrats, and ALDE.
I would like to ask my female colleague Regner: What do you think the trade unions could do to combat youth unemployment in Spain and Portugal, for example?
Demonstrations will be too few.
What active policy could the internal market implement here?
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that with today's debate on MiFID, we are entering the core area of financial market regulation.
Those who have made it through this legislative period know that the issue at hand is to regulate the financial markets, not just to look at individual products, as we have done in the past.
I just want to mention a few key words.
We certainly didn't make things easy for each other last year.

We conducted a hearing in committee, we surveyed all stakeholders, all interested groups, and on the basis of this, we developed a result through various processes, working documents, and similar things, which we will present to the plenary for a vote today and tomorrow.
I want to highlight a few points.
Topic number one: Market structure.

On the one hand, we must, of course, acknowledge that a great deal has happened in the financial markets in recent years, and it is in our interest as a parliament that all trading in financial instruments takes place within the MiFID framework, which is why we are also introducing a new category under many conditions.

they have agreed to the so-called Organised Trading Facilities, where only non-equities are to be traded, where proprietary trading is to be prohibited, and where, in accordance with the execution and transaction and interaction of the clients, corresponding execution can take place at their own discretion.
I believe that this will make an important contribution to ensuring that the entire range of OTC securities traded is traded within the MiFID world.
Another major issue that was not addressed in the last MiFID is so-called algorithmic trading or high-frequency trading.

Here too, our goal was to establish clear rules of the game, so that this area, which can be very dangerous and can also be used manipulatively, is subject to strict regulations with minimum holding periods.

with trading interruption options, with the possibility of testing algorithms, with the possibility of a supervisory structure to monitor algorithms, with the introduction of a so-called tick size regime, a minimum price size, and through corresponding fee systems.
Another topic I would like to address is the area of true futures markets.

I do believe that we have a special responsibility here to limit the speculative component in genuine futures markets to such an extent that we do not contribute, through misguided regulations, to people in the third and fourth world being unable to buy food.
We have therefore adopted a two-pronged approach with the aim of curbing speculation, but without harming the real economy.
We want to achieve this with position limits, with strict upper limits on the number of contracts or positions.
However, we also want to ensure that those who can prove that they really need a product are not suddenly engaging in speculative market activity by implementing a so-called position check system.
Another issue that concerns us greatly is the area of investor protection.
I would just like to point out here that we have chosen a very broad approach when it comes to ensuring consumer protection and investor protection.
The aim here is to identify the needs of specific customer groups.
Not every small saver needs access to all highly complex documents.

It is about defining appropriate products for target groups, conducting product tests, telephone recordings, relevant consultations, disclosure obligations, but I also want to briefly mention subsidiarity in the area of commissions.
Member States should have the opportunity to make appropriate adjustments in accordance with their structures.
I think we are on the right track here.
After my time is up, I want to thank everyone who has contributed here.
I find it a shame that one only gets four minutes of speaking time for such a difficult dossier.
That is why I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have contributed to this, and the Commission for its very constructive role in recent weeks and months.

I hope that with a strong vote from the plenary tomorrow we will be able to enter into negotiations with the Council in order to conclude this important dossier as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, thank you very much for the generally good cooperation on this report.
We have been able to further improve a Commission proposal at key points, which already took major steps in the right direction.
There will be more transparency in the area of market structures, more comprehensive transparency, especially in the area of derivatives trading.

Under the MiFID framework, the decisions in the area of high-frequency trading in our compromise go much further than what the Commission had originally proposed, and deserve the support, especially of Parliament as a whole.
And even on the issues that have provoked widespread public criticism, the report points in the right direction.

In the area of commodities and food speculation, after major and difficult debatesit must be saidthe measures are now much stronger than the Commission's decisions, because position limits are now established as binding.
However, we still need further changes in this area to close any remaining gaps.
I also hope for further additions here through the plenary vote and eventually in the trialogue.
It is gratifying that Mr. Barnier has already signaled his support for the Parliament's more far-reaching proposal.
However, where the report has weaknesses is in the area of consumer protection.
We now have the ability to ban products, which is progress, but we still have no changes in the area of commission-driven advice.
The distribution of financial products is still not primarily oriented towards the interests of customers, but is heavily dominated by which product offers the most commissions.
Consumers in Germany, and throughout the EU, have lost a lot of money.
Remember the open-ended real estate funds.
Unfortunately, for citizens in France, Italy, Spain, and Germany, not much will change even after our compromise.
The basic principle will continue to be commission-oriented.
To refer to subsidiarity here is a bit too simplistic.
I would have liked to see stronger rules here.
Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, yes, all good things come to those who wait, I can only say that.
The report on type approval for L-category vehicles has ultimately turned out to be a good report.
The work took longer overall than we all thought and, above all, than we had hoped, and there was much more of a drop in cases than we would have liked in the end.
But at this point, I would like to once again express my heartfelt thanks to the rapporteur, Mr. Van de Kamp, for the truly cooperative and excellent collaboration.
Together, we have still been able to achieve a lot in the negotiations with the member states.
As the rapporteur for my group, I recommend that we approve this report. However, it could have been much better.
And by better, my highly esteemed colleagues, I mean safer.

For us Social Democrats, the safety of vehicles and thus the safety of drivers has been a priority from the very beginning. In particular, the safety of scooter and motorcycle riders has been a focus.
The number of motorcyclists involved in accidents has remained constant for years.
In general, the number of accident fatalities in Europe is decreasing, but not in the case of motorcycle accidents.
Reducing the number of motorcyclists and scooter riders killed is indeed a matter close to my heart.
Fewer deaths on Europe's roads - that was and is my goal.
Every death is one too many.
This issue must be addressed in depth, especially in a regulation that is so advantageous for the internal market.
I am still convinced that this can be achieved using effective anti-lock braking system (ABS) technologies.
And I am equally convinced of its cost-effectiveness.
It is simply not true that ABS is too expensive.

Nevertheless, we have achieved that, starting in 2016, all new motorcycle models and, starting in 2017, all existing motorcycle models with a displacement of 125 cubic centimeters or more must be equipped with ABS by the manufacturer.
Motor scooters can be equipped with ABS or combined braking systems by manufacturers.
Unfortunately, we must admit that we have not achieved any improvement over the Commission's proposal on this point.
I would have liked to see much more here, but the Commission and the Member States have, to put it mildly, shown themselves to be very slow to act.
We did, however, succeed in getting the Commission to present a report in 2019.
The report must be based on traffic accident data from the member states and is intended to examine the mandatory installation of ABS for motor scooters.
It shall also be forwarded to the Parliament and the Council.
On this basis of this report, the Commission should then consider making the installation of ABS in roller compulsory.
You see, the topic remains very, very much alive.
Therefore, we will attempt to close the mandatory legislative gap starting in 2019.
I am sure that the collected data will prove me right.
I am convinced that this is indeed a good day for two-wheel drivers in Europe and that accident numbers will decrease in the future.
Mr President, Mr Matthias Groote, there is no technology without risks. There is no perfect energy generation technology.
And I believe that also applies to what we are discussing here today.
I am very much in favor of us discussing this rationally.
What we are currently experiencing is a new development in the energy markets through unconventional resources, primarily in gas, but also in oil.

I believe it is neither appropriate to succumb to great euphoria about the future of gas, nor is it appropriate, as some of my colleagues from the Greens and the Left have done here, to paint dire and terrifying scenarios that have nothing to do with reality.

I think we need to bear in mind that these unconventional resources have the potential to change all the energy supply relationships we know between suppliers and demand, and that the economic calculations of existing energy sources are also being called into question.
We should face the development.

I think we should acknowledge that this can also be an opportunity for Europe, not just a risk. We should prepare ourselves to positively embrace and utilize new technologies, to fairly weigh the opportunities and risks, and not to fall into ideological debates.
Commissioner, your answer does not entirely satisfy me.
Because I think it's a very long time to wait a year between the notification that the complaint has been received and possibly only receiving a response so late.
I believe that a complainant who takes the trouble to file a complaint - and usually they have already gone through the entire legal process in their Member State - deserves more.
We rely on citizens to engage with the European Union.
If they do it in this form, we should treat them accordingly.

And I believe it is necessary and indispensable in the long term that we have a procedure here that is clearly formalized and clearly regulates the rights. This is now an explanation of how the Commission intends to handle this.
On another point, I have no objection if it serves the cause that one tries to reach a kind of consensual clarification together with the member state.
But that will not always be enough.
We observe that, for example, things move relatively quickly in economic matters when one company sues another for a violation of EU law.
But when it comes to environmental issues and similar matters, where a large number of citizens demand the European Union's involvement or social rights, things become a bit more challenging.
I believe that these facts also need to be clearly taken into account.
And I hope that in your next report, we will have a clear formalization of the complainant's rights vis--vis the Commission, which are truly clear and well communicated.
Once again, if we really want European law to be applied, after we have gone through so much procedure here in the European Parliament, in the Council...
We have decided on this together. Then we must inform those who are taking care of it, those who are really committed to Europe, as well and as precisely as possible.
That is a very, very important concern for me.
And I will also closely observe what has developed here next time.
Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, five years ago the EU's Central Asia strategy was launched.
When one asks today about the results of this strategy, the assessment is mixed.
We see how the member states individually strive for good economic relations, especially with the resource-rich countries in this region, but on the other hand, the efforts do not progress.
accompanying member states in their transformation process towards modern democratic societies, or, as the recent events in Kazakhstan show, development is even characterized by setbacks.

Nevertheless, or precisely for this reason, the European Union and its member states must express their influence in this region more strongly together, also and especially towards Kazakhstan, which has now become a major supplier for several EU countries.

An isolation of Kazakhstan by the EU would only lead to the fact that the competing powers for influence in this geopolitically important country, for which the emphasis on compliance with civil and human rights is not as important, could assert their influence even more strongly than before.
The core of the Central Asia strategy is the linking of economic interests with the commitment to safeguarding citizens' rights.
This should also form the basis for further negotiations on a partnership and cooperation agreement with Kazakhstan.
The present report provides a good orientation for this.

Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen of the absent Council, perhaps you are following us on the Parliament's video stream, since you obviously have neither the capacity nor the desire to speak with us live.
I consider the Council's absence here and today as a gross disregard for Parliament.
Instead of evading this debate, you should rather reveal your secret for why you are opposed to any improvement of personal data protection in the fields of police and justice through a directive.

Police and justice have been a hotbed of data protection violations for years, as we know - not only at SWIFT, but also on a daily basis, where data of citizens who, for example, demonstrate against Nazis, are unlawfully collected and stored.
We need the same protection standards for the public and private sectors, as well as for the police and the judiciary, in order to be able to guarantee citizens' rights.
If the Council demands that Parliament constructively participate in data protection-related regulations such as EU PNR or Europol, then this must surely also apply to the Council in reverse.
That is why I urge you to finally put an end to the blockade policy in the area of data protection!
